instruction: Why can't bank use cash as capital as a buffer for potential losses?
output:
Why can't bank use cash as capital as a buffer for potential losses? If a bank lost its ability to earn profits, maybe it's worth less than zero? I am not saying it is, or that even if a bank loses a lot of money, it can't make it the next day. What I am asking is, how could the cash be used by the bank as a temporary buffer (capital) without its being considered as equity? Why capital should always be equity instead of cash, when it is still the same bank? I think the FDA could also benefit from it.
We are always told that the USD is the world's reserve or base currency. What does this mean? That the banks can hold on to it? I was asked to hold on to my USD so that's what they do. The government has never borrowed and held on to any of that USD. There has been no capital and there is no capital. So what does such a reserve currency signify? I don't get it.
This reminds me of the 1997 crisis: What makes the USD (and other government bonds which are USD-denominated) special and different from the bank's own asset (which is also a USD-denominated bond but not so good)? I would say the answer is nothing, but I was told not to be cynical.
I would really like to understand this.
It's the US as a nation.
If the US is no longer a nation, I really don't know.
I don't feel like I have made any progress on that answer.
If so, then it's the US as a nation.
I would really like to understand this. It's the US as a nation. If the US is no longer a nation, I really don't know. I don't feel like I have made any progress on that answer.
You got it. The US as a nation.
I am not American but I get it. The same goes for all countries, and maybe even groups of people. What I'm getting at is, what does it mean to be part of a nation? How can a nation keep on being one after what happened to Iraq, Libya and Afghanistan? I feel like I should know what I am talking about instead of just making some random comments.
In my case, what I feel is that a nation is a group of people that feel like they belong to each other. So by losing the statehood that made them belong to each other, they have also lost their nation.
I'm glad I got your point. How did you think we were going to end this?

instruction: convert December 21 ¬∑ 1:00 ‚Äì 1:50pm pacific to asia/taipei time
output:
convert December 21 ¬∑ 1:00 ‚Äì 1:50pm pacific to asia/taipei time December 26 12:00 ‚Äì 12:50pm
The Dangers of Giving Information Online
On Nov. 23, the ‚ÄúVietnamese-Americans Online: The Dangers of Giving Information Online to Immigration and the FBI‚Äù workshop was held at the JCPA. The ‚ÄúInform and Protect Yourself‚Äù workshop was a free two-hour interactive educational discussion concerning information sharing between Vietnamese immigrants and the FBI.
The goals of these workshops are to increase public knowledge of informants‚Äô actions, to develop safe tactics when informing about family members or acquaintances. The workshop also highlighted the importance of making educated decisions about our communities by engaging our government in discussions.
The Vietnamese-American Online informant, Huong Lam, spoke first at the workshop and explained what a Vietnamese informant with an intelligence background would do in order to extract information from a Vietnamese-American, such as using ‚Äúcultural shocks‚Äù by suggesting a trip. The cultural shocks are to make Americans feel that they are being a good and generous citizen by sending money to the informant for charity, and that they are being a great friend by staying at their house.
This strategy is very effective, because most Vietnamese Americans are proud and generous. According to Lam, the Vietnamese Americans usually help when they are asked by anyone for any kind of assistance. For this reason, an intelligent informant could easily manipulate a Vietnamese American into doing things that they would not otherwise do.
After the cultural shocks come the language pressure and the threats. In most situations, the pressure on the informant‚Äôs family is just as important as the direct pressure on him or her. Most of the time, the informant fears the consequences that his/her family will have to face in their community, the deportation of themselves, or of their family members. It is very typical of Vietnamese to try to protect their children from harm.
Huong Lam pointed out the importance of having knowledge about the information the US Government wants us to share with them. The US government wants to know where in the United States all Vietnamese are, whether they are employed, are student, are unemployed, have kids, don‚Äôt have kids etc. Once an individual starts sharing their family information, there is not going to stop collecting information.
Within the discussion, participants were asked to share their personal experiences, if any. I was the first of the participants to speak and share my thoughts. When the US government asked me to help with ‚Äúterrorism investigations,‚Äù and to send them names of ‚Äúother Vietnamese‚Äù in the U.S., I felt very upset. I was in the middle of dealing with a death in my family.
I don‚Äôt think my grandpa would have sent anyone else in our family into an investigation, even if we did not have the capacity to pay the informant. Moreover, it was very upsetting to learn that my grandpa had to go to court to tell the judge to not make my grandpa send someone else in the family to a court.
Luckily, my grandfather knows the law better than me. This made me realize that I should probably talk to my parents about the whole situation. It was also very surprising for me to hear that my grandpa had to talk to the judge in order to tell the judge that I was the only one in the family who had the responsibility and resources to send someone to the government.
I also found it interesting to learn that people are very vulnerable when they have to deal with losing someone. The Vietnamese American Online informant then talked about how it was very important to be able to know the language the FBI speaks when dealing with Vietnamese Americans, so that the government can not only trick Vietnamese Americans and get their information but also to protect oneself from others in the community.
Huong Lam talked and made joking remarks that the Vietnamese Americans who cooperated with the FBI, and gave the government information, especially ones living in the suburbs of Massachusetts, would be considered by people in Massachusetts to be ‚Äútraitors.‚Äù When they go out to eat in Vietnamese restaurants, they would not be welcomed and would be looked down and disrespected by Vietnamese American people living in Massachusetts.
It is even more surprising that people in Vietnam, for example, do not think that the US government does not collect information on the political activities of Vietnamese immigrants here in the US. They believe that there is freedom of speech and the US government does not collect this type of information on the people

instruction: I'm currently studying Bioengineering in Argentina, focusing on computational neuroscience. I'll be graduating in May, and planning to apply to PhD programs in the US at the end of the year in order to start August 2024. I'm thinking of what to do/study during this year until my program starts. Could you give me ideas? Feel free to ask me for questions which would help you give me better suggestions.
output:
I'm currently studying Bioengineering in Argentina, focusing on computational neuroscience. I'll be graduating in May, and planning to apply to PhD programs in the US at the end of the year in order to start August 2024. I'm thinking of what to do/study during this year until my program starts. Could you give me ideas? Feel free to ask me for questions which would help you give me better suggestions.
1. Post by: E-tard 35-8-1 23:56
2. RE: Need help.
i think bioengineering is a good idea. it is a good foundation with a lot of biochemistry and other subjects that are related like computer science, statistics, etc. it shows you that you can think out side of the box and have a broad view on various things. it will make you a more competitive candidate when you apply.
your biochemistry will be important as bioengineers usually have experience in the field
chemistry can never hurt either. i would say that bioengineering will prepare you the best for life in grad school though. i just think bioengineering is a good idea. it is important to understand things from the basic science point of view. it is important to become very aware of what is going on in the world and not just what is going on in your own field. it is also good to understand that the basic science is not as basic as people tend to think and it is not as simple as most people make it out to be. a lot of good bioengineering work is done by people in the life science fields who do not consider themselves to be bioengineers but that would be a good thing for you to learn.
I see. Thanks a lot. Could you suggest me other things to study?
sure bw. i'm a big believer in learning things. if things interest you, you can always learn something new. my rule of thumb, however, since time is money, is that if I think something will be useful enough in the future, i get it done. with that in mind the things that i would do is:
1. Learn the basic statistics. you can find basic statistics online or just google it. i would say 50% of graduate school is learning to calculate stuff. this includes things like correlation, covariance, normalization of data (mean, standard deviation, etc), standardizing data, doing a student analysis (t test, ANOVA, etc), and plotting data.
2. Learn computer programming or if you already know it work more advanced stuff. if this is what your research focus is, then you must understand the programming part behind the research that you will do otherwise it will be hard for you (and your lab) to advance. computer programming is the language of science and it's very important
3. you can take any type of course that interests you. i have a friend that took an entire course and learned how to fly stunt kite (you would be surprised how much of his graduate school work has been directly related to this course). i think it is a good idea to take courses that are only useful to you and not your program. i think a good idea is to take a writing, music, math, sociology or other very random courses and learn them.
i would say if at all possible learn computer programming. if you already know it go beyond the basics. the basics of programming are learned in the first year. learning computer programming is something that takes a lifetime. my graduate school had a programming class for people who wanted to learn more computer programming and those are things you will never learn in biochem or the hard sciences.
a good idea is to take a writing, music, math, sociology or other very random courses and learn them
these courses aren't that random. the point is that many things are interdisciplinary. i agree that you should take classes but they have to be useful.
i agree that you should take classes but they have to be useful.
it is not what is useful but what is interesting to you. if you think it would be interesting to learn how to sew, it probably is not useful but it is something that you can go do. if you can do this and enjoy it, then go to school to do this. a lot of what you do in research is interesting to you.
I get this. So, let's suppose I decide to learn programming or data analysis. Do you suggest I start by reading a tutorial? Or is it best to take a course? Also, I'm thinking of learning guitar. Do you think it's useful to do? What do you recommend?
guitar is good if it would interest you. but there is no point in going to guitar class when

instruction: Give me a sample 5 day itienary for a switzerland holiday, starting from Basel
output:
Give me a sample 5 day itienary for a switzerland holiday, starting from Basel.
At 14:07 29th Aug 2008, nmf wrote:
Most of us enjoy travel and in some cases we may spend quite a bit of our own money on holidays.
However, when I read about a couple of the well known TV travel presenters buying holidays and handing them on to their co hosts or spouses, I was left very annoyed.
Some of us buy an A-Z map and may spend a day or afternoon planning where we want to go when we fly off to Europe or even further than that.
We might buy or use one of the travel agents, we may book online.
All of us are in the same position. We are not experts and we do not go to the same places in Europe and as far as I am aware, we are not the experts!
What ever the travel TV presenters may tell us we should or should not do, our experience may be totally different.
This is not fair on them.
This is not fair on us.
On top of this, we are paying money, to go on holidays and we know we are not the most intelligent, clever people on the planet, or as the travels say, we know we are not travelling experts.
What ever happened to the honesty that we are looking for? All these travel TV presenters are experts at saying yes, but where is the honesty.
Yes maybe they do get invited, free or they may get an all expenses paid holiday and they may be told to go to one hotel this year, another hotel the next time they go and so on.
We know from the TV that they have a lot of people running around, organising things, they have someone making them look smart, they have someone who is looking after them while they are on holiday and some of the travel TV presenters get more money from the newspapers (who are paid by the holiday companies of course), than some people get from a full time job.
We watch this, we enjoy it, we are fascinated with it. We go and organise our holidays, not that we need to do it.
I don't think the travel TV presenters realise that, when they go on holiday, they are in a position where many of the normal people can do the same!
Is telling us what we should do, a good or a bad thing? Maybe a couple of them who started when the travel show were just starting, back in the day when holidays were cheaper, perhaps told us how to get the best value and I can remember that I learnt a lot from that.
I then had a job and at night, when the kids were at school and they then had computers in schools, I still had time for an afternoon out and a week or so in the summer holidays.
When I left home I still had time for short breaks.
I think I got that from the TV.
When money got tight, I still managed to go on holiday.
However, I think they have a position of responsibility.
We take on board what they say and this is not a good thing.
Most of us are looking for the right advice. Some will listen and some will not.
All I am saying, is tell us an honest opinion, what do you really think? If people still book and go to the places you think they should go or not go to, then I don't mind if the travel TV presenters get paid.
How can they say a couple or a family should go on a package holiday, when most of them, have not stayed in the same type of hotel for years. Some of them are in the very same hotels the same people who they are giving advice to are staying in?
Why is that ok? If someone on the travel TV presenter's team go and stay at a hotel, do they tell us and say they are staying there and what a bad hotel it is, because it is not one of the hotels they favour? or perhaps the hotel staff or management do not do the things which the travel TV presenter thinks is good hotel service?
If I see a travel TV presenter on my TV and they are telling us what places to go to, I would like to know if they are getting paid for it?
Do we ask them about where they buy our clothes/shoes/mobile phone/gadgets etc and on what terms? We know some TV presenters are on "contracts" and do certain things, as this seems to be normal now.
When I see some of these TV presenters walking the streets of London,

instruction: explain The Death of Ivan Ilych
output:
explain The Death of Ivan Ilych of this book but it was not part of the discussion. My assumption is that he will cover it in his first lecture next Monday.
I‚Äôve read The Death of Ivan Ilych but not On the Boundary of Two Worlds. I still don‚Äôt know when we‚Äôll get over to The Brothers Karamazov, but I have to finish my other reading first and then I can finally read it for the read along.
I‚Äôm not sure what to make of the novel. I think it‚Äôs rather bizarre but interesting. It is definitely a product of an evolution of Dostoevsky‚Äôs writing.
I thought Ilych was bizarre, too. Very experimental, not in a good way.
Yes, and the first-person narrator does that experimental stream of consciousness thing in some places.
I read it last year. When I first started it I thought I wasn‚Äôt going to enjoy it much but by the end I loved it. It was quite bizarre, as you say, but fascinating, at least for me. It made me feel that I was part of Ivan‚Äôs world and I could not be sure if he was ever going to experience a real death or a spiritual transition on the other side if there was one, or indeed a transition back to life. I felt that I was a fly in an ointment jar.
I do think that Ivan Ilych made a transition from life to death, without a definite transition into an afterlife, and then transitioned back to ‚Äúnormal life,‚Äù although it might have been a continuation of his spiritual journey. I did not read it as a fly in an ointment jar. I thought that Dostoevsky was describing the stages of dying from the disease that Ivan Ilych had, using a different perspective than before the disease.

instruction:
Why is it that only proteins, carbohydrates and fats are deemed to have caloric value?
Just to clarify - consider the hypothetical situation below:
100g of 'carbohydrates' = 400kCal
100g of 'protein' = 400kCal
100g of 'fat' = 900kCal
100g of 'vitamins, minerals and/or other electrolytes' = ?
output:
Why is it that only proteins, carbohydrates and fats are deemed to have caloric value?
Just to clarify - consider the hypothetical situation below:
100g of 'carbohydrates' = 400kCal
100g of 'protein' = 400kCal
100g of 'fat' = 900kCal
100g of 'vitamins, minerals and/or other electrolytes' = ?kCal
So why does the first one have 400KCals but the second 400KCals? So can you see how this is a bit inconsistent/unfair?
Also, consider the 10-95 percent rule (http://www.dietitian.com/t-calorie-content-of-food&category_name=81#81)....10% proteins x 400kcal = 40kcal, 95% carbohydrates x 400kcal = 360kcal. In this case, why isn't there 360kcal of 'carbohydrates'? It's pretty much just math, i.e...to find out how much all of the individual ingredients in the foods are contributing to the food's calorie value. I suppose that the 'calorie' value and weight percentage of individual ingredients in food is used to calculate how much of a calorie/gm of a food is available i.e. what percentage of the weight of the food is carbs, fats, protein etc. Also, from what I remember reading somewhere....the idea comes from the fact that the human body can only use about 80kcal per 1gm.
I don't have an issue with the Calorie/g being given - it's simply used as a metric to see how much food is going to impact your calorie/fat intake if you eat X number of grammes. However, when the 'Calorie/kCal' is also given...then this can throw people off a bit, as we don't really eat grams and if you look at 100g of protein / carb / fat as a weight for the body then that'll give an accurate measurement I guess....it's just not one in my opinion that most people are going to want to try to measure/follow. When the weight for food is given, you need a more accurate measure with a 'gr' for grams in my opinion......then the Calorie/KCal will appear to be a more logical thing and will work. One last thing to think about is that the body will respond in a very different way to eating proteins, fats or carbohydrates i.e. you can store more fat in your body, your metabolism will work/be slower with the fats and carbs...and you can gain more muscle mass/strength than you would if you had protein for the meal (and the gym training).....this is where the Calorie/KCal starts to come in.....once we start thinking about eating for weight training or general muscle development e.g. gaining muscle or losing fat or maintaining muscle and fat, etc then the Calorie/kCal does start to make sense too.
The main reasoning for there to be a KCal unit is that it has been used for a long time and thus people are already used to it. It's a standard that works...and it's still easier to use. In terms of units, it's far more easier to convert 'Calories' to 'kcal' and far more people know what 1000kcal looks like than it is to try and convert 'Calories' into 'grams'. Of course, if we start going into KCal units then it's the other way...I might end up saying 'give me 2400Kcal and I'll give you 1000g of Protein (or whatever)'! And just in case you were wondering - in terms of storage/consumption, in the UK at least, I'm pretty sure that there IS an official standard for Calory/grammes of foods and one for 'kCal/gramme'. This is mainly an issue with foods that you'd buy in a supermarket and there is also an official standard of units for restaurants/c

instruction: Navina has $30 more to her weekly budget than her younger sister and can afford to get one of the many online credit cards she likes. What do they each have to spend?
output:
Navina has $30 more to her weekly budget than her younger sister and can afford to get one of the many online credit cards she likes. What do they each have to spend? And do either of these teens have a chance to pay off their credit card and car loans in 10 years?
‚ÄúI definitely agree with the 10% rule,‚Äù Navina said, adding that a student can begin investing at 18 with just $500 a month, or $8,000 a year.
That‚Äôs great, but Navina had a bigger challenge than investing. She wanted to take out a mortgage on a house, but her credit was shot and she couldn‚Äôt get approved. So she enrolled in a credit course for high school students at her local bank, where she learned to fix her credit. She also learned to apply for college by filling out the FAFSA form for federal financial aid.
Navina also found that with no income or student loans, a 20-year mortgage was out of her price range because it required that half her take-home pay go to pay off her loan. Even with two incomes, her sister was taking on a loan that would take up 70% of her family‚Äôs combined income.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure I‚Äôll be able to take out a mortgage at half my income because I‚Äôm not going to have student loans to help me,‚Äù Navina said. ‚ÄúI need to save up at least $10,000 for a mortgage. I want an eight-minute commute to school.‚Äù
So now this bright young woman had to take on a job because she really wanted to afford a car on her own. But she didn‚Äôt have a driver‚Äôs license or a car to insure. (Her family only has one car.) And the cost of her driver‚Äôs ed course, car loan payments and the $35 monthly insurance fee is equivalent to what she puts into her budget each month for food and entertainment.
She‚Äôs in a quandary. Saving up for a house is too time consuming because she needs more than four hours of free time each week. But taking on the expense of a car and insurance to go to work is impossible and eats up the hours she does have to work toward a college degree.
How did Navina get in this situation where she had to get a job when she‚Äôs trying to build her own career? The answer is fairly simple, I believe.
Navina is a consumer who is still learning how to be smart about her spending and how to control her budget.
Navina is a worker who is learning how to earn her way in the workforce, and she is being held back by her parents‚Äô income because they are both unemployed and she is earning at least $50 per week more than they are. The family income is less than it really should be because Navina‚Äôs mom has been unable to find a job for a long time.
My suggestion to Navina is to learn about managing her spending and income better. Then she‚Äôll be able to make the decisions about when to get a driver‚Äôs license, a job or a credit card.
And most importantly, I suggest she spend some time on a career to become the professional who will guide other girls through the consumerism that will mark the next generation.
My advice is to follow these tips:
Set a goal for saving, not spending.
Start now. Even if you make $3 or $5 a week, use that to develop the habit of sticking to a budget that you set for yourself. Start by saving in an account your parents won‚Äôt be able to access. Put your allowance and other cash or change into a special ‚Äúdeposit‚Äù account. Then do the same with any income you earn so you can follow your own personal spending plan. This will require good money judgment about spending and saving more than $10 a week. But that will help you build the skills you‚Äôll need to manage your own finances.
Be the smart banker.
As the smart banker, learn to open and use a checking account to keep track of all your spending money. And use an online site like Mint.com to develop good habits of staying on budget by balancing your outflow and income. It‚Äôs easy to learn and free for this year, so sign up and go ahead and use the site.
Be sure to read my previous post about how to get a mortgage to make a down payment on a home in your future.
If you don‚Äôt already have a job, get one now. One of the first things you must do

instruction: define a new language that contains words that are with numbers and letters such as 'IL9op'
output:
define a new language that contains words that are with numbers and letters such as 'IL9op' and the system will still work. For an additional safety feature, the user must still enter the password that was set before the system was enabled, and after entering the password another button will appear and when the click it everything will function as usual, such as 'enter date' will appear and when clicked 'IL9op' will appear. Another advantage of using the 'IL' (IL: English) language is that when a user does not enter the same password because he forgot it, he can still continue typing without worrying about pressing the 'enter' button 3 times or he can always go to the 'back' button in the browser and select it. The application will always work in any language and user does not need to set any language, because before using this application it will already be familiar with the 'IL9op' language and will work correctly. The disadvantage of this language is that, from a technical point of view, the application will need to be downloaded to the computer 3 times in order to install it. After this the user will only have to download the 2-3 applications that he will want to use. After the user will have the application downloaded to his hard drive 3 times he will be ready to use the language. It will be good if the applications which will use this language can detect the language automatically. It will be a better option if the user will define his language before downloading the application (from the browser), so that when the application which was not developed using this language will be downloaded the system will automatically detect the language and open an additional window on another screen telling him to choose his language, but this problem is not a big one and can still be improved.

instruction: Mick pays his teacher $800 for 40 lessons worth 2 hours each. If this will be all he is going to pay for his lessons, how much did he receive?
output:
Mick pays his teacher $800 for 40 lessons worth 2 hours each. If this will be all he is going to pay for his lessons, how much did he receive?
Say that $800 is equal to $5. When you write the math, you multiply x by 5. In this example it might look like $5x.
Let x be the number of lessons he paid for.
Say that x = 20, then 5x = $80. $800 was what he paid for 40 lessons, so this is $20 each. So he paid $20 per lesson.
If she charges 2 hours of teaching for 35 lessons, what is the charge?
When you write the math, you would write it like $5x = 275.
So what does x stand for? x is the number of lessons the teacher taught.
Let x = 35. When you divide 275 by x, then you will receive the amount per lesson. So, 275/x = $15 per lesson.

The most basic form of a strategic plan is a one-page document outlining objectives, strategies, resources and timelines.
In some cases, however, it is more appropriate to create a multi-page strategic plan -- outlining the same things, but in greater depth.
If you have more than 3 pages, you're most likely adding information that is best presented in more than one page. Consider breaking larger sections into their own attachments.
There are three components to a strategic plan: an overview, the goal the team needs to work toward, and the resources -- people, places, and things -- that must be in place for the goals to be achieved.
This document should outline the following: a summary paragraph of the vision/goal of the plan, the overall resources needed, and the team that will be involved. The plan should also clearly define who is responsible for each element of the plan; this may be done by listing each member of the team or by designating a different person as the owner of each element.
Include here what your mission and vision are, and state the primary goals the organization has. What do you want to accomplish? What do you want to be when you grow up?
This section takes a strategic look at the company's future. It helps the reader understand where the company is heading, what its priorities are, and its focus in the current year and beyond.
This should explain who you are, where your resources come from, the kind of work you do, and what you do to excel at what you do.
Talk about this in the 5-year projection.
It's critical that when a strategic plan addresses a specific action item, every team member agrees to be accountable to that commitment. Accountability can be assigned to specific individuals or groups.
If a strategic plan fails to take each person's perspective into account, the plan can quickly derail. You can have an excellent plan in place, but if the people and the resources needed to execute that plan aren't aligned, the strategy will fail. To ensure a successful strategic plan, the team has to understand everyone's unique perspective -- including the people who are not in the room with you.
One of the basic elements of strategic planning is to be clear on the target: what exactly does it mean to "succeed" in the eyes of the team?
Be as specific as possible, making sure to cover things such as: what specific financial figures do we want to work toward; what do we want to accomplish with new and existing services; and what do we want to say to customers about our value proposition.
A clear vision is a critical element of an effective plan. A team may set one-year financial goals, but if the organization can't achieve them, there's no point in completing the plan.
How much do we want to grow/make/do?
How will the world change in order to make this possible?
If you have a budget, you'd better stick to it. If you don't have a budget, you should be willing to commit the resources required to execute the plan.
When should the strategic plan be implemented?
When should each element of the plan be completed?
What resources will be spent for each project in the strategic plan? This is a key element of the financial projections that must be aligned with the team's desire for success.

(E. G. Poggiolo 1999.1) * One can either be subjected or not to the others if he is either related - subject (meaning: to have an identity) - or not (meaning: he does have an identity). (E. G. Poggiolo 1999.12-3) * One has only one identity but many subjectivity (one subject in relation to many others). (E. G. Poggiolo 1999.12-4) * Human relationships are reciprocal: one is (either) subject to the other(s) and the other(s) are subjects of one another (at least insofar as the relationship is a human relationship). The human subject only exists in being subject to the human other(s); the human being can only have an identity in being subjective to the human others. (E. G. Create an Annotated Bibliography, in APA citation style, with six entries describing a different social media technology in each of the following six categories: blogs, social networking sites, virtual social worlds, virtual game worlds, collaborative projects, content communities. To help you get started, see this article about APA writing style. If APA style is new to you, it may be helpful to use this Online Writing Lab: APA
Use the following guidelines when creating your bibliography:
List sources alphabetically by the first author s last name using the hanging indent method. Hide all other authors
Name the entire title of the primary source (with no abbreviations or alternate words) in bold text and in italics
Include the publication year; no periods after the year are necessary
Use title case (capitalize the first and last words, as well as all words except for articles, prepositions, and coordinating conjunctions) for all headings
List all of the authors' names in full (Do not abbreviate either last name or year)
Include the source title without the word "Online" after it (unless the title clearly indicates that it comes from the online version). If the source is a web page, include the URL after publication information

instruction: What does Nassim Nicholas Taleb say about market efficiency?
output:
What does Nassim Nicholas Taleb say about market efficiency? What does Edward Bullard, the former editor of the Financial Times (and the current editor of the Economist) say? What does Paul Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve say (as an expert)? What is Taleb‚Äôs opinion of how we get information? What do the editors at the Financial Times and the Economist know about markets? If they know anything and you don‚Äôt, then who is right?
2 The Winner‚Äôs Curse and Selling A Carrier
Those who sell cars today use what I consider to be a very basic strategy, which I had occasion to use myself. I had to get rid of my car back in 1993. It needed repairs and I wasn‚Äôt going to pay for them. I knew that its resale value would be low as it was, in my eyes, of limited utilities. I also wanted to get a deal on the taxes for the vehicle. I decided to sell it to myself. The price was low and the car was of no value to me. I kept it for a while. It was a Volkswagen Rabbit and in a few days after the sale, I received a letter from the VW organization. It informed me about the resale value of the car and inquired what the value of my car was. I gave it the value I had sold it for and sent the letter. I never saw the car again. I received a check in exchange for the car and a year or so later, a friend of mine, the owner of a VW specialty shop, called in Boston to complain to me about a deal he had not done. He had heard from a customer that the stereo installed in my car was the best money could buy. How could that be? He had inquired, to no avail, as to who sold me the Rabbit. My wife and I had bought the car locally and I took it to his specialty shop for the installation of a much better sound system than the original one. He found out in the end that it was the VW specialists who had sold the car to me and that it was a different one. (Yes, I have a very low self-esteem.) The VW store sent me the stereo it had installed before. But it turned out that this stereo was no longer available. It took a lot of calling, but in the end VW installed a much better stereo for me (for a fee). The moral of the story is that if you want to make money at selling a car, you must do it in a few days. The car turns to be of little value to anybody as soon as somebody purchases it.

The result is a sound that is a cross between Kings of Leon, The Arcade Fire & The Killers and that makes songs in the realm of the Lumineers and City & Colour that are not only catchy but emotionally charged. With a recent string of successful performances that have included SXSW, a support act for The Good Lovelies & a European tour - we can't wait to see what's next.

instruction: antennas that transmit an equal amount of energy in the horizontal direction are called
output:
antennas that transmit an equal amount of energy in the horizontal direction are called
antennas. These antennas should be far enough away so they do not interfere with each other. Also
noted is that all the wireless signals transmitted on the ground will be intercepted by the transmitter.
This means that other buildings, trees, vehicles, and other large sources of wireless radiation will be
intercepted by the receiving antenna. As with any communication system, a large amount of signal
will be lost due to the large interference.
There are two ways to minimize the interference. The first method is to use antennas that are
directed to where it is needed most. These antennas can be as wide as the area that interference
comes from or only as far as can be extended away from that area. This will minimize the loss
of signal but will still cause a large amount of interference. The other possible way to minimize the
interference is to adjust the direction of the antenna. This method will cause loss of some signal due
to having the antenna oriented in the wrong direction but at the same time will increase the signal
gain in the target region. Another disadvantage to this procedure lies in the need of reconfiguring
the antenna periodically due too interference. This method is only for systems that require a
large amount of signal and need to be targeted to a small area.
Both of these system components are only the two ways to minimize interference but do not
reduce the amount of interference received. Also noted in Fig. 1.6 is that there is an area where
the signal strength will be much lower than it would be with the ideal system which implies an unacceptable
reduction in communication and a possible reduction in effectiveness of the system as a whole.
Fig. 5. Sysm and the interference of wires.
1-8-1 WIRELESS SYSTEM ADVANTAGES AND DISADVANTAGES
Advantages and disadvantages of wireless systems are well summarized in Table
Wireless systems of transmission are advantageous because
they may be easily installed and reconfigured and require little room for installation. They allow
flexibility which a hardwired system cannot.
They also allow for many additional features such as the possibility of releasing multiple
frequencies and multiple signals in the network. Although this may be beneficial to the network as
a whole, it can be harmful to those within the network and interfere with the wired network. They
also allow for a much longer usable life which is crucial when installing multiple wireless systems
or using wireless networks that are far apart. The longer life of the network will reduce the amount
of reconfigurations and expenditures for new nodes and links.
Although wireless networks are versatile to install, they also have several disadvantages.
They usually do have a higher installation cost, and as mentioned earlier, their operation requires
considerable expense over time. These components can be minimized as some wireless systems
can operate with power supplied by the signal to be sent or can operate at a reduced power
supply thus saving in expenses. Wireless transmissions are often not as fast as those of a
hardwired system due mainly to the limited speed of the modulation schemes and signal power
levels. The transmission speed for wireless system can be further enhanced by introducing
frequencies with higher bandwidth to the network which can then be used for the data transmission.
Wireless systems also have a shorter range of operation when compared to a hardwired
system due to the lower signal radiating power, and as seen earlier, the loss of signal between
antennas is unavoidable due to the interference of other hardwares and antennas. In addition,
the presence of water, metals, conductors, and concrete will also degrade the signal performance
on a hardwired system. Since this is not the case with wireless systems, the range of operation
will increase substantially. As mentioned in subsection 1.3.2, the presence of walls or buildings
also affects how far the signal will propagate. With a wireless connection, however, this is not a
problem since there is no hardwired connection.
1.9 SYSTEM LOAD
The system load of a wireless network is determined by the distance that the signals travel in
spread spectrum modulation as shown in section 1.7. The distance that is measured is called
the Doppler spread of the system. This distance is shown as

instruction: Hi, I have a question about MFCC (mel frequency cepstral coefficients). Are they the same thing as a MEL-spectogram, or is there a difference?
output:
Hi, I have a question about MFCC (mel frequency cepstral coefficients). Are they the same thing as a MEL-spectogram, or is there a difference? Thanks.
Greg: They are somewhat related, but different. The Mel-frequency cepstral coefficients are what you get when you compute a Fourier transform of a mel-spaced spectral cepstral vector.
However, the mel-spaced spectral cepstra are simply a matrix that holds how the spectral energy is distributed across frequency within a mel scale, so there is actually nothing special about the mel-frequency cepstral coefficients. They are just the first few entries (frequency domain) in the Fourier transform of this matrix, much like the first few entries represent the first few harmonics of sounds.
Therefore, since there is nothing special about this representation, you should always try to do all your operations in the spectral domain whenever possible and this is why the Spectrogram would be used to create the mel-spaced spectral cepstra.
Therefore the mel-frequency cepstral coefficients, as a vector, are really a representation in the frequency domain of what the spectral cepstra looks like, much like a mel-spaced spectral cepstra is a representation of what the full spectrum looks like.
This is why the mel-frequency cepstral coefficients and the mel-spaced spectral cepstras are similar, yet a little different.
There are some interesting results that come out because a mel-spaced spectral cepstra matrix isn't really a frequency domain representation. For instance, the frequency content of the mel-spaced spectral cepstras do not represent what the original signal's spectral content looks like. That's why you often get funny representations like the one you get from a mel-spectrogram because that's effectively the same thing as what the full spectrum looks like, but in the frequency domain. That's also why you can do other interesting operations on mel-spaced spectral cepstras for analysis, such as how to find the average magnitude and frequency in a mel-spaced spectral cepstra matrix.

instruction: who was the black cabinet member who went on to play an important role in the civil rights movement
output:
who was the black cabinet member who went on to play an important role in the civil rights movement when he was the Assistant Attorney General to Thurgood Marshall.
He brought the civil rights litigation to the court. And so with the help of his colleagues and later on with the help of people like his colleague Justice Marshall but also with Howard University, they would host all of these conferences. That‚Äôs exactly what was in mind. The goal in mind had to do with the idea to really educate these African American lawyers because the only access to the legal system was through the university law schools. It was up to Howard University to really make a point of saying, ‚ÄúLook, we‚Äôre going to send our students out to law school, we‚Äôre going to provide them with everything that they need because by 1964 what we need to do is to make sure they have a chance to succeed.‚Äù And so that‚Äôs what‚Äôs that‚Äôs where these conferences came from as an idea and an effort.
Later on, and you‚Äôll hear other stories about these kinds of conferences with the NAACP that‚Äôs, you know, for example, that‚Äôs where we got the Legal Defense Fund which was created by Thurgood Marshall and other civil rights lawyers coming out of law school. We got the NAACP through these conferences. So the conference that you see in the film is part of this ongoing tradition that really started at Howard University.
Eugene: So we talk about access, we talk about the need for access to education in general and specifically in this case to a legal system and a legal education. Would you talk a little bit about your film focus and its impact?
Judge: We talk about access but we also talk about people who are willing to do the work that that access opens the door for. You know, if you have a university that doesn‚Äôt have a law school, well access is important. The access might be to a university or the access might be to a court. This is what Howard University became about. It went from a university of black people‚Äôs dream to an intellectual leader that produced lawyers who actually went on to lead a movement.
We have a civil rights act and one of the best examples of that is actually in the conference because President Kerr, right? He‚Äôs been president since the mid-40s when he was here. He is a professor of psychology. He‚Äôs been a professor of psychology his whole tenure as president. In 1961, it‚Äôs the time that he was a professor of psychology. But what he‚Äôs also the president of Howard. He also is the president of a university.
And at that point, there is no Civil Rights Act. He‚Äôs trying to figure out how to talk to these lawyers about how to change civil rights law. He didn‚Äôt necessarily understand the history of civil rights policy. He wanted to bring in people who understood that history. This is the president of the university. He invites these people because they‚Äôre the best among us. You know, they were the best law students of their class at various law schools.
Eugene: He‚Äôs inviting the best and brightest to come to Howard and that starts a movement to make legislative change.
Judge: Yeah. I think sometimes we forget but you know, the work the legal professionals have done to change civil rights law is enormous and the work they did in the 1950s as part of the Brown case is that in the 1950s they brought in these lawyers to teach these law professors at Harvard and other law universities how to argue for the NAACP‚Äôs position that segregation was wrong. You know, it was something that the lawyers of the day just couldn‚Äôt quite see through the legal system. What would happen if we start allowing for, you know, equal access to things that people of color weren‚Äôt allowed to do before?
Eugene: So we‚Äôve seen that a number of ways in terms of legislative policy and judicial policy through access to education and access to legal education, access to justice, that‚Äôs the next question. In this film, obviously, you‚Äôre asking a question about access to justice. For me as a lawyer who really cares about that, access is really the big deal. And we talk about it in terms of diversity, we talk about it in terms of equity, but at its core, it‚Äôs about fairness.

instruction: Over two thousand years, the moon has covered every point on the Earth once. At the most recent time of a moonrise, the moon is going to cover the next point to the north. How far north will it be?
output:
Over two thousand years, the moon has covered every point on the Earth once. At the most recent time of a moonrise, the moon is going to cover the next point to the north. How far north will it be? The point nearest to the moon's path over two hours previous is at 50 degrees north.
The moonrise point is 7¬∞ west of 50 degrees north. The sunrise point is 31¬∞ west of 50 degrees north. The sun is going to be in the sky for 2 hours. If you are standing at the moonrise point 2 hours before the sunrise point, you should be standing at the sunrise point 2 hours after the moonrise, 20 degrees (15 + 4 + 5) to the east of the moonrise point.

sunrise
point. That's
the opposite
of the moonrise
point.

Beyond the time of sunrise, the only thing you can know for sure is that there will be stars in the sky, and at sunrise, there won't.

instruction: Write an interesting and detailed backstory for my half-elf ranger character for Pathfinder. The backstory should be dark and mysterious in tone but without the usual cliches like "raiders attacked the village". Make it unique and interesting. Be creative.
output:
Write an interesting and detailed backstory for my half-elf ranger character for Pathfinder. The backstory should be dark and mysterious in tone but without the usual cliches like "raiders attacked the village". Make it unique and interesting. Be creative. It can be whatever you want.
The backstory should be set on the world of Golarion (and the campaign takes place on that world). I don't think Golarion is real but that's not the point.
It can be set anywhere in Golarion except the Thassilonic plane of existence.
The ranger must have an elven racial feature either natural armor, dark vision, or the ability to speak and understand elven. A drow or halfling is not elven enough to be considered for the backstory.
The ranger's race must have at least one subrace (see below). Only subraces must be used, other racial features can be ignored. For example a drow could have darkvision and natural armor, not drow subrace.
At least one subrace must be used in the background. It must be either an elf, orc, or drow. Half-oaks from other subraces is not needed for the backstory but is encouraged.
Only one subrace must be used from two elf subraces. If the character is a half-elf the other elf subraces may not be used. For example, either a half-elven elf or half-drow ranger may be told, but a half-elven half-drow isn't relevant.
The ranger could start in the human subrace if that was easier to do with the backstory.
The ranger must have a human language and be able to speak it fluently.
The ranger must have at least one of the following three feats: Scenic View, Eldritch Heritage, or Danger Sense.
Any of the feats listed in the Skilled Ranger background are allowed.
The backstory can be about the ranger, or about a parent before they became a father.
The player cannot add additional subraces, feats, traits, or racial features, or change the racial feature and subrace used.
For example, if the ranger was a half-elven drow ranger, it is allowed but not encouraged to say that parent was half-elven and not half-drow. The parent could not be a human half-elf half-drow.
There will be at least one surprise element, and that element will not appear in the first two posts. It will start the third post though.
No background on the character until the third post, then you can post the character in your current campaign. You must keep the campaign on Golarion except for the element of the backstory not being in the first posts. This is so players can be fair to each other by not using any information from the backstory in the game.
Use as much detail as possible. Be creative!
The backstory will be graded.
The player will be told how well they did in the form of a grade. Their grade will show up when they post the third post, when they make the first post. The grade will be on a scale from A, to D. The player will get 0 if they don't add at least one element of surprise.
A= Excellent! You surprised us well, you put the most effort into the backstory. You clearly put a lot of thought into your backstory and it came out great. Well done!
B= Good job! You surprised us well, although you put less effort into your backstory. You put the most effort into it that was good enough. You can't win an award but you're doing okay.
C= Average. You made a good average backstory, but it wasn't really anything more than average. Most players try that too, and it's better than what we're used to getting.
D= You tried, but failed. Your average backstory didn't surprise us at all. Even if you tried to surprise the others, you didn't succeed. You've made many backstories but none of them impressed us greatly. This one is better than the average backstory, but it's a very low average. Hopefully that means you'll do better next time.
F= It was obvious from the very start what the backstory was going to be. We could see the whole thing from a mile away before you even said anything.
You've done such a terrible job that your grade will be a F. You'll probably have trouble making a backstory in the future that

instruction: In this math problem, we are asked to figure out the percentage of total profits that are made in each quarter. They are 90% in the first quarter, 92% in the second quarter, 81% in the third quarter and 88% in the fourth quarter. What is the total profit percent over a period of time, based upon these quarters?
output: In this math problem, we are asked to figure out the percentage of total profits that are made in each quarter. They are 90% in the first quarter, 92% in the second quarter, 81% in the third quarter and 88% in the fourth quarter. What is the total profit percent over a period of time, based upon these quarters? You'll also need to know how to use the decimal multiplication and division symbols to change decimals into a suitable form when doing the problem. Let's get started! To figure out the percentage that is made in each quarter, we take the number of times each ratio appears, which is: R1: 21%, R2: 92%, R3: 81%, R4: 90%. Then, we take the product of these numbers, which is: (90%*21%) + (92%*81%) + (81%*88%) + (88%*90%). (90%*21%) + (92%*81%) + (81%*88%) + (88%*90%) = ((90*21 + 92*81 + 81*88 + 88*90)/100)*100 = (74/100 + 75/100 + 71/100 + 80/100)*100 = 93/100*100 = 930% You'll want to remember that this percentage works out to be: total profit over the course of a quarter: 90/100, total profit over the course of half a year: 90%, total profit over the course of full year: 900% You can see that the total profit percentage is indeed: 100% - 80% = 175/100 = 17.5% You can remember this as: 100 - amount to sell: 20; remaining is profit: 80%.

instruction: Why is it a bad idea to give a mouse a cookie?
output:
Why is it a bad idea to give a mouse a cookie? It‚Äôs a good book!
Asked by Cora 16 months ago
Crystal is absolutely correct, it's very good indeed. I read it with a group of adults and we all enjoyed it. I have a personal thing about giving children cookies. (You might call me a control freak. Okay, I might call myself a control freak.)
So I'll give the mouse a tuna sandwich instead. Maybe a handful of crisp lettuce leaves. It needs fresh air!
Answered by Linda Johns 14 months ago
Ok this is a cute story. I just have a problem with it having to do with my health. We know that sugar and all the things that make cookies have effects on our health. But so many parents and children think that sweets are ok. That is not right. Parents need to wake up. It may be cute and funny to read. But if these stories get repeated over and over again. It will have effects on our children.
How did the mouse get the cookie?
I'm not sure if anyone will answer this question but, how did the mouse get the cookie?
How did he find the house?
And how did the cookie find him?
Answered by Cora 15 months ago
Well, the book doesn't specifically say, but it appears that he entered the house from the back door, which had been left open. And, I suspect that a mouse (or small child, for that matter) would be able to snatch a cookie from an open plate. As far as the mouse's finding the house, I think his instincts told him to go there looking for food (or shelter); or, maybe he just took a wrong turn.
That doesn't really answer my question but thanks anyways.
I was about to offer the same answer about that back door being left open but the book never mentions it. I did wonder about it though.
Crystal, you are correct. I'll make a note to update my answer to help with the confusion. Thanks for bringing that to my attention.
Answered by JBonding 15 months ago
Hey Linda--I can see your point: It's certainly not what I'm trying to do is advocate the giving of all cookies to all mice (or adults, or children or anything else.) I just thought this was an amusing story and I'm curious about the origin of the line. I'm guessing it started out as a joke about a really bad idea that no one should consider. But the story just doesn't make sense without it.
I do agree with your main point: I think we could and should do more to teach our children about healthy eating. And I know that it's a lot easier for parents to buy and sell caffeine soda pops and chips in vending machines and 7-11's than it is for them to sell fresh air and sunshine. It's a problem. But I digress...
Answered by Crystal 15 months ago
That is true. But when the child get to be older they are thinking why they got to do their. Maybe they need to do it in the morning or in the evening or they need to eat healthy like you said.
And this book is about how the cookie found the mouse.
This story is based on the old saying: "If you give a mouse a cookie, he'll ask for a glass of milk". It has nothing to do with healthy eating, except that maybe if you give your children tons of cookies and milk, they'll be too drowsy to run around until they're fat instead.
And I agree Crystal, you're also right. Parents do what they can to give their children everything. So I can definitely understand where you're coming from.
In my opinion, I'm not sure how the mouse got the cookie. I'm thinking the backdoor was left open and the mice just walked right in. That's my opinion!
I think his instinct told him to eat. Also, his hunger got the best of him. He needed to eat and that's all it came down to.
Answered by LJJohnson 15 months ago
That was a really funny book but the line always confused me when I read it. How did the mouse get the cookie?
I think this might be a question the writer might not have answered himself or herself. It's not a great book but in my opinion it's a cool children story.
Answered by Tracy 15 months ago
So I'm guessing

instruction: which second messenger molecule acts on the endoplasmic reticulum to release calcium ions
output:
which second messenger molecule acts on the endoplasmic reticulum to release calcium ions into the cytoplasm?
The endoplasmic reticulum, as part of the cytoskeleton, helps to move things around inside the cell.
The endoplasmic reticulum is an organelle with several functions, including synthesizing proteins and storing calcium.
The endoplasmic reticulum, along with the Golgi apparatus and the lysosomes, is a part of an organelle system in the cell known as the endomembrane system.
In the process of protein folding, the endoplasmic reticulum serves as a temporary "storehouse" to let proteins settle down before they are fully formed.
The endoplasmic reticulum is an important part of the cell's membrane system.
True or False: The endoplasmic reticulum is an important part of the cell's membrane system.
The endoplasmic reticulum is a structure found within eukaryotic cells where protein is synthesized.
True or False: the endoplasmic reticulum is a structure within eukaryotic cells found where protein is synthesized.

During mitosis, which of the following is the region containing the nucleus?
The main function of chromosomes is to carry protein synthesis (RNA transcription) genes.
The microtubules, microfilaments and intermediate filaments are part of the cytoskeleton.

instruction: How can anti-deressants make people think or act suicidally? Suicidal thoughts or actions' are a side effect of every single anti-depressant I've seen. Is the medicine controlling your mind or something?
output:
How can anti-deressants make people think or act suicidally? Suicidal thoughts or actions' are a side effect of every single anti-depressant I've seen. Is the medicine controlling your mind or something?
Is it the mind control pill? No one can believe it is the mind control pill!
"I was walking through town on Monday and I saw on of our own members!"
"It was none other than Lena."
"Was I glad to see her!"
"Came across me at the park with my husband!"
"And did she speak to you?"
"That's right."
"Say anything?"
"Not a thing!"
"Hmmph. She must've thought about it, that's obvious to see."
"She must've thought about it!"
"Yes, I mean, she had time to think, we were at the park, she was alone with me! And what did she think, what did she think when she saw the other side, what did she think when she saw the happy side?"
"I know what I think about it."
"You know, Lena? You must have been thinking: What the hell is this? Is this what you wanted? But it's not, we tried everything, I mean, I really tried. And I found it to be true: that what matters most when we're struggling, when we're not so well off, is love."
"We tried everything."
"Yes, I mean, we tried everything, but in the end, when all's been said and done, when everything's finished, it's always just the same: it's always love."
"And everything's finished."
"Everything."
"And love never fails."
"No."
"And love never gives up."
"No."
"And lend to the Lord your ear."
"Yes, I mean, he may not have been lended to us, no, but we learned to love ourselves. And if one can love one's self, he may also love another. I'm happy for you, really."
"Well that's the thing. It was no use."
"Well how come that was?"
"Well, it's just something that happens, I mean, how many people can handle it, how many good people and what not?"
"Who don't handle it?"
"No one handles it, not properly."
"That's just ridiculous."
"So you think so?"
"Yes, I think so."
"So you'd say you don't handle it, do you think?"
"No, I mean, I like to try, but I don't succeed."
"That's a shame."
"Why? I mean, the poor people who handles it are so few and far between, no one likes it when they fall apart like that, they're just so... you know, poor."
"But in a world with a God, the only God that matters, how can one not handle it?"
"I'm trying to handle it as good as I can."
"Do you really think God will be satisfied with that?"
"I have no other option."
"You need to tell the Lord what happened and He'll help you out, believe me. Trust in the Lord!
It may be you don't have enough faith."
"Do you think that could be a reason?"
"Yes, I mean, if faith is a factor, then you need some more faith."
"What do you mean?"
"Well, I think you need to turn to the Lord Jesus, you need to take up your cross, and follow Him, if you want to receive His gifts, you know what I mean."
"I don't know what you mean."
"You really don't know?"
"Well, I know, but I don't know if Jesus cares."
"That's just ridiculous talk."
"Well who the hell cares if it is."
"So you won't take up your cross?"
"No. To receive His gifts is too much of a gamble."
"Too much of a gamble? No, it isn't. And if it is the gospel we have to worry about, isn't it our eternal soul at stake, isn't it our salvation that we have to worry about? Isn't it something that concerns only you, only yourself, that you're interested in, your own ass, and not someone else's? Don't you see then what it means to have faith and to believe?"

2. Create a game plan where students will practice all skills. Students will practice all four skill types (reading, writing, speaking and listening) in different activities.
3. Students will make flashcards and then test each other using them. This way they will have to listen to what they were reading. After the students take the quiz, they will read new words (for revision).
4. Students will work independently on the booklet. Then their peers will evaluate their work.
5. At the end, students will be asked what they learned or understood about the topic in class based on their reading and peers evaluation.
Lesson Plan for Teaching Intermediate Students on the topic of Tackling Difficulties
1. Teachers will talk about the topic of tackling difficulties in a general way. Explain that difficulties are unavoidable parts of life and it is important to be able to handle yourself in those situations.
2. Ask students to make group of four.
3. Have them make a plan in which they will talk about what they can do to face a certain difficulty. To help them, teachers will give them a template where they can write what they have to do.
4. Students will write a paragraph to which they will have to attach (write) some actions they have to do (in order to face/solve the problem) and their personal feeling when facing it.
5. Students will read it and do the same. This way they can have feedback from their peers
6. After reading and evaluating partners paragraphs, they will have to write some actions they think are necessary to tackle their problem.
8. Teachers will give them a homework with the same activities.
Activity of the Day: Students will listen to songs where the singer tells his/her story and is asked to make notes of what it is about.
Lesson Plan for Teaching Advanced Students on the topic of Tackling Difficulties
1. The teacher will give students a questionnaire where they will have to answer: what have you done in order to face a certain problem?
They will be divided in groups of around four students and will do a presentation on those activities.
2. Students will write 5 activities to tackle difficulties in a paragraph. To do it, they will be give a template.
3. Students will read the paragraphs and they will do the same.
4. Students will decide which of the activities they can apply in their lives according to their interests (studying, music, cooking‚Ä¶)
4. Teacher will give a form with a question that students will have to comment. Then they will make another form with their comments.

output:
Draft a ministerial speech outlining the top five benefits that innovation brings to the Australian economy. The speech should outline the economic importance of science, technology, entrepreneurship, the need for a skilled and flexible workforce and access to global markets. Innovation in health, medicine and education should be a key part of the speech. It is also possible that a major challenge would need to be addressed. The opportunity should be used to clearly communicate the government s commitment to innovation and highlight its important role in the future of Australia s economy. 37

instruction: Write a section for an award application detailing how photography has insipired you
output:
Write a section for an award application detailing how photography has insipired you and been a part of your life.
Inspiration is such an elusive thing, so this part can be the hardest and take the most time.
If you need help finding your inspiration, consider these questions:
What was my first camera and why did I want to take photos?
What type of photography do I enjoy taking the most?
Whose work has inspired me the most? Why?
Has travel influenced the way I take photos? Why?
Is there a particular time period I like to photography or a particular scene, culture, or subject matter I'm drawn to?
Why do I take photos?
Has a particular book by a famous photographer or writer inspired or influenced my writing? Why?
Who is my favorite photographer and why?
Another place to start is browsing through your photos. Have you been able to accomplish something you were really proud of? Did that accomplishment influence how you felt, helped your confidence, made you proud of what you could achieve?
Has technology influenced your photography? Why? How?
I love the above question. Have so many technological breakthroughs made it easier to be creative or do we overuse these new ways of creating and sharing images? What is the future (as in 10 or 15 years) for camera technology?
If possible, include a section for a friend or relative to fill out. It's one thing to describe yourself, but it is usually more helpful to hear from others how they see us.
Use this part as an opportunity to highlight how your photography has changed your life or inspired others, friends, family, co-workers, or acquaintances, etc.
I had fun recently while writing my statement. It made me look back at photos and my photography history and it made me feel great about what I've done. So I encourage everyone interested in applying to do the same.
If you want more inspiration or someone to bounce ideas off of, try taking a photography class or find yourself a trusted friend/colleague who knows you well and is also a photographer.
You don't have to do this alone, nor should you feel that you have to, but having someone to bounce ideas with and talk with can really help you figure out what you want to say.
Take your time with it.
What if your statement doesn't win the award?
Well, as my friend, fellow photographer, and fellow AAF member (hey Dave!) says, "It's not a popularity contest, it's not a popularity contest, it's not a popularity contest, so stop worrying about popularity."
But seriously. If you do win, great. If not, the award panel has already seen the quality of your photography and written statements, and may see your work as a finalist in another award category or simply at the top of the list of your peers. Don't let a loss bring you down.
Also, know that many professional photographers don't win first place, so you are in very good company. You can view the 2009 Gold and Silver Award Winners here, but also know that many of the 107 Gold Medalists didn't win the Grand Award. And that many, many more didn't win any of the 37 awards given in their respective categories.
Take the time with your statement and make sure you have a good argument on why you deserve the award and what you have accomplished in your career.
Make an argument, don't ask for an award. After all, you won't get it if you don't ask, right?
What's the next step after you have finished?
I'll discuss this next week, so tune in soon and check out what I have for you Monday and Thursday, as my next two weekly segments will be about writing your statement for an award application.
Until next week, happy writing!

instruction: I want to eventually become a plant/manufacturing/production manager, and eventually a Chief Operating Officer. output:

Cameron Rice, President, CE and BMO Wealth Management North America, Bank of America What factors do you consider as top priorities in identifying and selecting a good candidate? instruction: explain the basics of area and perimeter
output:
explain the basics of area and perimeter. With a number of hands-on activities that require students to use their mathematical reasoning and problem solving skills, this book is perfect for students aged 10-12. Included are sections which show clearly how to work out area and how to work out perimeter. There is also a glossary at the back, plus space at the end of each section for students to work out a problem, put down their answers and draw in the diagrams. It is fully teacher-supported, with space at the end of each section for teachers to add notes to the book. Each activity is followed by a number of questions, which can be used to consolidate students' learning. Also includes a section on converting measurements from metric to imperial and back and a timeline of important events in measurement.
Issues in Science
Science is a fascinating subject with a huge amount to learn but it can also lead students to think deeply about their position in the world around them. By encouraging discussion, Issues in Science helps students recognise, understand and debate scientific issues that are of concern to them. This book focuses on the relationship between science and human health. The first part of the book explores how medical research has developed and its impact on human health. It includes sections on DNA research and genetic engineering and explores the relationship between science and health. The second section looks at environmental health - how pollution affects human health and the ways in which humans can cause problems for the environment as well as how to protect it. This section includes a glossary explaining environmental science terms, a quiz on how humans can affect the environment in a negative way, and a short project that looks at how to improve water quality. The final section focuses on the health of individuals, including sections on the human body, exercise and nutrition. It includes a practical project on how the body can get energy from substances that it absorbs. This book is perfect for 11-13 age range students studying towards their Core Science GCSE. It has a glossary section at the back explaining some science terms, and space for teachers to leave notes. It is fully teacher-supported.
In Issues in Science, students can explore a wide range of scientific topics in a structured way to increase self-confidence, encourage critical analysis, promote personal development and help students to understand the role science plays in society. Discussions at the start of each book encourage an open mind and the text includes a short quiz at the beginning to stimulate students and to check that they are clear about the scientific issues. Topics covered in the book include science and food and issues relevant to food consumption such as GM foods and obesity. This title also covers the controversial issue of animal testing and encourages students to reach their own conclusions. With a glossary at the end to explain scientific terms, Issues in Science is perfect for 11-13 age range students studying towards their Core Science GCSE.
Getting Started with Science is packed full of activities and science experiments to bring Science to life. This title contains a variety of stimulating and challenging activities that will encourage and inspire any future scientist. Topics covered include food and nutrition, light and sound, materials, forces, and rocks and soils. With the aid of step-by-step instructions, the reader is taken on a journey of discovery and learning. Suitable for use at home or at school, this title offers a great way to study!
The Science Club Book 4
The Science Club Book 5 combines both science and math, with a wide variety of experiments to try with friends or on your own. Written for junior scientists aged 11-14, the book takes the reader from the basics through to more advanced studies, explaining the science behind all experiments in comprehensible terms. The text is clear and well laid out and is complemented by large images and step-by-step demonstrations. With full teachers' notes provided, this title is ideal for science enrichment or as a reference for GCSE studies. Also contains a number of short projects, such as converting temperature measurement on degrees Centigrade and Fahrenheit, converting distance measurement from miles to metres and kilometres, and using data collected to create a line graph.
A series of nine maths books for 9-11 year olds, written specifically for UK schools. The books aim to support classroom learning by giving extra practice using a variety of different activities. Books 3 and 4 cover the following subjects: Fractions; Percentages; Rates of Change; Ratio and Proportion; Measures of Circles; and Area. Teacher's guide available for each book.

instruction: Write a story about Anakin Skywalker encountering a Jedi who speaks and acts like a 1920s British aristocrat
output:
Write a story about Anakin Skywalker encountering a Jedi who speaks and acts like a 1920s British aristocrat. Every time our hero talks, he has to follow-up with a question. (You could give the character a silly hat.) It's amazing to see.
Ewan McGregor can act. I guess. But let's cut him some slack.
YOUNG OBI-WAN TO YOUNG ANAKIN: "Don't tell me about your dreams, pal!"
YOUNG ANAKIN TO YOUNG OBI-WAN: "But that's your dream!"
SAD VOICE: "I said I would kill you, didn't I? I swore on it, my whole fucking force!"
STOP IT. STOP IT. STOP IT. STOP IT.
When he gets a chance to see his mom, who's been taken to a mental hospital.
In his mom's asylum bed, Darth Vader tells the kid that it's time to leave his mom. "You can never come back," she tells him. "I'm Darth Vader." And then Darth Vader proceeds to use the words "Darth Vader" five hundred times over the next few minutes.
This one's really good.
Vader is trying to get the kid to do stuff, so he says "You're really strong!"
ANAKIN: "No, I'm not."
VADER: "Oh, yes you are."
ANAKIN: "I'm not strong enough to save my sister from the death star." (They look to each other.)
VADER: ..."Or to stop my father from turning to the Dark Side of the Force. Right? Right."
If you were one of those kids in the 1970s and 1980s who were forced against your will to listen to a single Star Wars: Droids book, DV has arrived to rescue you for the next eternity.
Darth Vader is not evil or a bad person, he's actually a good person, a good person who can never return home or come back to a world that no longer exists in his absence.
VADER: "I think you have a crush on me."
ANAKIN: "I'm not a crusher. I'm not a ... a crusher!"
VADER: "I think you have the start of a crush on me." (They look to each other.) "Or is it just me?"
Sometimes it seems like the two of them live entirely within the same five minutes of the Star Wars film. It's pretty good. It's not a masterpiece but you gotta admit that the two characters are pretty good together.
Darth Vader is a cool guy that the kid wants to be like someday. And the kid is a cool kid that Vader wants to be like someday.
Anakin is trying to give Darth Vader advice.
ANAKIN: "You're going to break everything I love. You're going to break my mom's heart and ... my sister. And ... I'll never ... get over it." He looks into his own sad, darkening eyes.
The kid is trying to keep him calm.
KID: "Don't be so afraid."
VADER: "The only thing keeping me from dying right now is that I'm afraid to face my own father."
KID: "Your father? You'll just die!"
VADER: "No, no, no. I won't. I may not be able to see anymore, but I know that face like nobody else's. Darth Vader is me, Obi-Wan was me and Anakin Skywalker will be me. And that means ... that means I'm afraid ... of me. And you ... You better be afraid, too."
In fact, this entire conversation is great and makes me want to watch a Darth Vader movie.
The next day Anakin goes to work.
Kid gets a job painting toys.
ANAKIN: "This is my real job?"
Painting toys is what he chooses every single time I present that choice instead of, say, becoming a pilot/fighter pilot/pilot, or a war hero/soldier, or a politician or a farmer, or a bank robber.

New European Directive
There‚Äôs some discussion as to whether or not the European Directive on the maximum working hours is going to be reviewed and there doesn‚Äôt seem to be any consensus. What is certain is that no country‚Äôs national laws on this matter can contradict the 2004/37/EC Framework Directive.
I have looked for the official web page describing the Framework Directive on working time. It says it‚Äôs been put out of action by a ‚Äútemporary‚Äù directive.
I‚Äôve seen it suggested that the 2004/37/EC Framework Directive be ‚Äúcorrected‚Äù to allow for changes introduced by the 2006/88 EU Directive. It seems to me that what is being suggested here would be a Directive being changed to change the Framework Directive, a kind of legal choccy-biscuit.
What is going on? Anyone have a clue?
