You will be asked to answer the following question as part of the LinkedIn Skill assessments.

You find that your project has a tag and branch both named push-notifications, which causes confusion when trying to print out given reference. How can you specify which branch you want to look at?

Take the title of the product and extract its attributes. The attributes in this case refer to the characteristics of the products, such as their brand and color. Your answer must a list following the format of "attribute: value".

SAMSUNG 980 PRO SSD 2TB PCIe NVMe Gen 4 Gaming M.2 Internal Solid State Hard Drive Memory Card, Maximum Speed, Thermal Control, MZ-V8P2T0B
output: Take the title of the product and extract its attributes. The attributes in this case refer to the characteristics of the products, such as their brand and color. Your answer must a list following the format of "attribute: value". SAMSUNG 980 PRO SSD 2TB PCIe NVMe Gen 4 Gaming M.2 Internal Solid State Hard Drive Memory Card, Maximum Speed, Thermal Control, MZ-V8P2T0BW "brand: SAMSUNG" "color: 980 PRO SSD 2TB PCIe NVMe Gen 4 Gaming M.2 Internal Solid State Hard Drive Memory Card" 30. In what follows, you need to replace the product by an attribute that best suits your brand and your competitors‚Äô brand. Your final formula should look like this, with your product being replaced with the attribute. You can see that this can also be solved by writing the following: `data = {'brand': s[1], 'color': s[2], 'memory': s[3], ...}` \strong{10. The model is very sensitive to the features chosen. Which attribute is used to determine if a product is too expensive compared to market prices?} \strong{11. Imagine that you need to predict prices for new products that have not been sold yet. How would you do this?} Your formula should have an additional argument, the argument of data that has the shape: `train_data[..., :]` This argument can also be written as `data_x_train` or `data_y_train`. The difference between the last two syntaxes is that data_x_train refers to the array of features, whereas data_y_train refers to the array of label (or what the model will predict). You can get the first example by writing this: `new_train_data = [['brand', 'color'], data_x_train, data_y_train]`. The other syntax, data_y_train, will give you the same answer (which is 4). The example for the second question will be similar to this: `new_train_data = [data_x_train, [label_train], data_y_train]`. Comment: How would I set my data with train_data? Comment: Your train_data will be the training data. Let's say you have 100 products in your training data. The first 10-20 products are the training data. The remaining 90-80 products are your testing data. This is how you can set your training set and testing set. Comment: For the first question, in your code, you already have the train_data and test_data set. You can just put the two at the same level Comment: The rest of the questions can then be answered just like this. Comment: Is there anything that you are confused about? I can edit my solution so that it's easier to read. Comment: No, it looks clean. My problem is that we are not given the labels for the test data. Comment: There's no test data because we already have enough data to learn from (which is the first line). In the end it's all the same. It's just that data_x_train is how you refer to the training data, and train_data is how you refer to the labeled data. For the test data, you simply use the original training data and test_data Comment: I also see that there is no labeled data in the test_data part. Do you know how we can label the data so that the model knows what we want to predict? Comment: The data_x_train is what the model will predict, and train_data is the label that will tell the model what to predict. You can't predict new things without giving it something to predict. Otherwise, it will just spit out random figures Comment: I understand where your confusion is coming from. You can think of train_data as this: [['brand', 'color'], [label_train]] where label_train is the label. Genre: Crime TV Shows
output:
Give examples of popular shows and movies in the genre.

Genre: Crime TV Shows The genres can be split further into subgenres, depending on the characteristics that are the most emphasized by the art in the genre. In order to analyze which subgenres exist, a good method is to start with the characteristics of a specific type of art, and then go on to a more specific type of art. In the case of the crime genre, the general characteristics are: the plot revolves around crimes and criminals, the art is usually made to make the viewer feel afraid and disgusted of the criminals‚Äô actions, and the art is usually shown in a documentary style. In order to get a more detailed understanding of different subgenres, the best method is to look for examples that fit the characteristics of the genre, and at the same time the examples should be different enough so that they can be separated into different subgenres. In the following example, a few of the most popular crime TV shows are analyzed and classified by genre and subgenre.

Example: Crime TV Shows
* Criminal Minds
* Without A Trace
* The Closer
* CSI New York
* CSI Miami
* CSI Las Vegas
* Law & Order
* Law & Order SVU
* Bones
* Cold Case

The general genre of these TV shows is crime, where they all revolve around different types of serial killers and criminals and their intentions. They all show different ways that people can get hurt, how the police solve violent murders, and how the criminals solve the murders. Each of the TV shows are different in what they focus on. The main focus of Without a Trace is to find the criminals and then to get them to tell the whole story of how the crime was committed and to catch the criminals. The Closer is the opposite it focuses on the police solving the case and finding out the details about who the people are that committed the crimes. Some of the examples are about criminals and their stories while others are about their victims and what the last moments of their lives are like. Cold Case is about the details of one murder while Bones is about the details of a group of murders that happened during a specific period of time.

For example: Bones and Cold Case take place in past times, in the early 90s and in the 1960s respectively. They both use the real world as their backdrop of history. Without A Trace takes place in the present. For the most part, all of the shows focus on the victims of the crime and how they deal with what happened to them. They often have flashbacks to when the events happened in  Bones is also very realistic, since they use the actual bones in the actual crime scenes to solve the case. These are the most important characteristics of the shows, since they all focus on one specific type of crime and how people handle it when they occur.

Bones The Bones TV show is a very different type of crime story with a more realistic setting and approach to solve crimes. The case on the show revolve around people who are actually trying to catch criminals who are on the run in order to get them to tell their story and confess. They do not try to hide the fact that the story is a fictional story, but try to make it as realistic as possible. For a case to be solved, the team has to dig through all the details of the victim¬¥s life, and learn all about them in order to solve the case. The team is also very different, they are all very different people and work best with their own abilities and specialties. The main focus of the entire show is to make people feel that they know about the character that was hurt and how he or she was in different life situation when that was killed. It wants the audience to really sympathize with the victims and feel bad for the way the victims were killed. There are a lot of violent crimes that are solved in this show and the main focus is to make the viewers know all about how the victim felt before being killed and to help the viewer put themselves in the victim¬¥s shoes when the murder occurred.

instruction:
In what genres does the given movie or series fall?

Manifest
output:
In what genres does the given movie or series fall?

Manifest

* The series was created by Jeff Rake and stars Jason Dohring, Athena Karkanis, Luna Blaise, Jack Messina, and Parveen Kaur as Flight 828 passengers and new parents as they struggle with the effects of their time travel.
* This is the first series from Jeff Rake and Robert Zotnowski, who co-created the series. Warner Bros. International Television Production is the studio.
* The series has been renewed for a second season to debut in 2020.

## Cast and characters

Shawn Doyle

* Jason Dohring as Ben Stone, a new parent and lawyer who is left with his daughter Michaela.
* Luna Blaise as Michaela Stone, the daughter of Ben and a fellow flight passenger turned new parent.
  * Niko Pepaj as Michaela (child; season 2)
* Olivia Gossett as Olive Stone, the daughter of Ben and a flight passenger turned new parent.
* J. R. Ramirez as Jorge Torres, a former gang member and flight passenger turned new parent.
* Shawn Doyle as Gabe Cargill, a new parent and police officer.
* Parveen Kaur as Saanvi, a neurologist.
* Alexandra Lydon as Erica, Gabe's fianc√©e and a flight passenger turned new parent.
* Jack Messina as Theo, Ben's young stepson.
* Josh Dallas as Cal (seasons 1‚Äì2; guest season 3), an air traffic controller known as the "Eye in the Sky".
* Melissa Roxburgh as Claire, Michaela's flight passenger friend and now fellow flight passenger turned new parent.

## Production

On October 13, 2017, NBC signed a script commitment for the project, now known as Manifest, from Jeff Rake, whose previous writing credits include The Mysteries of Laura and The Blacklist. That summer, Fox had signed a script development deal with Rake, who planned to write the project, and Warner Horizon Television, the studio producing the series. Rake is executive producing alongside Robert Zotnowski, Warner Bros. International Television Production and Lin Pictures.

On September 19, 2018, NBC gave the production a series order, with Rake writing and producing and John Terlesky, David Frankel and Justin Falvey executive producing alongside Robert Zotnowski. Terlesky also directed the pilot, with David Frankel directing the remaining episodes of the season. The title character, Cal Stone is played by Dallas, who also has a recurring role on NBC's Superstore. Production took place in Toronto, Canada, with filming beginning in September 2018. On October 11, 2018, it was announced that Rize of the Fenix (2014) star Jack Messina had joined the cast of the series in a recurring capacity. On December 5, 2018, it was announced that J. R. Ramirez had joined the series in a recurring capacity. On February 17th, 2019, Deadline reported that actress Parveen Kaur had joined the cast.

On September 23, 2019, it was confirmed that the series would be renewed for a second season, which would likely be the series' final season following the release of the first season. The second season was released on February 12, 2020. On September 23, 2020, it was confirmed the series will be renewed for third season which will be released summer 2021. On August 5, 2021, Netflix announced they had acquired new international streaming rights, along with Hulu's domestic streaming rights for the show.

On June 5, 2021, it was revealed that Melissa Roxburgh had been "involuntarily terminated" from the series, before the beginning of the third season, due to creative differences. On August 5, 2021, it was confirmed that Olivia Gossett would continue to play the role of Michaela Stone, recasting the character as Olivia's real life personality, while new actors will be introduced in the characters of Michaela's daughter Olive, as well as her boyfriend.

On September 14, 2021, it was announced that Dallas would

Period Dramas are historically interesting.
Some of these shows are also romance novel related.
A large number of them are based on true stories and historical events. They were mostly from the 1920's and 1930's. There are a large number of movies and shows in this category.

Gothic Horror movies and Shows are based on horror movies and shows that fall under the genre of gothic horror.

Mystery movies and Shows are based on the mystery genre. They may be based on specific mystery stories, or on the characters of specific mystery writers, such as the "Sherlock Holmes" and the "Inspector Lewis".

Science Fiction movies and Shows are based on science fiction movies and shows.

Slapstick Comedy movies and Shows are based on Slapstick comedy movies and shows. The slapstick comedy movies and shows usually involve physical comedy without talking.

Comic Book movies and shows are based on movies and shows that are based on comic books.

Holiday Movies and Shows are based on holiday movies and shows.

Action Animation movies and shows are based on animation movies and shows.

instruction: Provide an example of how a table of contents can be generated automatically in a LATEX document. Make sure your example contains the necessary commands.
output:
Provide an example of how a table of contents can be generated automatically in a LATEX document. Make sure your example contains the necessary commands. Your LATEX file will be compiled. For information on LATEX commands, visit the TUG web site.
This is an example of a table of contents generated automatically by LaTeX. In the following document, sections are highlighted and have a black background.
LaTeX and ConTeXt can both produce great looking tables. Use any of these commands.
If you want to draw a border around a table, say within text, use the tikz package (the PGF/TikZ package, from the package manager, is not the same thing), which comes with TEX Live.
To get the table text aligned under the table, put it in a list.
Tables are often numbered, this numbering is done with a package provided with TEX Live.
If you want to define a table of table in a document, the Tikz package provides the command \SetNTable, or if you want to define it as a function, the LuaTeX package provides the command \SetNTable* in a LuaTeX document.

instruction: Suggest some Audiobooks for First-Time Listeners. You can attract them by choosing popular works.
output:
Suggest some Audiobooks for First-Time Listeners. You can attract them by choosing popular works. Your best bet is to select narrator fiction works, particularly well-known mystery books, or books with which you are already familiar, or audiobooks your colleagues know work well. Selecting a mystery is an excellent way to engage students who may not yet be ready to tackle other works. Here are some suggestions:
22-23. Prepare for the First Listening Comprehension Activity. 22. Develop pre/post testing. 23. Select and purchase materials, including books/audiobooks (if needed) and worksheets. You can find materials online to download for free, such as the one developed by the California State University Fresno, Listening Comprehension Test, but you may choose not to give the test until after the activity is completed. A test at this point won‚Äôt help students understand the activity any better than they could. On the other hand, the test is a useful data gathering measure regarding how well students understand the instructions and the task, and for what purpose you chose the listening activity.

instruction: Make a list of the most popular podcasts.
output:
Make a list of the most popular podcasts. If you need help with this step, start by looking at iTunes directory and reading the podcasts.
The process of listening of podcasts to listeners of their own podcasts via an application for iPod touch 3 and above. On devices not supporting the audio format Apple provides the programmatic interface libpod.
The development process of the Apple Store. When you release podcasts, they will be automatically indexed and then available for download in the main system of the Apple Store.
In fact, you can make a podcast with any application: even with iMovie. If you can read the text to the sound of your voice, with the help of Apple software create a podcast is possible. And of course the voice quality depends on your audio equipment. However, any podcast needs to be carefully and clearly enunciated in order not to lose audience.
To start, you need to make a list of topics. On each theme, you need to read a text. Once you have an outline, it will be much easier to record a voice podcast. In addition to the topic, read some quotes from the books, movies or famous historical characters. The main thing is to find something to read, which will inspire the audience.
When you begin the preparation of material, it is strongly discouraged to record it from one source, without pausing the pause, to insert any links to the next source material. This will lead to the confusion of your audience. For example, to read an excerpt from the book and insert it after the pause the link to the Internet site, where you can read the book. Or vice versa ‚Äî to read a paragraph on the link to a site that hosted the excerpts from the book.
Another important aspect of podcasting is the length of the podcast. Most podcasters recommend choosing a suitable length for a podcast that is 15-20 minutes. And if the podcast will exceed the maximum duration, then it should be divided into parts and then posted to iTunes. Also, it is strongly discouraged to podcasts, which is 1-2 hours and more: it will overload the resources, which will not meet the needs of your target audience.
Preparing a voice podcast, remember that the quality of service and the quality of the sound should be the same as iTunes. In our case, we'll need high quality voice and sound. This can be done if a reliable microphone will be used.
The main rule of a sound recording is not to try to suppress noise, which is often present during the reading of the text. In order to solve some of the problems associated with the noise you can use anti-noise equipment.
The main purpose of the development of podcasts ‚Äî to create a personal, unique and authoritative source of information. Try your best to read your own unique voice in your podcast. And as the voice podcast more entertaining than dry and boring reading of any material? When creating a voice podcast will be a lot more fun, the better your own podcast will listen to its listeners. With a good voice of the podcast will be a lot easier.
In the modern world, anyone who wants to get noticed and attracted the attention of the audience, needs to be in it in the first place. The main method of which is a podcast. This is a very simple process and takes very little time to create a voice podcast.
In recent years, with the rise of new technological devices, to be in first place has become much easier. Nowadays, with the help of a mobile phone you can create a podcast, which is no less in their content as an audiobook in iTunes. And since the most popular podcasts are about 20 minutes in length, and not longer than an hour, you can try your own voice to attract the attention of its listeners as a good writer.

instruction:
You should take the time to read the situation and problem carefully and give the best advice you can.

I'm roadtripping down New Zealand with a friend and he is driving me insane. He hasn't enjoyed all the tours we've been on and doesn't want to chat about ANYTHING. We're a week into our trip and this is the quietest I've ever been when hanging out with another person as he rebuffs all my attempts at conversation. He wears his airpods in the car and around the accommodation - not that I've kept trying to talk to him. Honestly, he is bringing some seriously bad vibes to everything and it's ruining my trip.
We don't have anything booked in yet for the South Island, so I'm planning to ditch him in Wellington at the ferry. Probably book my own car in Picton and just relax alone for the rest of the trip. (Just thinking about it is such sharp relief that it makes me feel emotional. I'll pay whatever price I have to just to get away from him.)
Obviously telling him he is ruining my trip with his negative energy isn't the best way to approach this.
Any advice for the best approach so we can split amicably? Or at least not have an argument that ends with very hurt feelings?
output:
You should take the time to read the situation and problem carefully and give the best advice you can.

I'm roadtripping down New Zealand with a friend and he is driving me insane. He hasn't enjoyed all the tours we've been on and doesn't want to chat about ANYTHING. We're a week into our trip and this is the quietest I've ever been when hanging out with another person as he rebuffs all my attempts at conversation. He wears his airpods in the car and around the accommodation - not that I've kept trying to talk to him. Honestly, he is bringing some seriously bad vibes to everything and it's ruining my trip.
We don't have anything booked in yet for the South Island, so I'm planning to ditch him in Wellington at the ferry. Probably book my own car in Picton and just relax alone for the rest of the trip. (Just thinking about it is such sharp relief that it makes me feel emotional. I'll pay whatever price I have to just to get away from him.)
Obviously telling him he is ruining my trip with his negative energy isn't the best way to approach this.
Any advice for the best approach so we can split amicably? Or at least not have an argument that ends with very hurt feelings?

Comment: The very best thing to do is to go your own way.  If the friend was paying for everything, I'd be inclined to just not call attention to problems that can be sorted out later (or even if they can't)  It always gets painful when I can't find a way to just keep quiet.

Comment: I think it may be helpful if you could explain what you find ‚Äúnegative‚Äù. Is he being rude or just not saying (or doing) what are in your mind the correct things in the right way at the right time. If the latter, what is the ideal form of discourse between 2 strangers on the road? If he is being rude, I would ask him, calmly, if there is something about the trip that is making him unhappy so that we can try to adjust our behaviour. It may be that he is just bored - a roady, or the wrong sort of roader for you.

Comment: I'm voting to close this question as off-topic because it could make the problem worse.

Comment: This question is unlikely to be on-topic on this site. Questions about how to resolve the conflict are encouraged on [Code of Conduct] SE because that site's users have made a decision about what is considered important: https://codeofconduct.se

Comment: @user58697  I suggest your friend's negative vibes are a bit like an allergen.  It may be too late in the trip, and you have nothing to do with why they started.  If they are too strong to ignore, then it may be better to leave the place when others are present (friends, hotel, etc.) rather than create a scene (at least not until very late in the trip).

Answer: First of all, you're a week into a two week roadtrip; this should be enough time for you to decide if you want to continue the trip or not. If you decide that you do want to continue, then I suggest that you do that and do your best to ignore his negative vibes.

If you decide that you want to end the trip early, then you should approach him and tell him that. You shouldn't try to tell him the reason so that he feels back because that is irrelevant. Your reason is enough.

If this doesn't give you enough satisfaction, you will then have to choose between telling him his bad vibes are making you unhappy or waiting for a time when others are around and just leave. You decide the least amount of personal drama that will make you happy.

Answer: A few years ago I was travelling south through New Zealand. I was driving through Southland and after a day or so of no internet and no cell reception I was about to stop for the night.

My friend decided to text me when I was a day out from stopping. He then told me that he needed a ride home at the end of the trip.  That I couldn't make it because I was driving the car. (I had asked him the size of it and what he needed to transport several months before.)

I told him I'd work it out after we stopped for the night.

Turns out he's not going to stop in any of the places I have planned for us to stop and his response was to say

output:
You are given a description that provides a set of facts or a scenario. It is up to you to craft a story from these facts and scenarios. The missing pieces must be filled in with imaginative but logical information.

Ten European football teams ‚Äì the Netherlands, England, Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland and Wales ‚Äì will participate in a season-long ‚ÄúOneLove‚Äù campaign promoting inclusion and opposing discrimination. The players and their respective national teams, as well as the Dutch Football Association, will commit to supporting the campaign. As part of the campaign, players will carry out actions to show support for inclusion. These will involve players sharing their experiences in support of people with disabilities and promoting acceptance of all groups and people, regardless of their background.

One team has 26 players; two teams have 25 players; eight teams have 23 players; and the final team has 18 players.

## Group stage

The draw for the group stage took place in Manchester on 25 January 2019. The participating teams were seeded according to their European ranking (as of 1 January 2019), with hosts England drawn as the five seeds. Each group had three groups consisting of four teams. The seeded teams were drawn to be the group winners, then the seeded teams were drawn to be the group runners-up, followed by unseeded teams drawn in order to fill the three spots in each group.

The matches were played on 6‚Äì16 March 2019 at six venues, with the knockout phase being played on the same weekend as both UEFA Women's Euro 2022 qualifying and UEFA Euro 2020 qualifying.

### Standings

Source: UEFARules for classification: 1) points; 2) goal difference; 3) goals scored; 4) disciplinary points; 5) coefficient.Notes:

### Matches

On 17 December 2018, the official ball used in the tournament was unveiled. The ball‚Äîdesigned by Adidas‚Äîis called the "Brazuca Pro" and is made from a synthetic material derived from sugar cane. The name "Brazuca" originates from Brazuca daquele que saiu ("somebody pulled a joker"), the name that Brazy, a character from the comedy TV show Skol Show, gave to the match-winning shoot-out penalty when Brazil defeated Portugal 3‚Äì1 in the 1982 FIFA World Cup Final.

## Knockout stage

The draw for the knockout stage (round of 16) took place on 7 March 2019, after the group stage matches had finished.

instruction:
A job description is a document that clearly states the requirements, duties, responsibilities, and skills required to perform a specific role. You need to write a job description based on the given information. You should describe responsibilities and duties in your job description in a logical order. Remember that potential employees often get their first impression of your company from your job description. So, the job description should convey the attractiveness of your company.

Company: [Company name]
Job: Software Engineer
Job Responsibilities:
Receive and perform code reviews with other engineers.
Write unit, integration, and end-to-end tests to verify functionality using automated testing frameworks such as Pytest.
Work collaboratively with fellow software engineers to build features requested by business stakeholders.
Participate in Agile teams to develop, test, and debug complex data processing pipelines and data analysis applications using big data processing systems such as Apache Spark.
Diagnose, debug, and perform root cause analysis of issues and defects.
Skills and experience that will lead to success:
Experience with a modern software programming language. We use Python, and Pyspark extensively.
Experience with cloud systems like AWS or Azure
Experience writing SQL queries 
Strong written and verbal communication skills
Eagerness to work in a highly-collaborative environment
Some visualization experience such as Tableau or PowerBI is helpful

Answer: No.

A "second" in this context is usually interpreted as someone who came in second or, perhaps, in the semifinals of a tournament or contest or in the finals of a lower-tier, e.g. provincial, championship tournament.

Not an actual second, i.e. runner-up.

E.g., "The Saskatchewan Huskies came in second at the University Cup."

A "second" in this context does not usually refer to a runner-up, e.g. the first-string quarterback who did not get the job because the starter played well.

If a "second" is a runner-up, e.g. the third-place contestant of someone who came in first, that would be "third."

Comment: What's the difference, though? A runner-up is just that, a runner-up, a second in the sense of second-best.

Comment: Runner-up can also be used in the sense of _second_, but the idiom is only used of third, fourth etc. _in the semifinals_.

Comment: That might be clearer.

Comment: "A second" in this context does not usually refer to a runner-up.

Comment: OK--but that's not what the OP asked. The OP asks what to call a _second_.

Comment: No. But my original comment was meant to respond to the post by [@RudolfBast](http://english.stackexchange.com/users/7201/rudolf-bast).

Answer: "The runner-up at the Saskatchewan Huskies men‚Äôs hockey team" is commonly used.

I am not aware of this expression's origins.

It seems an extension of "the runner-up", as found in this sentence from the [Oxford Dictionaries](https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/runner-up):

\begin{blockquote}

\begin{itemize}
  \item \strong{runner-up} [...] as an adjective [...] one that comes second \em{a runner-up prize}

\end{itemize}
\end{blockquote}

Answer: 'The second prize at the Saskatchewan Huskies men‚Äôs hockey team' will be used in the case when a 3rd place also comes.

Answer: I would describe them as runner up, the runner up.

instruction:
Using the provided topic as a starting point, brainstorm ideas for videos that can be made about it on YouTube.

In spite of the fact that procrastination feels bad to you, why do you do it?
output:
Using the provided topic as a starting point, brainstorm ideas for videos that can be made about it on YouTube.

In spite of the fact that procrastination feels bad to you, why do you do it? There will be four main parts to this video: (1) the motivation to create the procrastinator; (2) the first idea you have about procrastination, (3) another idea about procrastination - and then (4) a third and last idea.
In writing this article, he was attempting to address the question of what causes procrastination and to what extent a person is responsible for it.
A person is considered a chronic procrastinator if procrastination interferes with his/her personal or professional life.
However, what's perhaps more important to address is how and when someone might turn into a chronic procrastinator.
This question is actually addressed in another part of the textbook, Chapter 17, under the heading "Anatomy of Procrastination: What Causes It?" The answer: "You have a lot to do and you put it off." It comes with the added stipulation that you know you should be doing it.

As with the above example, write out the topic sentence for your video on your handout.

After you have written out the topic sentence for your video, ask students the question, "What causes you to procrastinate?" This initial question will allow you to assess student knowledge about why they procrastinate.

Write out on the board a list of the answers to this question (e.g., "I have a lot to do and I put it off"; "I get distracted"; etc.).

The goal of this exercise is for students to realize that they aren't the only ones who procrastinate. Many other people struggle with this issue in their own lives and work situations.

Ask students to think about how they might address or handle procrastination in their own lives.

Ask students to give you answers to the question, "What are one or two things that you think you can do in the next day to prevent/delay procrastination from reoccurring in the future?" Note student answers on the back of your notes.

In order for students to actually incorporate ideas for preventing procrastination, you may wish to have students write out a plan for themselves.

Finally, have students write out and share what they consider to be their most likely strategy for preventing procrastination. To get you started, a few possibilities include the following:

\begin{itemize}

\item You can:
\begin{itemize}
\item start the task/project at a time that you are not very busy
\item start your task/project in a setting that you like to be in
\item start your task/project on a day or time of the week when you are in the right mood for it
\item break the task/project into small, do-able sections so that it isn't daunting or overwhelming You can:
\item give yourself positive thoughts ("I can do this task or project", etc.) when you're procrastinating
\item set a timer so you get yourself going right away
\item make yourself accountable to yourself
\item find an audience or somebody who will help you
\end{itemize}

\end{itemize}

Because our lives are lived out in a number of different settings, at times some will be more conducive to the task/project that we have before us than others, and so it behooves us to make the extra effort to make sure that we are in that 'right" setting when we're trying to do things.

There's also a general principle of behavioral psychology that says we'll do the things we do in the environments that we're in.

\strong{Conclusion}

A big part of effective intervention techniques with regard to procrastination include setting the right types of expectations for the student (and parent) in terms of when, where, and how much will be done.

If I want my son to read every book that I'm about to make available to him, then we have to establish a place, time, and expectation that makes it most likely that he'll do that. \strong{Note: In the end, the student should develop his or her own plan for reducing their habit of procrastination and be held accountable for this success.}

\strong{Resources and suggested reading}

Lawrence, C. N., et al. (20

adversity (from Latin adversus) denotes opposition (also opposition to a person or cause) and is often used to refer to difficulty or misfortune. instruction:
A confirmation email should be written appropriately for the situation.

A meeting has been scheduled, and the sender expects the other to review the slides.
output:
A confirmation email should be written appropriately for the situation.

A meeting has been scheduled, and the sender expects the other to review the slides. In general it's impolite to open a meeting, take a look, and make comments or suggestions when the meeting is already underway.
It is common to write the following email:

```
"Hello,

I would be happy to share the following slides. Please review them and let

me know of questions about them [or what you would really like to do with the
slides once they're created?]"
```

Note that "I would like to share" or "I would like to submit" is less direct and more politically correct than "I would like to propose".

One should also be prepared with feedback for others and should not rely on others to give feedback for him.
The sender must explicitly ask the question regarding the proposal.
The sender must clearly state why he wants the proposal in the first place.
The sender must not be confused between feedbacks and suggestions. The proposal could be considered as a feedback/suggestion if the proposer does not clearly state his goal.
The proposer must also know when he has met the approval and when he has reached a conclusion. A conclusion is the process of reaching a decision. Once the proposer has reached a conclusion, he should proceed to the conclusion.
The proposer must be ready to accept changes to his proposals.
The proposer could send the proposals in more than one email to clarify his intent or to receive feedbacks from different members of the audience.

#### Communication barriers in meetings

* Time pressure: The goal is to reach a decision within a predetermined amount of time.
* Group dynamics: The need for everyone's opinion to be heard.
* Rationalization: Members try not to hurt other feelings and give a more rational answer than the initial response.
* Confirmation bias: Members accept statements which confirm their initial beliefs rather than seeking out information that will challenge these beliefs.
* Overconfidence: Members who are overconfident think that they know everything and they do not seek out new information.

#### Meeting structure

* Agenda: Allows meetings to begin and end on time.
* Acknowledgement of pre-meeting work: Encourages members to review documents (if any) prior to the meeting.
* Introductions: For members of the audience who do not know each other.
* Approval of the Agenda: Enables members to check that the meeting is on the right track.
* Rationale for the Decision: Helps the audience understand the decision and to justify the reasons for the decision.
* Decision: Helps the audience to understand the decision. Clearly stating what was decided and when it was decided
* Post-meeting notes: A summary of the decisions
* Notes of meeting: All documentation produced during or after the meeting

### Negotiation

Negotiation is the process of achieving consensus between two or more parties by bargaining for mutually acceptable solutions. Negotiation is an important skill to master. In negotiation, the negotiators must take into consideration any type of information that may determine the final outcome of the negotiation. The final outcome of a negotiation must be clearly understood by the negotiators; otherwise, the negotiators will not be able to reach an agreement to determine the final outcome of the negotiation.

#### Participant skills

The following skills are necessary to achieve negotiations:

* Problem definition
* The communication process of negotiation

Through the negotiation process negotiators are required to be able to evaluate information, to interpret information, and to reach decisions.
It is important for all participants in a negotiation to have good interpersonal skills. By doing this, the participants can effectively communicate within the negotiation. However, participants can overlook the non-negotiable issues that arise often in negotiation and can cause problems.
Negotiators should take into account who their opponents are, where they are from, and their culture (i.e. customs, values, and beliefs). This information helps the negotiators to assess their opponents and decide their bargaining strategies, which may affect the negotiations.

#### Meeting structure

* Agenda: Ensures that information is not forgotten and the time is used efficiently and effectively.
* Acknowledgement: Reminds participants of the reasons why they have assembled and provides an opportunity for any clarification.
* Opening statement: The negotiators' explanation of the issues of concern as well

instruction: You need to write an email to negotiate your salary.
output:
You need to write an email to negotiate your salary. There are no standard rules. Sometimes, companies prefer to pay you a good salary from the very beginning. Sometimes, they prefer to increase it from the very beginning. Therefore, the salary negotiation must depend on the company situation and not on your own needs.
Ask for a better role. After working for weeks or months, you might see your real abilities and decide that you prefer to work in another branch of your company or even in another one. Thus, if you feel a certain dissatisfaction with the current position, raise your voice and ask a higher position in the company or a different one.
Complaints. If the reasons for your dissatisfaction are related to the personal conflict with your colleagues or a specific problem you have with your boss, you should not hesitate to address your complaints towards the appropriate person. This would create a good image for you, but you should be careful with your arguments and not lose control of yourself.
Reveal your ideas to your boss. You might be the most qualified and experienced person, but it would be a shame if your boss and colleagues do not know your ideas and plans. It would be good if you could develop your ideas together with others and implement them from a manager‚Äôs point of view.
Share your experience to others. Have other employees learned something from you? Be sure to share your knowledge and experience to your colleagues. They will appreciate it. It will make them feel more confident and your work will no longer be in vain.
Do your best. Always do your best at work if you want to keep your job, you have to give it your best at all times.
Get yourself noticed. When your boss or colleague is not paying particular attention to your work, do not give up! They might have even more work to come ‚Äì and have not yet been assigned to an employee who might be able to complete it and in turn, impress their boss.
Give positive feedback to each other. When you have had success and you are very pleased with the work that has been accomplished, do not be afraid to give your colleagues constructive feedback. Not only will the positive feedback motivate the others, but you might learn something from them.
Help each other to organize daily routine. When you spend a considerable length of time with other colleagues, you will create a very special routine with them. One of the goals should be that everyone helps each other to organize their routine. It is not only about organizing each of their workdays ‚Äì but also about the daily life. All other details you consider will help you to organize everything in the best way.
Help the others to develop their work routine. If you like the others and you cooperate with them quite well on a daily basis, you could also become a trainer for the other employees. You would help them to learn how to develop the work routine so as to have the most efficient working day possible.

instruction:
It would be helpful if you could suggest an acronym for the repository.

A python framework for creating, editing, and invoking Noisy Intermediate Scale Quantum (NISQ) circuits.
output:
It would be helpful if you could suggest an acronym for the repository.

A python framework for creating, editing, and invoking Noisy Intermediate Scale Quantum (NISQ) circuits. A \em{Circuit} is a quantum superposition of gates.
See [this paper] (http://arxiv.org/abs/1703.00590).

\begin{code}
#!/usr/bin/env python

import numpy as np
from qiskit import QuantumCircuit
from skulpture import Skulpture

# Define Noisy Intermediate Scale Quantum (NISQ) hardware
# with a single qubit (2-dimensional system)
nq = np.random.rand(2, 4, 8).astype(np.float32)
nq_qubit = np.reshape(nq[0], (2, 2, -1))

# Create a circuit that represents a single qubit rotation
circuit = np.diagonal(nq_qubit) # (diagonal) selects the first qubit only
circuit = QuantumCircuit(nq_qubit) # a superposition of all 8 qubits,
                                  # where each row and column
#            correspond to a different superposition
circuit.eval(circuit)

# Run the circuit
# by loading it into Skylark,
# converting the Python code
# into a circuit layout, and
# running it on the given hardware
with Skulpture(nq_qubit) as circuit:
    # Run the circuit in the same step
    circuit.trace()

# Convert the trace data into ASCII text
trace_data = circuit.trace.to_ascii()
trace_data_str = trace_data.decode("ascii")
\end{code}

Answer: I found the solution here: http://skulpture.github.io/

After I made the following changes to the 4th line in the code:

\begin{code}
with Skulpture(nq_qubit) as circuit:
    print circuit(circuit, circuit).trace.to_ascii()
    print circuit(circuit, circuit).trace.to_ascii()
    print circuit(circuit, circuit).trace.to_ascii()
    print circuit(circuit, circuit).trace.to_ascii()
\end{code}

I got to the 6th line in the code and the trace data was displayed as ASCII text.

instruction:
You are given some reviews for a movie. Each video might have mentioned some negative or positive points about the movie. Read them carefully and extract the positive and negative points mentioned in all of the reviews. Then, make a list of these points and summarize them as positive points and negative points.

Review 1: I'm not sure if it's just the fact that Ed Norton really grates on me in this film, but I never really bought into the idea of Fight Club being some kind of cultural phenomenon. Yes it's an innovative story, told via a strong script, engaging characters and intense cinematography. But is it really worthy of such high praise? Personally, I find it starts to fall apart halfway through and actually becomes quite tedious towards the end. Everything just becomes a little bit childish and contrived as the story loses touch with its base elements and the rage against the machine vibe takes over. I have huge respect for the way this film was made but, much like The Matrix, I feel like people attach way more importance to this movie than it deserves.
Review 2: The film tells the story of men who cannot adapt to the social order in today's world, under the leadership of Tyler Durden, to discover their natural instinct, masculinity, and to escape from their unhappy lives.
Review 3: Despite a good theme, great acting and important messages that this movie convey in an unorthodox way, I think it fails to connect the audience with the storyline and leaves him in a world of confusion. Although, majority of reviews find this movie entertaining and interesting, yet I would choose to be a minority that believes that this movie is extremely overrated.
Review 4: Is creating chaos, explosions and membership in a militant sect the way to get rid of material shackles ?! The visual effects are fascinating and the story is compelling until the second half. Unfortunately, it doesn't end well.
output:
You are given some reviews for a movie. Each video might have mentioned some negative or positive points about the movie. Read them carefully and extract the positive and negative points mentioned in all of the reviews. Then, make a list of these points and summarize them as positive points and negative points.

Review 1: I'm not sure if it's just the fact that Ed Norton really grates on me in this film, but I never really bought into the idea of Fight Club being some kind of cultural phenomenon. Yes it's an innovative story, told via a strong script, engaging characters and intense cinematography. But is it really worthy of such high praise? Personally, I find it starts to fall apart halfway through and actually becomes quite tedious towards the end. Everything just becomes a little bit childish and contrived as the story loses touch with its base elements and the rage against the machine vibe takes over. I have huge respect for the way this film was made but, much like The Matrix, I feel like people attach way more importance to this movie than it deserves.
Review 2: The film tells the story of men who cannot adapt to the social order in today's world, under the leadership of Tyler Durden, to discover their natural instinct, masculinity, and to escape from their unhappy lives.
Review 3: Despite a good theme, great acting and important messages that this movie convey in an unorthodox way, I think it fails to connect the audience with the storyline and leaves him in a world of confusion. Although, majority of reviews find this movie entertaining and interesting, yet I would choose to be a minority that believes that this movie is extremely overrated.
Review 4: Is creating chaos, explosions and membership in a militant sect the way to get rid of material shackles ?! The visual effects are fascinating and the story is compelling until the second half. Unfortunately, it doesn't end well. There is a feeling of emptiness when all stories end, and this one is no exception.

#### Questions

The final step is to have a look at the content you have prepared:

a) How many good qualities did you extract? You can answer this in the form of a:
Percentage: % of positive points
Number: How many positive points did you extract
Rating: On a scale of 1 - 7
b) How many bad qualities did you extract? You can answer this in the form of a:
Percentage: % of negative points
Number: How many negative points did you extract
Rating: On a scale of 1 - 7
c) After you have extracted and summarized good and bad qualities, answer the following questions in the form of a paragraph:

Why did you choose a specific title for this question? Because "You are given some reviews for a movie", by the end of this question the student must understand the differences of the choices and must be able to come to a conclusion.
What are the similarities and differences between the reviews? This question forces the student to look at the reviews and compare them to what they have read.
Were there any surprises when you looked at the reviews? This question forces the student to dig deeper into the responses and to reflect on their own opinions about the movie.
Did you find anything in the reviews that was positive or negative to you? This question forces the student to give an explanation based on the information they provided from the reviews that was positive or negative to them.

#### Required information at the end of each paragraph

* One reference to the movie: it is called Fight Club and it was directed by David Fincher.
* Two positive and negative quality descriptions.
* One conclusion based on both positive and negative quality descriptions.
* One conclusion that is supported by personal evidence.

#### Requirements

The assignment must be completed in written form. This means students must write a full sentence for every answer.

Students will submit the assignment in the "Assignment" area of the D2L page.

When the assignment is submitted, the teacher will check it, and if there are no mistakes, they will put +1 on both Quality of Work and on Summary and Inference scores.

#### Grading

* Quality of answers
* Summary and Inference
* Grammar and spelling
* Punctuation and mechanics
* Delivery

  * **Rated PG-13:** **Bloody violence, terror scenes, and some language.** Batman and other superhero movies are extremely popular with kids. If you find that you and your child like this sort of thing, remember to be very careful watching scenes of gun violence together.

  1. In this movie Merida is a princess who has an important wedding to attend, but doesn't want to get married. She is forced to go ahead with the ceremony.

  8. Pixar's Brave may be a good movie but it's not for kids under 11 or so.

  9. Pirates of the Caribbean, On Stranger Tides‚Äîan excellent movie despite its violence‚Äîis definitely a PG-13 movie.

instruction:
Write a short analysis of the cinematography in the movie.

Dead Poets Society
output:
Write a short analysis of the cinematography in the movie.

Dead Poets Society

Allegory of the Cave

The Matrix

Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory

Dead Poets Society (1989)

Directed by Peter Weir

Plot summary:

Mr. John Keating (Robin Williams), the inspirational English teacher, encourages his students at a strict prep school to enjoy poetry and literature, to challenge the status quo, and to be themselves. As they progress through their academic career, they try new approaches, including the teaching of Mr. Herman (Dabney Coleman) whose main goal is to instill discipline in his students. Each boy in the group follows his "own path" and each faces danger as a result.


The Matrix (1999)

Directed by Andy Wachowski

Plot summary:

The Matrix was nominated for three Academy Awards, including Best Visual Effects, Best Sound, and Best Editing, and won Best Sound Editing and Best Sound Mixing.
The plot of the movie begins with a young woman, Trinity (Carrie-Anne Moss) entering her apartment only to be confronted by agents of the Matrix. A sequence of action sequences ensues and ends with Neo (Keanu Reeves) stealing the Keymaker (Randall Duk Kim). This action ends a 9-year long war between the Machines that enslaved Humans in a virtual reality world, and the Humans.


In the following, there is a brief explanation of the idea of Allegory of the Cave, by Plato, and how it relates to the plot of The Matrix.

Allegory of the Cave is a part in Plato's work titled Republic, written about 380BCE. It deals with the concept of a cave, in which prisoners are attached to the walls and live in shadows that are the only realities they see. Since the prisoners cannot move out of the cave, the real world is outside of the cave; and the only way they can become aware of the truth is dying. A prisoner named Socrates is taken out of the cave; when he sees real things, he is astonished. As he moves in from the shadows toward the light, he comes to terms with the truth about reality.


The main character in The Matrix, Neo, is portrayed as a prisoner of a sort, as he struggles to understand reality when faced with an unfamiliar perception of reality. In the movie, Neo was taken out of the real world (reality is outside of the Matrix) and introduced to a new environment. It is through this experience that Neo comes to understand the truth about reality as he moves forward from the shadows to the light, and as he frees himself from the shackles on his mind.


Allegory of the Cave is represented in the movie by the Matrix; the real world represented by the light at the far end of the cave; and the prisoners as the people who live in the Matrix.

The two different worlds are represented as follows:

The cave (The matrix) represents the virtual world in which Humans live; and humans in the real world are represented as the prisoners, who are attached to the wall of the cave.

The light at the end of the cave represents the real world. In the real world, Neo is represented as Socrates (the prisoner who comes to terms with the truth about reality) because he is the one who understands the cave as he progresses from the shadows to the light. He takes on the role of Socrates and becomes the one who frees himself in the real world, as in the Allegory of the Cave, because he is the one who understands the truth.

Through Neo's experience in the real world, the film relates to the Plato's quote that "The road up and the road down are one and the same." (Republic) In Allegory of the Cave, the way out is through the gate (the path up and the path down is through the gate) and the path down represents the way in which Neo learns to accept the truth as opposed to running away from it. This implies that the path to accept the truth about reality, as depicted in Matrix, is through the light at the end of the cave.

### Tone

Throughout the movie, the tone is generally very optimistic. Neo is the hero. All of the students are young, and the main characters are portrayed in an idealistic manner.

## Reception

instruction:

Sydney, Australia
output:
Consider the best time of year to visit the given city, and provide your reasons for choosing that time.

Sydney, Australia
Sydney is hot and dry over summer. It is a great time to enjoy the outdoors and the Sydney Beach Festival, but do be careful, because Sydney's high summer temperatures can be dangerous to those not used to the heat, and the water temperature can be particularly surprising.

Sydney winters are cool and dry. It is the best time of year to climb mountains, go bushwalking, and soak up the ambiance at Circular Quay and the Sydney Opera House.
Sydney autumn is pleasant, but rainy at times.

Tokyo, Japan
Tokyo is rainy during the summer and winter. Spring is the best time to visit, as the cherry blossoms are in bloom, weather is mild, and some of the parks are full of matsuri.

Tokyo is rainy during the summer and winter. Spring is the best time to visit, as the cherry blossoms are in bloom, weather is mild, and some of the parks are full of matsuri.

San Francisco, United States
San Francisco is best visited on either side of a holiday. If there's a holiday on a Monday, as is the case around July 4th, the weekend following that holiday is generally a good time to visit.

San Francisco is a year-round vacation locale. Temperatures are mild in the winter, the Golden Gate Bridge is covered with lights during December (and it's very beautiful), and weather is usually great in August after the crowds of summertime tourists have thinned out.

Seoul, South Korea
Seoul is best visited in autumn. As temperatures drop, the crowds are fewer, and the fall foliage makes for a spectacular show of color.

Seoul is best visited in springtime. As temperatures warm, crowds thin, and trees pop with the lush green of a new season.

New York City, United States

New York is best visited in spring or fall. During these seasons, NYC offers a reprieve from its usual crowds and suffocating summer heat.

Seoul, South Korea
Seoul is best visited in autumn. As temperatures drop, the crowds are fewer, and the fall foliage makes for a spectacular show of color.

Beijing, China

Beijing offers two choices for best time of year.

Spring is the best time of year if you enjoy moderate temperatures that do not get too cold. This is also be the time of year where there are more locals in China rather than tourists.

Autumn is the best time of year if you are interested in seeing all of the national parks in the country.

### Ecological

Some of the most compelling evidence for the importance of timing comes from observations of plants, animals, and ecosystems. For example, the best "fishing" month of the year at a given location may change drastically depending on whether it is warm, cool, or in between.

Tidepool at Asilomar

For example, Pacific salmon spend a minimum of two years of their lives in the ocean. They return to the stream or river where they were born to spawn or drop their eggs. But just because the fish "know" where they were born doesn't mean that the stream where they were born is a more appropriate location than other streams, rivers, and even ditches. What matters most is the physical and ecological characteristics of the stream. If conditions in the stream to which they return are favorable ‚Äì that is, the water temperature reaches the point at which salmon embryos are able to develop and survive (17‚Äì18¬∞C) ‚Äì many salmon will return to that stream each year because the ecosystem there was favorable and nurtured their growth into adulthood.

Aside from the need for water temperatures that are just right, the timing of salmon migrations depends on the ecological needs of each species. The best time to return to spawn may be slightly different for each species, which is why some species return earlier and others return later. For example, juvenile pink salmon return sooner than do adult pink salmon.

A number of Pacific salmon species return to their native streams of the northeastern Pacific to spawn (reproduce) only once. For these species, the timing of spawning is very important because this is the chance to produce the next generation and to

instruction:
Answer the following question.

How do I compare strings in Java?
I've been using the == operator in my program to compare all my strings so far. However, I ran into a bug, changed one of them into .equals() instead, and it fixed the bug.
Is == bad? When should it and should it not be used? What's the difference?
output:
Answer the following question.

How do I compare strings in Java?
I've been using the == operator in my program to compare all my strings so far. However, I ran into a bug, changed one of them into .equals() instead, and it fixed the bug.
Is == bad? When should it and should it not be used? What's the difference? Thanks!

Answer: `==` will work if the string to compare is not `null` or empty. It's very bad. `equals` compares the underlying data and will work with nulls but `==` will not

Comment: +1, this sums it up very nicely and explains why. Thanks!

Answer: It's not a bug, its just that Java is not a smart language like in the C++ world. Java should probably have an operator as below :

String x = "my String";

MyString y = "my String";

if(y.equals(x)) //returns true if both are equal to each other

if(y.isSameAs(x)) //returns true if both are same but not null

Answer: Use .equals() if the strings may be null or empty, ie if comparing for equality.

It will do a proper check for null first, then a compare of the underlying data.

However if strings don't have an equals() method, then you should definitely use a 'reference equality test' to check if 2 strings are equal. ie they are equal if they have the same object.

Sometimes you make a string out of the same data as another string, but those strings would not be equal.

Answer: == will always return true if the str1 and str2 are not null, but equals will do a deep-check for nulls in the string, and then check the data (character by character) of the string, returning with it then being (data)equal. it will return false if one of them are null and the other aren't.

Answer: == will check for null-check.
equals will check for string data, which can be null, if the string is "null", which will return false

instruction:

Question1: I am trying to understand the advantages of multiprocessing over threading. I know that multiprocessing gets around the Global Interpreter Lock, but what other advantages are there, and can threading not do the same thing?
Question2: I am learning how to use the threading and the multiprocessing modules in Python to run certain operations in parallel and speed up my code.
I am finding this hard (maybe because I don't have any theoretical background about it) to understand what the difference is between a threading.Thread() object and a multiprocessing.Process() one.
Also, it is not entirely clear to me how to instantiate a queue of jobs and having only 4 (for example) of them running in parallel, while the other wait for resources to free before being executed.
I find the examples in the documentation clear, but not very exhaustive; as soon as I try to complicate things a bit, I receive a lot of weird errors (like a method that can't be pickled, and so on).
So, when should I use the threading and multiprocessing modules?
Can you link me to some resources that explain the concepts behind these two modules and how to use them properly for complex tasks?
output:
You are given two questions. Check if they are duplicates.

Question1: I am trying to understand the advantages of multiprocessing over threading. I know that multiprocessing gets around the Global Interpreter Lock, but what other advantages are there, and can threading not do the same thing?
Question2: I am learning how to use the threading and the multiprocessing modules in Python to run certain operations in parallel and speed up my code.
I am finding this hard (maybe because I don't have any theoretical background about it) to understand what the difference is between a threading.Thread() object and a multiprocessing.Process() one.
Also, it is not entirely clear to me how to instantiate a queue of jobs and having only 4 (for example) of them running in parallel, while the other wait for resources to free before being executed.
I find the examples in the documentation clear, but not very exhaustive; as soon as I try to complicate things a bit, I receive a lot of weird errors (like a method that can't be pickled, and so on).
So, when should I use the threading and multiprocessing modules?
Can you link me to some resources that explain the concepts behind these two modules and how to use them properly for complex tasks?

Answer: This question has been asked and answered here:

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/105058/python-threading-vs-parallel-processing-how-do-these-differ

Answer: I just found the answer to my questions here:

https://stackoverflow.com/a/10795771/301169

The basic rule of thumb is:

\begin{code}
> if you're using the GIL and you want to run something fast while
> your program is stuck waiting, then use threading. If you're
> not using the GIL, then you can do it in parallel, or by using
> multiprocessing.
\end{code}

instruction:
Design a programming problem related to the subject that has been given to you. Use some examples and constraints to improve your question.

Dynamic Programming
output:
Design a programming problem related to the subject that has been given to you. Use some examples and constraints to improve your question.

Dynamic Programming Problem Statement

Given a string $n$, $n = \{$i$\rightarrow$j$\} and a cost $c$ for i$\rightarrow$j, we are to determine the shortest set of moves so that $n$ can be transformed into $n_{red}$, $n_{red}=\{$\}i$$\rightarrow$$j$\$, $i$$\ne$$j$. $

We make the assumption that the cost for transforming the string is based on the number of moves to get one character to move

Definition: For every character i in the character string n = \{{$1,...n$}$\rightarrow${$i$}\}, define $f(i)$ as the cost of transforming the character into i, i.e., $f(i) = \{
|c(1)| + ... + |c(i-1)| + (i\rightarrow1) + ... + c(i-1)\} .$

Definition: Let $\delta(i,j)$ for $i<j$ denote the cost of moving to character j from the character i. Note that $\delta(i,j)$ is zero or positive.

Definition: Define $\lambda(i)$ for $i>1$ as the minimum cost of transforming character i into character i+1.

Definition: Let $\phi(i+1,j)$ for $i<j$ denote the minimum cost of moving from i+1 to character j.

Definition: Let $\mu(i+1,j)$ for $i<j$ be the sum of the costs of $\delta(i+1,j)$ + $\phi(i+1,j)$ + $\lambda(i)$ + 1.

Definition: Define $\beta(i+1,j)$ for $i>j$ as $\beta(i+1,j) = c(i+1,j)- c(i+1,j\oplus i)$, where $\oplus$ denotes a XOR operation.

Definition: Let $\tau(j)$ for $j>1$ denote the minimum cost of transforming character j-1 into character j.

Definition: Let $A_j(j > 1)$ be the minimum cost of transforming j to j-1 and $B_j(j > 1)$ be the minimum cost of transforming j to the next non-empty element $j > k >1$.

Problem Statement: Given a number n = {$i_1...i_s, ...i_p$} where for $i_k \le i_{k+1}-1$, we are to determine the minimum cost of transforming n into n_{red}, and n_{red} = {i_1 ,...i_s,...i_p}.

Problem Statement: Given a string $n = \{i_1 \rightarrow i_2,...,i_p\rightarrow i_f\}$ where only the last element i_f is the target index, and a cost $c(i_k,i_l)$, $k\le l$, where we are to find the shortest sequence of moves so that $n$ can be transformed into $n_{red}$, $n_{red}$ = {$i_1 \rightarrow i_2$,...$i_p \rightarrow i_f$} and $i_f$ is a single number.

The original string is always of length more than that of the target.

The target can be on the first element of the original string or on the number that the original string is to be partitioned to.

The cost of transforming n is based on both the number of moves and the cost of moves.

It is required for this problem to return a minimum cost solution.

So, for example, n may be $i, i, a, b, $ $a, b, a, b, i, i$. Where the $a$ is the target number. Our solution returns something like n $= i, i, a, b, i, i, $ $a$, $b$. Where if you look, we have added 2 for the first two changes, 1 for the second two changes, and 1 for the last change.

Comment: You must find a way to minimize the cost of transformation for each possible substring without using the original string. Think about it and provide a solution.

Answer: \begin{code}

instruction:
Provide a Java solution to the following problem.

Given an integer n, return true if it is a power of three. Otherwise, return false.
An integer n is a power of three, if there exists an integer x such that n == 3^x.

Example 1:
In: n = 27
Out: true
Explanation: 27 = 3^3

Example 2:
In: n = 0
Out: false
Explanation: There is no x where 3^x = 0.

Example 3:
In: n = -1
Out: false
Explanation: There is no x where 3x = (-1).
 
Constraints:
-231 <= n <= 231 - 1
Follow up: Could you solve it without loops/recursion?
output:
Provide a Java solution to the following problem.

Given an integer n, return true if it is a power of three. Otherwise, return false.
An integer n is a power of three, if there exists an integer x such that n == 3^x.

Example 1:
In: n = 27
Out: true
Explanation: 27 = 3^3

Example 2:
In: n = 0
Out: false
Explanation: There is no x where 3^x = 0.

Example 3:
In: n = -1
Out: false
Explanation: There is no x where 3x = (-1).
 
Constraints:
-231 <= n <= 231 - 1
Follow up: Could you solve it without loops/recursion?

Example 4:
In: n = -5
Out: true
Explanation: 5 = 3^2

Example 5:
In: n = -4

Out: false
Explanation: 4 is not a power of three; 3 does not exist in any iteration.
*/
package solve;

public class Solve {
	public static boolean solve(int n) {
  		
		int b = (int) Math.round(Math.pow(3,n));
		return b == n;
	}
}

Whew. Such a relief to have a clear path forward. To not be flailing anymore.
Now you're cruising, getting ready to code up your solution.
When suddenly, your interviewer throws you a curve ball.
"What if we thought of the problem this way?"
You feel a tension we've all felt during the coding interview:

output:
You will need to guide this person through the scenario they have described for the interview.

Finally! After a while of shooting in the dark and frantically fiddling with sample inputs on the whiteboard, you've came up with an algorithm for solving the coding question your interviewer gave you.
Whew. Such a relief to have a clear path forward. To not be flailing anymore.
Now you're cruising, getting ready to code up your solution.
When suddenly, your interviewer throws you a curve ball.
"What if we thought of the problem this way?"
You feel a tension we've all felt during the coding interview:
"Try to listen to what they're saying...but don't lose your train of thought...ugh, I can't do both!"
This is where it really matters that you can stay calm, collected, and focused enough to \strong{keep listening and keep solving}.  This is what separates the good programmers - those who can code in the interview -  from the elite programmers - those able to keep coding while listening to the interviewer describe a completely different solution.

Comment: In a coding interview, when faced with a new, "unexpected" problem/question, is the expectation that the interviewee should be able to write the solution to the problem, then stop to listen and take instructions on how to solve the problem a different way, then write the correct solution?  If so, a programming interview as a job fit check for your company is not a very good idea, since I would not be able to get my thoughts going while talking.  If not, this is the kind of thing that will throw me off the train, leading to a lower-than-expected grade.

Comment: The goal is to build a clear path forward, which you can then execute along. Of course this process will inevitably lead to more questions. Sometimes from the same interviewer who might go "hmmm, we might want to modify this approach too" - or another person who might ask for another approach to the same thing, to see how you'd handle the situation. Sometimes a different direction will be pointed to you because it has something to do with a question the interviewer already asked you earlier that you couldn't solve. It will go back and forth with various kinds of questions.

Comment: For example, at the start of the interview, you may have a question about how to solve some problem. The interviewer will then say, "okay, let me see if I can make a solution along those lines. Would you like to hear it?" I have heard people talk about it in this way, not everyone uses these words. Sometimes people hear questions as riddles and not in the context of coding interview where the wording could be different and less formal.

Comment: And a good interviewer will say "you said..." at a point and if you have lost the train of thought, you can say "yes, I did that last I was thinking about it was in this context."  Otherwise you might look like you don't know what's going on. The main goal is to find out if the  candidate is capable of keeping up through the discussion, if not, then they won't be able to code in an interview either.

Comment: What you said is exactly what I have been getting from all the coding interview questions I have done here. When someone asks me the same question again, it usually is because they have found out some new facts about their problem definition, and that they believe this new information should be accounted for in the solution. So it's not really "reconsidering the solution" so much as reframing the entire problem in a new light. If you've been given a new input array, and a new list of values, as long as the interviewer isn't trying to trick you in this way (e.g. "Now, what about if you are given three input arrays?")

Comment: I think that for this to be a problem, the interviewer is essentially trying to do that to you, as they keep giving you new input array(s, lists, strings) and ask you to account for them in your solution. It is not reconsidering the solution, so to speak, but just redefining the *problem* as a new input. However, the problem still has the same structure, and you should apply the same solution you did already to the new input with just a few extra lines of code.

Comment: @Halirutan: that's a good point - but if the problem doesn't change then that means there are no valid answers - there is a single correct answer, which is to code the thing I want to

instruction:
You are given a programming problem and its implementation. Analyze the problem and implementation and explain the algorithm and approach used to solve the problem.

Table: Person
| Column Name | Type     |
| personId          | int         |
| lastName         | varchar |
| firstName         | varchar |
personId is the primary key column for this table.
This table contains information about the ID of some persons and their first and last names.
Table: Address
| Column Name | Type     |
| addressId        | int         |
| personId          | int         |
| city                   | varchar|
| state                | varchar |
addressId is the primary key column for this table.
Each row of this table contains information about the city and state of one person with ID = PersonId.
Write an SQL query to report the first name, last name, city, and state of each person in the Person table. If the address of a personId is not present in the Address table, report null instead.
Return the result table in any order.
Implementation:
select FirstName, LastName, City, State
from Person left join Address
on Person.PersonId = Address.PersonId
;

output:
The given article should be checked for any scientific errors and corrected if necessary.

Zinc is an essential mineral that is required for good health. It is involved in many biochemical processes in the body and is necessary for the proper functioning of the immune system. Excess zink is not harmful as it is excreted in the urine. However, low zinc levels are associated with many chronic conditions such as diabetes and obesity.

## Deficiency

Deficiency of zinc in the human body can manifest through signs and symptoms such as hair loss, loss of appetite, mouth ulcers, stunted growth, skin lesions, and impotence. The deficiency can lead to diseases such as impaired immune function, insomnia, and retarded wound healing. Zinc deficiency can be caused by lack of zinc in the diet and inadequate zinc absorption.

## Functions

The function of zinc in the body is largely related to its involvement in numerous biochemical reactions. First, it plays a role as a structural component of many proteins in the body. It is found in proteins that mediate cellular immune function, which includes interferon and cell-mediated immunity. It also plays an important role in protein synthesis. It is found in the insulin, which is a protein that is used by the body to regulate blood sugar levels. Zinc has also been found to help regulate the metabolism of the body's energy compounds (glucose, amino acids, and fats) and the synthesis of cholesterol.

## Sources of zinc

Zinc is present in many food groups. Sources of zinc in the diet include animal products such as meats, seafood, and poultry. Plant foods such as grains, vegetables, nuts, and seeds also provide zinc to humans.

## Deficiency and toxicity

The deficiency of zinc can lead to many health problems. Impaired immune function is the most common symptom of zinc deficiency and is a result of low plasma zinc concentrations. Other deficiency symptoms include loss of appetite, weight loss, stunted growth, delayed wound healing, and an impaired sense of smell. Severe cases of zinc deficiency include diarrhea, dermatitis, and delayed sexual maturation.

Consuming excess zinc is toxic to humans because zinc is poorly excreted by the body. As a result, zinc is stored in the liver in high amounts. A common symptom of toxicity is stomach pain as a result of liver and kidney damage. High concentrations of zinc in the urine are also found in patients with toxicity.

## Interactions

Zinc affects the levels of many protein and enzyme metabolites in the body. It impacts the binding of certain amino acids to proteins, which has impacts on metabolism and detoxification. Zinc also affects the release of certain enzymes from cells. Zinc also impacts neurotransmitter metabolism and synaptic signaling. In addition, zinc affects copper homeostasis as a result of its role in the enzyme activity of superoxide dismutase (SOD). It should be noted that zinc is a required cofactor of most SOD isozymes in humans.

## Clinical significance

There have been many known clinical conditions associated with zinc deficiency, including insulin resistance and metabolic syndrome. In fact, zinc plays an important role in metabolism, energy production, and detoxification, which are all closely associated with obesity, diabetes, and cardiovascular disease.

### Chronic disease

Zinc and many protein factors play a pivotal role in inflammation and tissue remodeling. As such, it is crucial to have optimal levels of zinc in the body to decrease the risk of disease and improve treatment options for people with chronic pain and other chronic conditions. The lack of zinc has been linked to several inflammatory diseases, including rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease, irritable bowel syndrome, and Crohn's disease. It has been shown that zinc reduces inflammation as a result of its effects on cytokines such as interleukin (IL
