Summarize the article you have been given in a brief manner.

Mathematics and art are related in a variety of ways. Mathematics has itself been described as an art motivated by beauty. Mathematics can be discerned in arts such as music, dance, painting, architecture, sculpture, and textiles. This article focuses, however, on mathematics in the visual arts.
Mathematics and art have a long historical relationship. Artists have used mathematics since the 4th century BC when the Greek sculptor Polykleitos wrote his Canon, prescribing proportions conjectured to have been based on the ratio 1:‚àö2 for the ideal male nude. Persistent popular claims have been made for the use of the golden ratio in ancient art and architecture, without reliable evidence. In the Italian Renaissance, Luca Pacioli wrote the influential treatise De divina proportione (1509), illustrated with woodcuts by Leonardo da Vinci, on the use of the golden ratio in art. Another Italian painter, Piero della Francesca, developed Euclid's ideas on perspective in treatises such as De Prospectiva Pingendi, and in his paintings. The engraver Albrecht D√ºrer made many references to mathematics in his work Melencolia I. In modern times, the graphic artist M. C. Escher made intensive use of tessellation and hyperbolic geometry, with the help of the mathematician H. S. M. Coxeter, while the De Stijl movement led by Theo van Doesburg and Piet Mondrian explicitly embraced geometrical forms. Mathematics has inspired textile arts such as quilting, knitting, cross-stitch, crochet, embroidery, weaving, Turkish and other carpet-making, as well as kilim. In Islamic art, symmetries are evident in forms as varied as Persian girih and Moroccan zellige tilework, Mughal jali pierced stone screens, and widespread muqarnas vaulting.
output:
Summarize the article you have been given in a brief manner.

Mathematics and art are related in a variety of ways. Mathematics has itself been described as an art motivated by beauty. Mathematics can be discerned in arts such as music, dance, painting, architecture, sculpture, and textiles. This article focuses, however, on mathematics in the visual arts.
Mathematics and art have a long historical relationship. Artists have used mathematics since the 4th century BC when the Greek sculptor Polykleitos wrote his Canon, prescribing proportions conjectured to have been based on the ratio 1:‚àö2 for the ideal male nude. Persistent popular claims have been made for the use of the golden ratio in ancient art and architecture, without reliable evidence. In the Italian Renaissance, Luca Pacioli wrote the influential treatise De divina proportione (1509), illustrated with woodcuts by Leonardo da Vinci, on the use of the golden ratio in art. Another Italian painter, Piero della Francesca, developed Euclid's ideas on perspective in treatises such as De Prospectiva Pingendi, and in his paintings. The engraver Albrecht D√ºrer made many references to mathematics in his work Melencolia I. In modern times, the graphic artist M. C. Escher made intensive use of tessellation and hyperbolic geometry, with the help of the mathematician H. S. M. Coxeter, while the De Stijl movement led by Theo van Doesburg and Piet Mondrian explicitly embraced geometrical forms. Mathematics has inspired textile arts such as quilting, knitting, cross-stitch, crochet, embroidery, weaving, Turkish and other carpet-making, as well as kilim. In Islamic art, symmetries are evident in forms as varied as Persian girih and Moroccan zellige tilework, Mughal jali pierced stone screens, and widespread muqarnas vaulting.

## Mathematics in ancient arts

### The Golden ratio

Further information: Golden ratio

The Golden ratio

The Golden ratio occurs frequently in nature and has aesthetic appeal. This has led to the notion that the relationship between the Golden Ratio and aesthetic values and beauty is more than coincidental.

One of the oldest references to the golden ratio occurs in the Greek writer Euclid of Alexandria, who in his Elements (book XIII, propositions 4-6), which contains his definitions of the golden ratio and of its reciprocal, writes:

And it (the line segment containing the points P and Q) is to the whole line AB as CP is to AB, inasmuch as PH/AC = CP/AB (for H is the mean proportional between P and C). Let now CP have a length equal to AB, and divide AB by the mean between CP and C. In this way the whole line [ACP] is to the semiperimeter of the triangle CAP as the length of the semiperimeter [ACP] is to that of the whole line AB.

‚Äî‚ÄâBook XIII, Propositions 4‚Äì6: The Golden Section, Euclid, Elements

The ancient Greek sculptor Polykleitos stated in his 4th-century BC Canon that the ideal proportions of the male human body are related mathematically to the Golden Ratio:

In proportionate measurements from the upper surface to the lower surface, the upper surface will be to the lower surface as the foot is to the height.

‚Äî‚ÄâPolykleitos, Canon, circa 400 BC

In the 7th century BC the Pythagoreans, among other things, sought to prove that the Golden Ratio was used in proportions of the human body:

So that the ratio of man to the measure of the one-and two-dimensional bodies of those animals that exist by nature may be equal to the square of a certain number that is taken in their natural proportions.

‚Äî‚ÄâPythagoras and Pythagoreans, (1) Aristotle (384‚Äì322 BC), in his Prior Analytics 55b, circa 325 BC translated by B. Jowett, quoted in J. R. R. Tolkien (1994). "Faerie". In Humphrey Carpenter (ed.). The Inklings: C. S. Lewis, J. R. R. Tolkien, Charles Williams (First ed.). London; Boston: George Allen & Unwin.

instruction:
Improve the article using your knowledge of the topic in order to make it more informative.

The "fair trade" movement, also known as the "trade justice" movement, promotes the use of labour, environmental and social standards for the production of commodities, particularly those exported from the Third and Second Worlds to the First World. Such ideas have also sparked a debate on whether trade itself should be codified as a human right.
output:
Improve the article using your knowledge of the topic in order to make it more informative.

The "fair trade" movement, also known as the "trade justice" movement, promotes the use of labour, environmental and social standards for the production of commodities, particularly those exported from the Third and Second Worlds to the First World. Such ideas have also sparked a debate on whether trade itself should be codified as a human right.

The fair trade movement was inspired by the 1960s counterculture, and was the result of a number of related movements, including environmentalism, human rights, and pacifism. In addition, fair trade is an effort to counter what fair-trade advocates call "free trade deals" or "free trade agreements". Free trade deals are agreements that are made between two or more countries to decrease or remove tariffs and taxes on certain goods that both countries are involved in producing. The goal is to increase consumer choice and protect the environment. However, these deals do not always apply to workers' rights and the environment, and usually do not affect the price of locally available goods.

## Fair trade movement (1960s - today)

Fair trade (which can also be known by other names, such as ethical trade) is a system for promoting sustainable economic development through trade in the production of crafts, agricultural products, other raw materials and consumer goods.
It is the practice of buying products from the third world and selling them domestically for a profit. In addition to the profit made by the third world country the profit made by the first world country is also considered fair trade.

The modern fair-trade movement was born in Germany in 1986 when a small group of activists (the Ivory Alliance) challenged the Deutscher Verband des Deutschen Ivory Handels (German Ivory Trading Association) to make fair trade a reality by developing rules and regulations which would protect elephants and the people who live with them. The Association quickly accepted this challenge and, together with a group of specialized NGOs (Nicholas Wolz), developed the World's first Fair Trade Ivory Rules, which have since been approved and adopted as the "International Ivory Protocol" by the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) in 1989.

The International Ivory Protocol required member nations to introduce new regulations prohibiting the trade of raw ivory except to those with special permission. Since 1989 the Ivory Protocol has effectively stopped the trade of raw ivory, which has led to the recovery of almost one-million elephants. By 2008 the number of Asian elephants had risen to 44,000 from the previous estimated 15,000 to 20,000.

### Early development of the fair trade movement

Despite this success, the World Fair Trade Organization, founded in 1989, began to doubt that fair-trade production was the most effective way to help the world's needy as consumer tastes began to change and environmental concerns began to dominate the social and political climate. Thus, WFTO launched the Alternative Fair Trade Alliance (AFTA) in 1993 to address these concerns in a manner that would benefit workers in the Global South and enhance the environment.

As a result, the first international fair trade organizations, which are now independent from WFTO, were formed. The Swiss Network of Fair Trade Organizations (SNV) focused its initial efforts on improving coffee farmers' economic well being and increasing productivity in the coffee industry. In 1998, the SNV created Equal Exchange, which specializes in supplying coffee, tea, chocolate, and other agricultural products to North American consumers. Equal Exchange works with over 60 producer groups in at least 20 developing countries.

Other fair-trade organizations focusing on tea include the Fair Trade Tea Association (FTTA). The FTTA provides training and support to tea estates in India, Sri Lanka, Nepal, and Kenya. The International Women's Coffee Alliance (IWCA) is another fair-trade organization which deals primarily with coffee but also works with people who produce sugar, tea, cocoa, and chocolate. IWCA emphasizes the importance of coffee cultivation within women's lives in Latin American where coffee cultivation is the predominate industry. By buying fair-trade coffee, consumers help

instruction:
An evaluation of the article's quality should be carried out. In order to do so, you should review the quality of the writing and the explanation of the topic.

The 20th century saw a revolution in music listening as the radio gained popularity worldwide and new media and technologies were developed to record, edit and distribute music. Music performances became increasingly visual with the broadcast and recording of performances.
20th-century music brought new freedom and wide experimentation with new musical styles and forms that challenged the accepted rules of music of earlier periods. The invention of musical amplification and electronic instruments, especially the synthesizer, in the mid-20th century revolutionized classical and popular music, and accelerated the development of new forms of music.
output:
An evaluation of the article's quality should be carried out. In order to do so, you should review the quality of the writing and the explanation of the topic.

The 20th century saw a revolution in music listening as the radio gained popularity worldwide and new media and technologies were developed to record, edit and distribute music. Music performances became increasingly visual with the broadcast and recording of performances.
20th-century music brought new freedom and wide experimentation with new musical styles and forms that challenged the accepted rules of music of earlier periods. The invention of musical amplification and electronic instruments, especially the synthesizer, in the mid-20th century revolutionized classical and popular music, and accelerated the development of new forms of music. Such experiments with musical form had precedents in classical music, with Arnold Schoenberg's Pierrot Lunaire for instance having a different poem for each song. Jazz music, which originated from the traditional music of the African Americans in the beginning half of the 1900s, led to more complex rhythms that developed into a variety of styles from main jazz subgenres: Afro-Cuban jazz, swing (sometimes known as big band jazz) and jazz blues. Traditional western tonal music was dominant for most of the 20th century. Many new styles emerged, including minimalism, electro-acoustic music, and modernism, such as in the works of John Cage and Karlheinz Stockhausen.

## Popular music

Popular music is music that many enjoy as a form of entertainment and expression. It is performed by popular music artists and music bands, and typically sold at a physical (CD's, cassettes, vinyl records) or a digital level (downloading or streaming of the music). Popular music is also called Hit Music or Top 40 Music and often sells for a higher price than other music genres because it is more mainstream and more commercial. In some cases, popular or mainstream music could be used interchangeably, but the definition to determine which music falls in this genre is based on several general principles.

### Music genre

Main article: Music genre

Main article: Music style

* Music genre: a type of music that shares similar characteristics, sounds, and features
* Music style: the combination of music genres

### Music artist

Main article: Musician

* Music artist: a musician or band who produces and publishes music

### Music label

Main article: Record company

* Record company: an organization, company branch, a team of companies that produces and publishes music and is related to artists
  * Music record label: a branch or a subdivision of a record production company which creates, produces, and publishes recorded music, for profit or nonprofit
  * Record company: a music company that controls the rights to an artist's music and records
  * Independent record label: a record company that is autonomous and operates without oversight from major record labels or any multinational corporation
  * Indie record label: (Independent record label)
  * Music distribution: the means (usually companies) of releasing music commercially, often independently distributed music distribution
  * Specialty record label: a record label with a focus on one type of music, and generally a smaller, more personal operation
  * Independent music label: an independent record label
  * Record production company: organization responsible for the promotion and distribution of artists.

## Ragtime

Main article: Ragtime

Gershwin playing the piano

Ragtime is a musical theater style that blended European classical music traditions with syncopated African rhythms. Ragtime was extremely popular in the United States, Europe, and South America during the late 1890s, early 20th century and its popularity helped facilitate the rise of such popular jazz musicians as Scott Joplin, James R. Johnston, Jelly Roll Morton, and Joseph Lamb.

A rags performance time range from five to ten minutes in duration and it can be performed by piano, a quartet, a trio, or a duet. The music has a strong syncopation component which often makes the audience to tap their feet. Ragtime involves piano playing styles that can be difficult for even the most skilled pianists to perform. Ragtime is typically seen as a precursor to the jazz and classical music genres.

* Lists of years in music (containing 19th century, 20th century,

\item Can handle customer complaints, respond quickly to issues and handle the situation to their best advantage
\item Can handle criticism
\item Can write and edit their own work and can proofread their own work
\item Can work under their own timeline and deadlines.
\item Can work independently ‚Äì have the ability to learn and get used to doing everything for themselves
\item Can work in a team, be open to advice and other opinions
\item Have good judgement/common sense
\item Can take constructive criticism and use it to get better
\end{itemize}

\em{Source: Job requirements} (Webmasterworld.com. 2019. Webmasterworld.com)

\strong{So, based on this answer, how would you phrase the following?}
\begin{itemize}
\item \strong{What are the traits required for someone to be a Software Developer?}
\item \strong{What are the traits required for someone to be a Social Media Marketer?}

\item \strong{Which traits or skills are more important for someone to be a Social Media Marketer rather than a Software Developer?}
\end{itemize}

\strong{This may give you an idea on what to ask the interviewers in such scenarios.}

Comment: A *trait* is a "characteristic, property, or quality of a group, person or thing."

Comment: *Are they highly innovative?*   That is not a trait?

Comment: A traits is not a quality or property. It's a characteristic. That's different.

Comment: And, if a trait is a characteristic, how are they different?

Comment: Traits aren't *different attributes*.

Comment: @TrevorD But what exactly it is ?

Comment: @Sree A trait is a characteristic that is found in most/all individuals. That is one definition. If you want to use a strict one, it's any quality or property that can be used to distinguish or identify an entity. That is also a definition. "Characteristic", while usually defined in one way or the other, is not specifically defined as a subset of "trait".

Comment: *Traits are characteristic similarities across a group of diverse individuals.
If you were asking for a trait, I may say that "Jimmy" has a strong trait of being shy, yet another may say he is timid. "Shy/Timid", are characteristics, thus, it is not a trait. A trait is found in most/all individuals.*  I would say those are attributes.

Answer: This all depends on if this are the traits of a successful software developer or the traits of a successful social media marketing professional. This would then lead to a different result.

In the case of the software developer, I would call the "Social Media Marketer" a tool and if the software developer has the necessary traits he would be able to use the tool to great success.

In the case of social media marketing, one would also consider the software developer a tool, but in that case, the tool would be using the social network as an extension of its capabilities to provide value.

What are the traits required for someone to have skill with a tool?
What are the traits required for someone to provide value with that tool?
What are the traits required to provide value with a social network?
\end{blockquote}

I feel all would be similar, with possibly the last one having a different emphasis.

\begin{blockquote}

In the real world, electronic payments are made possible by clearing houses. They are companies that do the
  physical clearing of money in commercial banks by maintaining banks accounts. They are privately owned and
  operated and generally do this in exchange for a fee. Most of these clearing systems today are using a cryptocurrency technology developed by Nick Szabo called Bit Gold that was later refined into a digital currency called Bitcoin by Satoshi (Nakamoto) in 2008. All cryptocurrencies are built using these two technologies.
  These digital currencies allow transactions to occur without having to use a third party or middle man. This enables transactions to be made directly between two individuals, eliminating the need to pay transaction fees and sometimes even exchange fees. While such digital payment systems can exist without being directly involved in trading cryptocurrencies, they do not come bundled with cryptocurrencies.
\end{blockquote}

And chapter 9 covers:

\begin{blockquote}

While paying fees is necessary for using payment processing services directly, the payment processing service may use a third party to accomplish the physical settlement of money. In that case, the payment processors (i.e. electronic clearing houses) must take care that the fee charged by the service provider to the customer is less than or equal to the fee they paid to the entity which actually performs the
  physical settlement of money. This is to ensure that the fees the consumer pays into the clearing house are
  sufficient to cover their fees plus profit.
  The fee is a payment for the services provided by the clearing house. Because electronic clearing houses allow
  money to be moved and exchanged with much less effort than physically moving money, they represent
  significant cost savings to their users. And as one company, Clearing Corporation, explains their services:

  \strong{\em{‚ÄúIn many cases companies do not need to physically transmit funds, they simply rely on

instruction:
Create a daily itinerary based on the given information.

Our family is looking for a 9-day Morocco trip that has light to moderate activity levels.
output:
Create a daily itinerary based on the given information.

Our family is looking for a 9-day Morocco trip that has light to moderate activity levels. I know I want to see Fes and Marrakesh and have included them in my itinerary. Should I consider including a few more days there? I am looking for recommendations on what to see. Also what is the preferred way? To take airlines? And train? How much time can be covered by trains. Thanks for your help.

Answer: You seem to want to see both the Northern cities of (Marrakesh, Fes, Merzouga) and the Southern cities of (Casablanca, Essaouira, Agadir). If you wish to cover the Marrakech-Agadir area, then the best mode of travel is probably a train or a private taxi, as that area is very deserty.

If you wish to see the Northern cities, I'd suggest using a combination of trains and buses, as the city of Marrakesh (being in the north) is a perfect place to start your Moroccan experience, and Marrakesh, Casablanca and Agadir can be easily reached by train from Marrakech.

The 9 day itinerary proposed below is a general idea of how I'd suggest visiting the area in question, and would involve leaving the country once (after 9 days), but if it were me, I'd add another week or so (leave the country twice) to travel all the way to Essaouira and back again.

\begin{blockquote}

\begin{itemize}
  \item Go to Marrakesh. Spend your time in Marrakesh. After your time in Marrakesh, board the train to Casablanca. This train journey should take less than 6 hours. In Casablanca, check into a decent (but affordable) hotel, then spend the rest of your time in the city.
  \item Head on to Agadir (the southernmost city of northern Morocco) by taking a bus from Casablanca. It should take about 3 hours to get there. Spend a day or so in Agadir, then board a train to Essaouira. This train takes approx 3 hours from Agadir. Spend any remaining time in Agadir in Essaouira, a seaside town, 4-5 hours south of Agadir, a day trip from Essaouira is worthwhile. Stay in Essaouira for the rest of the time.
  \item Go to Marrakech, spend the rest of your time there.
  \item Depart Morocco heading for Algeria (Algiers or Tlemcen) by plane or train, as you prefer.

\end{itemize}
\end{blockquote}

If you wish to do a little bit less than this itinerary proposes, I'd suggest:

\begin{blockquote}

\begin{itemize}
  \item Go to Marrakech
  \item Spend your time in Marrakech.
  \item After your stay in Marrakech, spend about 1 day in Casablanca, then board a train to Essaouira. Travel to Essaouira by train should probably take less than 5 hours.
  \item Spend time in Essaouira.
  \item Spend the rest of the time in Marrakech.

\end{itemize}
\end{blockquote}

Comment: +1, I think it's a bit more complicated to go from Agadir to Essaouria, given the mountain range in between.

Comment: I would add "in Marrakech make a city tour and then return to Agadir."

Comment: @A.L. and dpeggian Thank you for your inputs. The itinerary that I have is: 1. Flight from London to Marrakeach  2. On day 2 have city tour in Marrakesh and on day 3 return to the UK.  Then I have a day gap so I thought I could travel on day 4 to Casablanca and from Casablanca to Tlemcen. I thought I could spend 2 days in Tlemcen . Then on day 7 return flight to UK or return flight from Algiers and spend 2 days in Essaouira.

instruction: Give students tips on how to keep their nerves under control during class presentations.
output: Give students tips on how to keep their nerves under control during class presentations. A simple guide on how to be confident during your presentation. In a small group, you can try various examples of different speeches to find the ones that work best for the group as a whole. This is done by simply speaking in a large group and letting the students provide the cues to pause, or to go slower or faster. It doesn't matter if you're doing a lecture or a presentation, having a set of notes is useful. It can help you get over your nervousness if you don't have to look at something with written words. This is a good way of getting you thinking about the points you are going to make. It is also an effective technique as it involves two different things at the same time. It can be very useful to rehearse a presentation a number of times. The more you rehearse, the more familiar you become with the material. This helps to remove some of the nervousness about delivering the presentation because it stops you being afraid of the content! Another useful way of overcoming your nerves is to rehearse the presentation in front of friends or family - who will give you supportive, encouraging feedback. Another good way to get over your nerves is to relax by doing something that will make you happy before you start giving the presentation. What's stopping you? Do it anyway! And if the presentation is too late in the day, go do something fun before then (but don't drink alcohol the night before as it's not going to help you at all!), which will then help you to relax a bit and get you into the right frame of mind before you deliver the presentation. Don't spend too much time on every detail of the presentation! Presentations should be short, sweet and to the subject. You will give a much better presentation if you have something to say of value to the audience than if you are reading from notes for hours. It's OK! If you do forget or are taken off track by a question during the presentation, try to do something with the question (even if you ask the questioner to wait until the end and then ask it of the group). It's a good idea to get to know someone in the audience ahead of time, so you can introduce them to everyone after you are done speaking. It's good to get feedback after a presentation to help improve future. Try to get a few questions from the audience after each one. Don't be afraid to make mistakes during a presentation. Sometimes, not knowing something can be just as positive as knowing something. It's a good idea to have some notes to carry during the presentation, but don't read them out. The notes will serve as a prompt if you forget what you were going to say, but it is much better to speak from memory than to read from a script. Don't forget that your audience will appreciate it if you are prepared ahead of time. Being prepared shows that you care about your presentation. Don't be afraid to get up and move around. It can help to keep you focused on what you are saying. It's a good idea to have a friend come with you to your presentation in case you get nervous. They can help you to keep on track and feel calmer if you have a friend with you. Don't speak the words in "parrot" fashion. Instead, try to speak in a more natural voice (but still with a bit of passion in it). It's OK to make mistakes! If you mess up, don't get too upset or afraid. Just keep going! Most of the worst speakers you have heard have only gone off on a tangent rather than speaking with a little lack of confidence (they just haven't kept going). If you get nervous, it's OK to laugh at yourself. That will stop you from becoming anxious and may even make the audience feel more comfortable, too. Keep doing it! If you get nervous, don't laugh at yourself, try to take it out on someone or something else. If you hit a rut in your presentation, don't stop and try to get back on track. It's OK If you get off your subject for a while. Try to get back on it as soon as possible and don't apologise. Be nice! If you think that the audience is not going to agree with everything you are saying, don't be so negative about the subject. Instead, try to be nice and find some things that the audience does agree with. Don't forget that you are talking to the audience, so make sure that you are talking to them as "individuals". People in the audience aren't stupid, even if they don't agree with you. And they won't hold it against you if you point out some of the

instruction: You can easily make your holidays more eco-friendly by following these simple steps:
output: You can easily make your holidays more eco-friendly by following these simple steps: Before you fly: ‚Ä¢	Get an eco label Airline, it means they have reduced their flying CO2 emissions compared to average airlines. ‚Ä¢	Think twice before you book flights, they will release a lot of emissions into the world's atmosphere, but if you really need to go, choose the airline that has the least emissions per passenger/flight (more in our flight calculator). When you arrive at your destination: ‚Ä¢	Stay in an eco accommodation, they will make sure they reduce energy and water consumption, and you will be contributing directly to the protection of the environment. ‚Ä¢	Eat local, the food is produced right around you, and not imported, a lot less emission and fuel is used. ‚Ä¢	Rent a bike, car or moped to make your way around. ‚Ä¢	If you do drive or take a train, use eco transportation like an hydrogen powered car, train or bus. When you leave the hotel: ‚Ä¢	Turn off the A/C. ‚Ä¢	Taking a cold shower for 1 minute is better for the environment than a long hot shower. ‚Ä¢	Close the curtains or blinds. If you open the curtains in your hotel or apartment, you will be letting in even more sun and emissions from vehicles outside.

instruction:
Answer the following literature question as accurately as possible based on your knowledge of literature for high school students.

What does the green light symbolize at the end of the book?
output:
Answer the following literature question as accurately as possible based on your knowledge of literature for high school students.

What does the green light symbolize at the end of the book?

Comment: "symbolize". Don't capitalize the beginning of a sentence or a title.

Answer: At the end of the book, the green light symbolizes the hope of renewal; renewal for Gatsby, and his hope of getting together with Daisy. Even though Jay has the opportunity to make his dreams come true, he never takes any action steps to pursue renewal for himself, or the possibility of a relationship with Daisy.

From the last paragraph of the book:

\begin{blockquote}

I had meant what I said about being able to forgive him, and I could. I was thinking of it all the time I was dressing, \strong{I hoped she would forgive me, too}! It seemed to me that I owed her some explanation, a plea in mitigation, the story of my life perhaps, though I couldn't give it now for anything \strong{since it was the green light, the old familiar green light, that \em{had} haunted me.
\end{blockquote}

\begin{itemize}
\item I hope she will forgive me, (as she deserves to be forgiven)
\item I owe her some explanation, I should plead in mitigation before her
\item I \em{need} to tell her my life story ("I should like to be of use to her")
\end{itemize}

\section{What is the meaning of the colour of the green light?}

The colour of the green light symbolizes the life of hope, dreams, and renewal Gatsby dreams of, and hope that the old dreams are within his reach. Gatsby is a man who doesn't "let" himself feel anything beyond hope and dreams, and the novel makes it clear that his hope is a "new green life" with Daisy. She is the hope of renewal he looks for, and in the end, it is in vain.

It is interesting that you note \em{old} dreams and \em{old} green light. This is significant in that it suggests that his hope of renewal in the past was not in vain, and therefore that Daisy's future \em{wasn't} something he had a hope in that was "old". The "old" is a reference to the past, and he didn't seek renewal with the past in his dreams.

\begin{blockquote}

I thought suddenly that I would like to come back one summer
  ‚Äì ten years later on, perhaps - and try to reconstruct everything.
  \strong{I wonder if he‚Äôll still be standing there.}
\end{blockquote}

The colour also symbolizes how in the end he doesn't take any steps in his renewal.

Comment: As you noted earlier, the quote *the old familiar green light* is actually a reference to her home back east where she's lived all her life; the same one he saw while waiting for her to come to his party so long ago. That doesn't fit with any meaning of *symbolizing* renewal. That's the same as *dreaming on*.

Comment: @DanRomik The quote says that "it is the green light", not *"it *symbolizes*" the light. I was under the impression that Gatsby does what he does for the hope that his dreams of his life with her might come true, and in the end they fail.

Comment: Sure, he does that, but that's not what he thinks of the green light. It's a thing, it's a color; it's not a symbol. You're misreading *The Great Gatsby* if that's what you're trying to say.

Comment: I can easily see how you could take the end quote (which comes after the green light has failed him)as *I had meant what I said about being able to forgive him, and I could. I was thinking of it all the time I was dressing, *I hoped she would forgive me, too*! It seemed to me that I owed her some explanation, a plea in mitigation, the story of my life perhaps, though I couldn't give it now for anything since it was the green light, the old familiar green light, that *had* haunted...

instruction: Develop a mental exercise that can help people manage their anxiety and explain how it works.
output:
Develop a mental exercise that can help people manage their anxiety and explain how it works. This could be a hypnosis exercise where the mind is mentally directed to feel relaxed and calm. The patient may be instructed to repeat a positive and calming statement such as ‚ÄúI am confident and confident.‚Äù The patient may even be instructed to repeat this affirmation when they start to get nervous about the test or appointment. A technique like this is often effective because the patient already knows how to do it. If the patient is not very confident in the technique, the patient may be given a hypnosis tape about how it works. If the patient does not do well with this method, there are always other methods that the patient may be advised by the therapist. Exhibit R For some people, it may be helpful to practice certain relaxation techniques before an appointment or test, to help them feel less anxious. Some of these techniques include: Deep breathing (breathing in and out slowly for 10-15 seconds), concentrated attention on a single point (such as the tip of the nose or the throat), or the application of pressure on a particular point on the hand (such as acupuncture). These techniques help to reduce anxiety and the physical effects of anxiety, to help promote the psychological relaxation. Other methods the patient may be advised to try are: Imagining an uplifting and relaxing scene, such as sitting on a beach watching waves, or a beautiful park in springtime. Imagining that tense feeling gradually easing from your body and fading out. 4

instruction: Give me an idea of the mental exercises you do to inspire yourself.
output:
Give me an idea of the mental exercises you do to inspire yourself. What works for you? What works for other people? Do you have a specific time/app/tool you use? Do you focus on making things? Do you listen to music?
I think about things.
Also about things.
And then things.
I do not have a process. My "process is me having stuff to think about. A lot of my thinking is influenced by the stuff that I've read, but most that influences me is things that I've been exposed to in real life...like talking to a real live human being, either in person of over the phone. Or reading something in real life.
I keep a notes app on my phone for the stuff that doesn't fit elsewhere - sketches or lists of what I need to do, or just random shit out of my head, or anything else. I can search it, find things, and figure out what I thought a week ago. I'll find a note, and I'll look back on it. If something doesn't make sense, I'll make a new note and ask myself why. That helps me figure shit out.
I use Sketchbook Pro for what little art I put into the world. I also use it for brainstorming, and I'll just throw stuff out of my head onto the screen. Anything else, I do by hand. I also have a couple other notebooks that have random sketches and notes in them. Sometimes I'll take a break from working and I'll go for a walk, and I'll think things about. Whatever it works.
The best way for me to get new ideas is to get lost in the shit that got me going in the first place, to see something that I thought of in the first place and figure out how it might apply to a whole different thing. Sometimes it's just to go somewhere and be like "oh shit, I need a new idea, what do I do" and just let my brain wander onto whatever else it thinks about.
I use a notes app on my phone for brainstorming, outlining, and taking notes of whatever I don't have time to sit down and type out. That's mostly the brain exercises. Other than that, I don't have a process. Shit that's in my brain wafts out into the ether and whatever comes back, I put that in the notes app and work with it from there.
I should also mention that I love writing in notebooks for that sort of thing. I've only gotten into digital sketching because of the convenience. But with notebooks, the brain is slower, but not distracted. No notifications to keep track of. If you want to take notes, you can't look elsewhere. You've got to face it.
You wanna know what the secret is to brainstorming? It's a simple thing, and it's not really all that new-age/out there. It's an idea. The idea that no idea is too silly or even that bad to throw away. The first time you came up with the idea of X, was it a crappy idea? Was it boring? Not very unique? Boring, right? Well, that was nothing but an obstacle. It wasn't a good idea, it was an old idea...but that doesn't matter. Don't you throw away an idea with a boring premise.
It's all about playing around with the idea. This thing, whatever it is, where do you see this taking place? What's in the background? Who are the characters? I have to admit something here. Something that I always seem to leave out when people talk about brainstorming and "not having an idea". You can have as many ideas as you want...there are no limits. But the idea that everyone keeps talking about is the "one" good idea. There's nothing wrong with that. It can happen, and it might even be all that you need to do to get started. But why? If your "premise"/idea is boring as hell. Why do you think that's the best idea? Because you came up with it? I'll put it out there: you're full of shit.
When I'm looking for "the one" to use, I do so, but I will often look at 3 or more or maybe just 5 that would allow me to use my skills with them. In this case, I was actually trying to make sure I had an idea to do something specific as a challenge with a coworker and we were tasked with writing these things. One was essentially a

instruction:
Write a to-do list based on the given information.

Daily tasks in the pharmacy
output:
Write a to-do list based on the given information.

Daily tasks in the pharmacy:
1. Take the drugs from the storeroom.
2. Take a prescription into a private office.
3. Look through the prescriptions made by the patient for the day.
4. Sign them.
5. Count how much of each drug they need.
6. Write the amount of drugs on the prescription.
7. Write the name of the drugs on the prescription.
8. Look through the information on the drugs and medications.
9. Give the prescription to the patient.
10. Give the prescription to the assistant pharmacist.
11. Sign the pharmacist book.
12. Help the doctor with the prescription for the day, and then correct if needed.
13. Control if the drugs are correctly written on the prescription.
14. Repeat steps 1-3.

Weekly tasks in the pharmacy:
1. Repeat steps 1-3.
2. Call a pharmacist to check the medication.
3. Organize if the prescription is correct.
4. Place the prescription on the counter.
5. Give the prescription to a pharmacy assistant.
6. Ask the doctor to correct a prescription if needed.
7. Give a corrected prescription to a patient.
8. Make sure that the doctor has written the correct medication.
9. Place the patient‚Äôs and doctor‚Äôs signatures in the appropriate places.
10. Check the number of packs if the prescription is correct.
11. Repeat steps 2-2.

instruction: Design a template table for keeping track of all subscriptions.
output:
Design a template table for keeping track of all subscriptions. This will keep your email marketing in check. Make sure you capture email addresses when someone subscribes. Send an email newsletter to every person in your list and ask them to forward to friends. Design template emails, inviting them to take part, with instructions on where they should go and how to contribute. Don t forget to include a place for readers to share feedback. 12
13 Step 2 How do I raise money? Get people to donate to the cause. Design email appeals specifically seeking donations. (Always make sure you are clear about which organization you are raising donations for.) Send appeals to friends and family. If you want to raise money from the public more widely, design appeals that invite participation, and include information on who and where to send a cheque. Step 3 What does the project need? Make a list of resources required for the project, and budget accordingly. Research prices of resources (materials, services, travel, accommodations, etc.). Get offers of help from friends and family. Use the list of resources for the project. Use emails and social media to coordinate and mobilize volunteers. 13
14 Step 4 How do I sell product? Figure out which businesses sell goods that can be turned into a product, and approach them with your idea. Develop a product prototype, and show it to businesses that make the same thing. You should do this research step first, as it will limit your choices for manufacturers. Once you have a list of manufacturers, ask each if you can create a sample, and offer one to each of them if they want it. They might pay for it or you might get it for free. It is important to contact each possible manufacturer and ask them about their interest and pricing. Make a business plan for making the product. Consider pricing, branding, and funding. Get prices from manufacturers, and keep an eye out for cheaper ones. If pricing with one company makes no sense, find out the next cheapest company to make it. Design a prototype, or at the least create a digital or physical mockup of how the product will look. Develop a business plan including the goals and costs of creating and marketing the product, and how to make a profit. Determine what you need to do in order to bring your idea to market. Figure out what kind of product you want to make, and who might make it. Create a prototype. Write a business plan. Bring to market. 14
15 5 How do I promote? Promote early and often, especially within your community where it will have the most effect. Don t wait until you think the product is ready to make its debut. Write about your project early in blogs and publications where your target audience reads, with the intention to draw in the media. Write about your project to create connections with the public, and keep you in the public eye. Promote on social media (Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube are a good start). In addition to using these platforms, design attractive messages and photos, and make them available as downloads. Design eye catching posters and flyers, to promote in the real world, and be prepared to hand them out. Create a viral campaign around your product/project. Keep an eye out for news stories about your product or project. When a positive one emerges, contact journalist. Ask them about any story, but especially those where your project is involved as an expert. Let them know about other people you can speak to who are interested and expert in your topic. Don t just rely on the media though, but have a promotions team to use social media to spread the word, and send out press releases. You may have to invest some money in promotion, but look at it as an investment. Think what it will be worth once news of your project reaches the public. You may also have to work a certain number of hours for free, helping out while making connections. But this is part of the deal, and there are plenty of rewards. (It s also worth noting this promotional and contact-building work gets you a whole lot further than hiring a big PR agency to do the exact same job.) 15
16 Step 6 How do I promote locally? Identify the organizations and leaders who influence your community. Be sure to target those who are interested in your project, and the people they influence. Write articles and press releases to newspapers and magazines of interest. Write letters, articles, and blog posts about your project, and why people should be interested in it or involved. Contact local political agencies to get your project on the agenda. Develop a local fundraising campaign. Host fundraising events in public places, and promote them in newspapers,

instruction: Plan an agenda for the daily standup meetings. Assign a time duration to each topic on the agenda.
output:
Plan an agenda for the daily standup meetings. Assign a time duration to each topic on the agenda. Assign a responsibility to each team member on each topic. Assign time slots for each team member to speak on each topic. Review the meeting agenda. Assign time slots for each team member to report on work that they did. Assign time slots for team members to provide feedback to each other. Require each team member to speak for 10 seconds, and if none of them are speaking you stop them. Require that if a team member stops speaking, that the person next to him speaks in his place. Provide rewards and punishments for not abiding by the rules of the standup meetings.
Sprint Review This meeting is attended by all stakeholders and project members that desire updates on the project. The purpose of this meeting is to provide information about progress and risks related to the project. It also allows all stakeholders to see the project status. Stakeholders should not need to attend other meetings. This meeting provides feedback on whether or not each team member is doing their job. Meeting Objectives This meeting is attended by those stakeholders that desire to get updates on the project and receive any information about risks or issues. The purpose of this is to allow those that need to know about the progress and risks of the project. Also, this meeting allows those stakeholders to see a visual representation of the state of the project. Stakeholders should not need to attend other meetings. This is a great opportunity to gather feedback and make corrective actions. Meeting Frequency This is a meeting that is scheduled per iteration. The frequency is once during every iteration. Each stakeholder decides whether or not to attend, based on the amount of information that they desire. The attendance of this meeting is optional. This means the stakeholder will only attend the meeting if they are interested in the topic, and they decide if they want to attend or not. These are open meetings, so any stakeholder can provide input or ask questions. Those that stakeholder deems as having the most knowledge are the ones that should be speaking for the most time. That is why the team members should be the primary presenters. The stakeholders can also attend the other meetings if they so choose. If they do, then they should have to speak at those meetings as well.
Sprint Retrospective This meeting is attended by the entire team and the project stakeholders that desire updates on the project and receive any information about risks or issues. The purpose of this is to allow those stakeholders that need to know about the progress and risks of the project to see a visual representation of the state of the project. Stakeholders should not need to attend other meetings. This meeting allows those that are participating in the retrospective to provide their feedback on how the team should function. Meeting Objectives The purpose of this meeting is to allow team members to determine processes and practices that will allow them to become more effective on the next iteration. To do this, they need to examine the processes and practices of the current iteration, and then recommend and implement the necessary process and practice changes that will enable them to be more productive and efficient on their next iteration. The team members can propose and try out new practices, but only those that they deemed successful, and those that get used should be written down as improvements that need to be documented and made permanent. If an improvement is proposed and not used on the next iteration, then it should be documented in the improvement file, and be reviewed with the team members to verify validity. Meeting Frequency This is a meeting that is scheduled per iteration. The frequency is once during every iteration. Only those team members that are interested in helping to make the team more proficient attend the meeting. The attendance of this meeting is optional. This means the stakeholder will only attend the meeting if they are interested in the topic, and they decide if they want to attend or not. These are open meetings, so any stakeholder can provide input or ask questions. Those that stakeholder deems as having the most knowledge are the ones that should be speaking for the most time. That is why the team members should be the primary presenters. The stakeholders can also attend the other meetings if they so choose. If they do, then they should have to speak at those meetings as well. The retrospective should always be focused on one topic. The team leader should set the retrospective topic before the start of the retrospective.
Agenda Review the current retrospective template, in order to understand the sequence of retrospective steps that are being followed. Write a template for the current iteration, and use the sequence

Kim says that these are the only two native "person" words for bears and she notes that they are "very close" to "people words". She says that it is highly uncertain whether the Japanese "person" words for any animal stem from a bear, but says that in the case of words for a bear, the animal word could have been borrowed from the Ainu or from the "Jomon culture". The two words in Kim's summary were in fact taken directly from Miyake and Kim 1978 pp. 153‚Äì154.

The first of these two examples, the verb hakkƒ´ and the noun hokkƒ´, have been adopted by people in general and are found in dictionaries and textbooks. In fact the "bear" sense of hokkƒ´ was found in a Japanese-English dictionary in England, but hokkƒ´ could be used to mean a person or creature from a bear family. However this dictionary definition is no longer cited in dictionaries and textbooks. Hokkƒ´ is also used by some people and is listed by Yamamoto in his dictionary as a word that has been "released" from being a bear word, for use as a general word (p. 966). But despite all this, hakkƒ´ and hokkƒ´ have remained true to the sense of "bear" that they had when they were first used by Ainu. In fact, in one dictionary, there is still a note that says that these two words can be "misused" and the dictionary offers some examples, e.g. "a great man, a hero" ([R] Ikumi shir≈ç). This dictionary suggests that these two words should only be used as the names or nicknames of people of "brave" or "big" character. This is still an unusual sense of these words for people who are not Ainu, and so they are not used for these qualities. For this reason, the words can be said to be restricted to their "original" sense, "bear". (For more, see [H3] below.)

## 2. Abe and his bear family

"The little bear's mother and father are looking for him" (from [15]).

One day a little boy went off to play and came to another boy who had a bear with him. This boy put the bear in the boy's bag and took the boy off to his house. The little boy was sad. "I want my bear" he said to Abe, who lived in that country. Abe said "I'd like my bear too". He got on his horse and galloped off to the boy who had the bear. When he reached the boy's house, he was crying and Abe asked what was wrong. The boy said "I want my own bear, why doesn't Abe let me have one?". Abe said: "Why don't you give up your bear and come with me". The little boy said "okay" and he gave up his bear. So Abe and the little boy got on his horse together and galloped off, and then at the same time, Abe and the little boy got on their horses and galloped off separately. The little boy and Abe met up and Abe said to the boy at the same time that the boy's mother and father had found him. Abe was so happy!

This story is recorded in [15] pp. 102‚Äì103 of Kim and Tanaka's translation of Miyake's Ainu Legends.

What about the Ainu words for bear? This story is an explanation of why bears and humans don't look alike. Why, in fact, do any bear words look like human words? instruction:
Describe how to prepare the given food in your own words. Note down the ingredients you will need and the steps you will take to prepare them.

Chewy Chocolate Chip Cookies
output:
Describe how to prepare the given food in your own words. Note down the ingredients you will need and the steps you will take to prepare them.

Chewy Chocolate Chip Cookies

Sugar   4 cups    Brown Sugar

Eggs   2 eggs

Chocolate   1 bar, milk or dark   1 lb, bit more if it's bittersweet

Butter	  2 sticks of butter, softened

Corn syrup	 1/4 cup corn syrup

Mini chocolate chips		2 cups

Preheat oven to 350 degrees. In a large bowl mix the sugar, eggs and chocolate together. In a medium bowl combine the flour, cocoa, baking soda and salt. Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix together gently. Dough should be sticky, but not too much. Using more flour to prevent stickiness, make a 1/2" thick disk. Bake these around 10 minutes. Cookies might be underdone as they tend to burn on the bottoms. Remove from oven. While the cookies are in the oven, melt your 1/4 cup corn syrup in a heat-proof bowl. Microwave on low for around five minutes or until syrup is liquefied. Cool briefly. Roll the dough in your hands into 1/2" balls, flatten just a bit, and press the balls into the corn syrup. Sprinkle them with mini chocolate chips and place the cookie in the refrigerator. The cookies will remain puffy, and when fully set, they will have a crunch to them. If you let them sit for an hour.

##### Cooks for Kids

* **Cheese Pizza**

  1. Cut your pizza dough into four even squares.
  2. On each square, roll a pizza sauce into the center.
  3. Layer four cheese of your choice onto each pizza.
  4. Place a pizza stone in the oven, and place the pizzas on the pizza stone.
  5. Turn the oven to 450 degrees. Check the pizzas every 15 minutes. Once the cheese begins to turn a golden color, remove the pizza stone and check the pizzas again. If your pizzas appear to have baked a little in this time, set the stone back in the oven and check again.
  6. Once the cheese starts to brown, remove the pizza stone and check the pizzas again. Once again, if your pizzas appear to have baked a little a little in this time, set the stone back in the oven and check again.
  7. When the cheese has turned golden brown, remove the pizza stone and let the pizza cool off in the oven.

Apricot Sauce

  1. Combine the water, sugar and juice in a non-stick fry pan.
  2. Stir until all the sugar was dissolved.
  3. Let it boil.
  4. Add the butter and stir.
  5. Let it cool off, and pour in the sauce in a glass jar.

* **Nanami's Sticky Rice Balls**

  1. Bring the water to a boil with the tapioca starch.
  2. Mix in the sweet potato flour.

  3. Let it boil again.
  4. Put the mixture in a rice cooker, and let it cook until it is half done.
  5. Stir it and let it cook for more half an hour.

Think of a motivational quote that you have read in a book. Try to keep it positive and sweet.
3. Give a smile
Smiling is always a sign of happiness. It‚Äôs a gesture that can tell people you‚Äôre not a bitter person. So keep showing a smile always!
4. Enjoy life
If you think that the worst thing that can happen to you is that you‚Äôll get sick or die, you‚Äôre lucky. Consider yourself as a winner if you can survive all your illnesses.
5. Accept who you are
You should have to love yourself no matter what. Love yourself so much that nobody ever have to hurt you again. So be yourself, be proud of yourself and stop hiding. Keep this in mind everyday.
6. Be Optimistic!
No matter what happen if you can always be an optimistic person, I believe you would become a better person. You can always see the bright side of life, no matter how bad your life is.
There will be always someone will tell you they don‚Äôt like you. It‚Äôs not something worth worrying about though. Let them continue their wrong path of life and just stay focused on what you want. You will be surprised, you‚Äôll gain many friends in the end.
Having the courage to say yes, is more important than having a good plan to say no. You don‚Äôt have a great idea, but decide to do it anyway.
Worries, problems, and challenges are part of everyone‚Äôs life. What matters the most is how you deal with it. Don‚Äôt let life beat you, be beat it!
If you ask people about you one day, what do you want them to say?
I‚Äôm the nicest person ever.
I‚Äôm the most beautiful person ever.
I‚Äôm the smartest person ever.
I‚Äôm the best person ever.
All those questions are similar. But you should know that you are the best and the nicest person ever. Love yourselves!
How to have a happy life?
Having a happy life means, having a successful mindset. Having a positive or optimistic mindset can help you to face all those difficulties. I‚Äôd like to share with you the quote from Steve Maraboli that has changed my life.
1. Happiness is never about how you look, so you can put all the makeup on or go to the gym for two hours, but you still won‚Äôt be happy. And it‚Äôs not about how much money you have or how many people who love you. Happiness for me has everything to do with your mindset and your heart. Your attitude towards life and what it has to throw at you. You can be happy if you choose to be and see the bright side of life.
2. If you love it, and it makes you happy. It‚Äôs the thing to do. If your passion becomes your profession, you‚Äôll be happier for the rest of your life. You will be living your dreams. And that‚Äôs what matters the most!
3. I don‚Äôt want to spend my days thinking about what could happen if I had been a different person. I‚Äôm here now and I believe it‚Äôs too early to think about the future. Whatever I try to do, I can always learn and improve. So just focus on being the best person you can be in the present time.
I have never really thought about what it means to be happy or what‚Äôs the right way to choose happiness, until I read that quote. It is true. Happiness doesn‚Äôt depend on what you do, how much money you have either if someone loves you or not. Happiness depends on how you feel at the moment. If you‚Äôre happy and positive, it‚Äôs means everything in your life at the present time. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm positive. I‚Äôm happy always. I‚Äôm just happy to be living.

instruction:
Give a brief description of the book that you are given.

Matilda
output:
Give a brief description of the book that you are given.

Matilda's class is put into a terrible mood by Miss Trunchbull, a headmistress with a penchant for breaking children's limbs and eating babies, and so the children get revenge by making Matilda into their own librarian.

Miss Trunchbull
A very tough headmistress with a very high mucus line (which is her mood line) and a nasty personality. She also enjoys eating kittens. Despite her tough demeanour, she can be seen crying very easily. The main target of her abuse is her class of children and this includes her favourite student, Bruce Bogtrotter so she often abuses him.
Humour and sarcasm also play a part in Miss Trunchbull's mood, and this shows in the way she talks and behaves throughout the book, often making fun of students such as Bruce, and even Matilda.

The Wormwoods
Matilda's parents. At first, they seem very kind and nice towards their daughter. However, they turn out to be not so nice after all. Her mother is a famous TV celebrity and her father seems to not care for Matilda because he's too busy thinking up ideas, for TV, and writing letters to the Prime Minister. Despite being so famous, Matilda's parents do not realize how their lack of love for Matilda and constant ignoring is doing harm to their daughter.

Matilda
A 5-year-old girl with very special powers. She makes her parents very proud when she goes and teaches Miss Honey how to read. Also she likes to read and learns faster than anyone Matilda's age.

Miss Honey
Matilda's kind and caring teacher. She first meets Mr and Mrs Wormwood who make a joke at her expense and seem very unimpressed by her. This is because they do not treat other people very nicely and do not realize how their own selfishness is hurting them, too. Miss Honey is very gentle and kind, however this also allows people to take advantage of her, the headmistress included. She is very intelligent and a kind student.

## History

Ms. Richards began her career as an actress at age four. She is a graduate of the Highwood Theatre Actors Repertory Company, (HTARC), which she has appeared in many of HTARC's productions. She appeared as Matilda in her school's production of Matilda by the Royal Shakespeare Company (Kansas City, MO); she also performed as Alice in the same school's production of Alice in Wonderland (Cinco Ranch High School, Houston, TX); as Gwendolyn Faircastle in Once Upon a Mattress; and, most notably, as Matilda herself in another school's production of Matilda. She has worked with the Houston-based company, The Phun Company, performing in such productions as The Jungle Book Kids, as the character Kaa, Peter Pan (Tinkerbell), Aladdin (Genie, Princess Jasmine, Abu, Carpet, and Snake Charmer), and The Lion King (Simba, Timon, and Jazi-Babe). She also appeared in a stage production of Disney's A Christmas Carol. Ms. Richards appeared as Daphne Blake (The Scooby Doo Show) in Kids Club, Inc.'s production of Scooby-Doo Is In The Museum. She has appeared in numerous stage productions, including The Addams Family, Godspell, West Side Story, and You're A Good Man Charlie Brown. Ms. Richards toured North America as Daisy Mae in the stage production of Li'l Abner. She was also one of the youngest performers ever to be accepted into The Houston Shakespeare Festival, a summer camp in which actors are taught Shakespeare by practitioners of the Royal Shakespeare Company. Upon graduation, she appeared as Miranda in the Royal Shakespeare Company's adaptation of Shakespeare's The Tempest. She appeared as Cinderella (alongside the Prince, Belle, and Aladdin) in the Houston Ballet's Christmas Show. Ms. Richards has also appeared in various TV commercials (for the Texas Department of Agriculture, the Texas Lottery and a Texas Public Television Station) in addition to modeling for various designers and national magazines. "If x is a positive integer or a solution to x+3>4, then x>0 and x>12."
output:
Prove the given statement using your information.

"If x is a positive integer or a solution to x+3>4, then x>0 and x>12."

I don't really understand how to explain this problem. Please explain in detail. Thanks.
[enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/ZjWKa.jpg)

Comment: How have you proved that $6$ and $29$ are solutions? (They seem to be the only two known by you)

Comment: @TheCount I haven't proven that numbers are a solution yet

Comment: Please clarify your specific problem or provide additional details to highlight exactly what you need. As it's currently written, it's hard to tell exactly what you're asking.

Answer: There is nothing to explain and the proof is an obvious consequence of the definition of \em{integer.}

Answer: A positive integer can have the following properties:
\begin{itemize}
\item It is even or odd
\item It is a multiple of $3$ or prime
\end{itemize}

If $x\geq 5$ ,  $x+3 > 4$ is impossible due to the multiple of $3$ criterion.

Thus $x<4$ or $x=5$, then $x+3>5$ is impossible due to the prime criterion. Since $x=5$  is impossible, then $x<4$ which is what we need to show.

instruction:
Based on the facts that have been provided, prove the following statement.

Statement: "For every integer k, k^2 + 2k + 1 ‚â• 0"
Fact: The square of any real number is non-negative.
output:
Based on the facts that have been provided, prove the following statement.

Statement: "For every integer k, k^2 + 2k + 1 ‚â• 0"
Fact: The square of any real number is non-negative.
Conclusion: In other words, for any real number, x, x^2 ‚â• 0. (This fact may be stated more broadly as any number can be represented as the square of some other integer.)

Since the statement and the facts used to prove it are consistent with our general understandings of the natural world, we have probable, a priori, justification for the statement.

### Proof by contradiction

Another way to prove the truth of a claim is by using a proof by contradiction. Consider again the fact that, for any real number, the square of that number is non-negative. We know that that statement is true, so why would it be true?

Suppose that the claim were false. In that case, for all of numbers x, the equation x^2 + (‚àí2)x + 1 would equal x^2 ‚àí 2x + 1. This means that the statement (x^2 + (‚àí2)x + 1 ‚àí (‚àí2x + 1) = 0 would hold for all of the numbers
If you multiply that equation by 2x, you get that x = ¬Ω. However, if x = ¬Ω, then what is 1 = x-1? You have a contradiction; therefore, the claim cannot be false.

### Deductive proof

Proof by induction is another method for proof, and one of the most common.

### Deductive proof

Proof by induction is another method for proof, and one of the most common.

Inductive arguments provide justification for claims through a process of generalization. Begin by asserting that a claim is true for a certain set, {1, 2, 3}, for instance. Then extend that set to set {1, 2, 3, n}, for all numbers n where n is a positive integer, i.e. a whole number with no fractional components‚Äîlike 3/2.

The claim must be consistent with other similar claims, even if the original claims are false. If the original claim is false‚Äîthat the square of every rational number is a rational number‚Äîthen its extention will also be false, since {1, 2, 3, n} is also false.

The same extention fails for every n. In other words, {1, 2, 3, n} is consistent with the extention of its preceding set, but it fails to extend to set {4, 5, 6, n} for any n. In other words, {1, 2, 3, n} fails to maintain its coherence with itself.

## Proof by computation

A computer is capable of providing a proof by computation, which is a very quick way to establish the truth of a proposition.

A proof by computation is typically not sufficient to establish a proposition because it is too easy to perform a proof by computation for the wrong proposition. However, it is a useful way to quickly check your proof when you are not sure if your proof is correct or not.

For example, if you need to establish that f(x) = x¬≤ + 3x ‚àí 2 = 0 is true for all numbers x, you could use the computer to find the values of f(x) for all numbers x. If it turns out your computation confirms the assertion, then you may be sure your proof is correct.

In fact, if the proposition you are trying to establish is simply true, a computer will easily give you a proof to establish the truth of the proposition. For example, if you wanted to establish that œÄ is an irrational number, you can simply use a computer to compute all of the decimal approximations to the decimal approximations of œÄ, and the computer can easily verify for you that it produces an infinite number of digits.

In this example the proof by computation takes less computational time to establish the truth of the proposition than any proof method known to man.
Computers are able to perform such proofs much more quickly than most other methods known to man.

## See also

* Axiomatic deduction
* Computer-aided theorem proving
* Deductive logic
* Deductive mathematician
* Discovery method
* Disqusitivism
* Euclid's Elements
* Formal language (mathematics)
* G√∂del's incompleteness theorems
* Mathematical proof
* Non-

instruction:
Verify the correctness of the given statement.

"For all integers j and k, if j and k are odd, then jk is odd."
output:
Verify the correctness of the given statement.

"For all integers j and k, if j and k are odd, then jk is odd."

My attempt:

If j and k are odd then . . .  [by the hypothesis]

Therefore jk is odd . . . [by associativity of multiplication]

Let me know if my proof is wrong.

Comment: Note: "by assumption" should be "by assumption" "by associativity" should be "by associator" and "by commutativity" should be "by commutator".

Answer: In fact (notice that $j$ and $k$ are \strong{not} necessarily integers), we say that $f\in C^{\infty}(\mathbb R)$ is a \em{smooth} function if $j$ and $k$ are integers in the statement above. We shall see later on that any continuous function is the limit of smooth functions.

Let assume that both $j$ and $k$ are odd. Then $f$ is the product of two odd numbers, i.e. $f=j\cdot k$. Then notice that \strong{all} the other factors are even. The result is even, in particular odd.

Now let assume that both $j$ and $k$ are even (it follows directly from the preceding case, that the case $j$, $k$ odd). Then $f=j\cdot k=2\cdot A$ where the $A$ is an even factor. It follows that $f$ is even as well. We already show that if $f$ is an integer even number, then it's odd.

Thus our hypothesis is true.

This is a simple proof about numbers (they're \strong{all} the elements of the system that we are considering now).

The previous argument should be generalized now that we consider continuous functions, but the argument should be the same.

instruction:
Provide a formula for computing the nth term in the given sequence

5, 14, 23, 32, 41, ...
output:
Provide a formula for computing the nth term in the given sequence

5, 14, 23, 32, 41, ...

I understand that this is an arithmetic progression, in which case we look for a common difference and use this to compute n for any given term. What I cannot understand, however, is how they get 672 for this problem. It seems like by using the formula we'd simply get 0 for the common difference. I'd greatly appreciate some help on this.

Edit: To answer one of the comments, they're using a general formula for an arithmetic progression that doesn't contain any common difference in it, and then are just using this.

Answer: It does seem strange that they used a "common difference" to calculate the n-th term. In my opinion, they probably used a general formula for arithmetic progressions to obtain the n-th term, and then used that formula.

from collections import namedtuple
import hashlib
import io

class Response:

    @staticmethod
    def _text(text):
        """Convert text to string"""
        if hashlib.sha512(io.BytesIO(text.encode()).digest()):
            return '"%s"' % text
        else:
            return text

    def __init__(self, content):
        self.text = Response._text(content)

    def respond(self, text):
        """Add text in chat"""
        self.text += self.text + text.encode("utf-8")

user_state = namedtuple("UserState", ["chat", "response", "matcher"])

class App:

    user_state = user_state

    @staticmethod

        """Matcher method for user_state"""

        if user_state.response is not None:
            user_state.response.respond(response)
        message = Message(user_state.matcher.get_new_message())
        message.response = response
        return message

    def get(self):
        """Matcher method for app"""
        message = Message(self.matcher.get_new_message())
        return message

instruction:
Currently, there is a chat in which people are arranging a meeting in the future. Retrieve the meeting information from the conversation.

Person 1: Hey, when are you free? I'd like to meet up.
Person 2: I'm free tomorrow afternoon.
Person 1: Great, what time?
Person 2: How about 3 pm?
Person 1: I have another meeting at that time. what about 5 pm?
Person 2: That works. Where should we meet?
Person 1: How about the coffee shop on Main Street?
Person 2: Sounds good. I've heard they have great coffee there. See you tomorrow!
output:
Currently, there is a chat in which people are arranging a meeting in the future. Retrieve the meeting information from the conversation.

Person 1: Hey, when are you free? I'd like to meet up.
Person 2: I'm free tomorrow afternoon.
Person 1: Great, what time?
Person 2: How about 3 pm?
Person 1: I have another meeting at that time. what about 5 pm?
Person 2: That works. Where should we meet?
Person 1: How about the coffee shop on Main Street?
Person 2: Sounds good. I've heard they have great coffee there. See you tomorrow!
I want to know if there is any way to find the information about the date and time of the meeting using a chatbot.

Answer: It's hard to get all that information from Chat in one line.
The bot may get the time part at this point.

\begin{code}
Person 1: Hey, when are you free? I'd like to meet up.
Person 2: I'm free tomorrow afternoon.
\end{code}

Or It maybe can parse this one line:

\begin{code}
Person 1: Hey, when are you free? I'd like to meet up.

Person 2: I'm free tomorrow afternoon.
\end{code}

It is possible to determine when is morning

\begin{code}
morning = datetime.datetime.now().hour < 10 && datetime.datetime.now().
hour > 22
\end{code}

But it won't determine what kind of day it is, it may be a Saturday or a Sunday.

If we have this much, we can build some simple program with `datetime` library.
Here's an example: https://gist.github.com/kristaps/f2e34be3c80f2644619e

And there are more ways to determine day on Python.
You may want to use an NLI Chatbot framework like Chatty to handle more natural language.

If you want to handle more information, but with similar approach here's another example with Google Calendar API:

\begin{code}
from google.calendar import CalendarService
import pprint

# Create and initialize a Calendar service.
service = CalendarService()

# Define an event object containing the parameters
# that you specify when you add an event to the user's calendar.
payload = {
'summary': "Event object",
'description': "Event object description",
'location': "Location",
'start': '2016-07-05T8:00:00'
}

service.events.insert(user="me@email.com", body={'event': payload})
\end{code}

https://developers.google.com/google-apps/calendar/v3/reference/events/insert

instruction:
Describe the content of the article in a brief manner.

A study published earlier this year by Zee and her team examined the role of light in sleep for healthy adults in their 20s. Sleeping for only one night with a dim light, such as a TV set with the sound off, raised the blood sugar and heart rate of the young people during the sleep lab experiment. An elevated heart rate at night has been shown in prior studies to be a risk factor for future heart disease and early death, while higher blood sugar levels are a sign of insulin resistance, which can ultimately lead to type 2 diabetes.
output:
Describe the content of the article in a brief manner.

A study published earlier this year by Zee and her team examined the role of light in sleep for healthy adults in their 20s. Sleeping for only one night with a dim light, such as a TV set with the sound off, raised the blood sugar and heart rate of the young people during the sleep lab experiment. An elevated heart rate at night has been shown in prior studies to be a risk factor for future heart disease and early death, while higher blood sugar levels are a sign of insulin resistance, which can ultimately lead to type 2 diabetes.

## Research

Zee is the recipient of numerous research grants for her investigative work, including funding from the National Institutes of Health, the National Science Foundation, and the Dana Foundation. In 2014, her Dana Foundation research focused on the adverse effects of blue light on health. In the experiment, Zee and her team found that light exposure before bedtime can impact how much sleep participants received. Her research on light's effects on sleep has been covered in numerous media outlets, including the New York Times, Scientific American, Smithsonian Magazine, Forbes, NBC Nightly News, and The Weather Channel. Zee is known for speaking about her scientific research regarding light and health. Her presentations on such topics can be seen on her website.

## Professional activities

Zee serves on the editorial boards of Sleep Medicine, and Clinical and Experimental Hypertension. She is a member of the National Academy of Medicine and the National Academy of Sciences. Her book, The Mind-Gut Connection is being translated into Chinese, Korean, and Thai languages, and will be available as an e-book. She is currently authoring a book for a lay audience on the topic of light and human health.

## Honors

* 2010 MacArthur Foundation Fellowship
* 2014 Javits Neuroscience Investigator
* 2015 Award for Research Excellence
* 2015 UCSF Leader of the Year for Research
* 2016 3M Non- Tenured Faculty Award
* 2017 Kavli Prize in Neuroscience
* 2018 Elected Member of the National Academy of Sciences

## Works

* Zee, PhD, PhD, PhD, PhD, PhD; D. PhD Pharmacology, PhD, PhD. Ph.D.(2019). The Mind-Gut Connection: How the Hidden Conversation Within Our Bodies Impacts Our Mood, Our Choices, and Our Overall Health (1st ed.). Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group. ISBN 9780525612166.
* Zee PhD, PhD, PhD, PhD, PhD (March 2009). "Light as an environmental factor in circadian rhythm regulation". The International Journal of Experimental Morphology. 33 (3): 257‚Äì276. doi:10.4081/jem.2009.145. PMID 19624781.
* Cajochen, PhD, PhD, PhD; PhD; PhD. D. PhD (2011). "The effects of light on circadian physiology: Relevance for sleep and aging". Sleep Medicine Reviews. 15 (5): 311‚Äì324. doi:10.1016/j.smrv.2011.01.003. PMID 21368702.
* PhD, PhD, PhD, PhD; et al. (September 2014). "The effect of color temperature on circadian phase and sleep patterns of young adults". Biological Psychology. 92 Part B: 34‚Äì42. doi:10.1016/j.biopsych.2014.04.012. PMID 25454453.

## External links

* Official website
* Randy J. Nelson, University of Kentucky (2007) "Phototransduction in Photoreceptors"

instruction:
