output:
Describe the responsibilities of the given job.

Security Officer
==============

-   Develop and implement security processes/policies for the organization.
-   Conduct safety and security inspections.
-   Develop a comprehensive organization-wide vulnerability management program across all assets and infrastructure with recommendations regarding the mitigation of key vulnerabilities.
-   Work closely with the organization's management team to develop and implement procedures for assessing new technologies and systems and determining the level of risk associated with each technology and system.
-   Create and distribute security procedures such as the Organization's Computer Use and Cyber Security Procedures.
-   Develop and distribute procedures for data and identity confidentiality.
-   Develop organization-wide policies for protecting sensitive information, including information security and privacy policies.
-   Develop procedures for protecting organizational critical security information.
-   Develop and implement a technology strategy that is commensurate with organization's business strategy and goals.
-   Be knowledgeable about and comply with applicable laws and regulations regarding cyber security.
-   Perform other related duties as assigned by the Director of Information Systems.

Job Requirements:
-   Computer networking knowledge, understanding, experience or training.
-   Knowledge of security threats and vulnerabilities.
-   A basic knowledge of and sensitivity to the needs of and issues affecting members with different backgrounds, particularly individuals with disabilities or members of ethnic minority groups.
-   Interpersonal skills necessary to work effectively with staff, clients, suppliers and others.
-   Proficiency in MS Office and other applications, databases and information management tools.

Job Hours/Days:
\begin{itemize}
\item Monday to Friday; 8 hours per day.
\item Flex-Time; 4 days a week.
\item Weekends; 2 hours a day. If needed, must be willing to work 6 hours a day for 3 consecutive days in a month.
\end{itemize}

Job Requirements:
\begin{itemize}
\item Network security and monitoring experience;
-   A Bachelor's degree in an appropriate field such as information systems or computer science;
-   At least 6 years of progressively responsible experience in computing/information technology or in an IT security role.
\end{itemize}

Job Hours/Days:
\begin{itemize}
\item Monday to Friday; 8 hours per day.
\item Flex-Time; 4 days a week.
\item Weekends; 2 hours a day. If needed, must be willing to work 6 hours a day for 3 consecutive days in a month.
\end{itemize}

Job Requirements:
\begin{itemize}
\item At least 2 years of experience with the Windows Server operating system;
\item At least 2 years of experience with the Linux operating system.
\end{itemize}

Job Hours/Days:
\begin{itemize}
\item Monday to Friday; 8 hours per day.
\item Flex-Time; 4 days a week.
\item Weekends; 2 hours a day. If needed, must be willing to work 6 hours a day for 3 consecutive days in a month.
\end{itemize}

Job Requirements:
\begin{itemize}
\item Criminal records searches;
\item Driver's license check.
\end{itemize}

Job Hours/Days:
\begin{itemize}
\item Monday to Friday; 8 hours per day.
\item Flex-Time; 4 days a week.
\item Weekends; 2 hours a day. If needed, must be willing to work 6 hours a day for 3 consecutive days in a month.
\end{itemize}

\strong{Security Officer}, a.k.a Security Analyst/Consultant

-   Identify and respond to network security breaches, hacker and other external threats, unauthorized access, and unauthorized use of IT resources.
-   Conduct security inspections of IT systems and infrastructure.
-   Identify and analyze security threats to the organization's information technology, infrastructure and information.
-   Determine vulnerability of the organization's existing IT systems and infrastructure to external breaches and provide recommendations for remediation.
-   Develop an effective strategy for protecting the organization's assets, including its information assets.
-   Collaborate with internal and external partners to provide security assessment,

In Croatian, the question is: "Uma≈æite li se?". This phrase means "Could you deal with [the conditions and procedures of the company] ...?" It is one of the questions you are asked during the interview and one of the questions that you can ask the interviewer. Note that this phrase does not mean "Can you get along with ...?" or "Do you get along with ...?" You may be asked a number of other questions about your ability to work with others, and this is one of the ways you can ask about it.

## External links

* "How to answer "can you work with others?" question" (How to Answer the Interview Questions) by Chris Saunders - 2006.

Meeting1: scheduled at 11 am, duration: 30 min
Meeting2: scheduled at 1:30 pm, duration: 90 min
Meeting3: scheduled at 2:30 pm, duration: 60 min
\end{code}

To add complexity, multiple persons (person1, person2, person3) may be on the same meeting.

What is the most simple / elegant way to determine such meetings within the constraints of the given information?

Answer: The following approach works for given input:

\begin{code}
from datetime import datetime

def scheduling(times, duration, persons):

    # Initialize to a new datetime object with time passed 0.
    now = datetime(now = datetime.today()) # = now - 5 minutes.
    meetings = [[] for i in persons]
    # Create and initialize new list with same number of persons.

    # Go through all persons with time passed 0.
    for person, a_time, d_time, a_duration in zip(persons, times, times[1:], duration):
        # Get a_time if it is greater than 0.
        if a_time >= 0:
            # Create a new datetime object and get its time of day.
            now = datetime(now = datetime.now())
            now = datetime(now = datetime.now()) + datetime(hour = a_time, minute = 0, second = 0)

            # If the now is less than d_time pass 0 as time of day.
            if now <= d_time:
                now = datetime(now = now)
                # Pass time of day to the meetings list with the same
                # person id as of person and the duration time passed.
                meetings[person].append(now)
                                         # Pass to the time of today.
                now = datetime(now = datetime.now())
                now = now
            else:
                # Pass time of day to the meetings list with the same
                # person id as of person and the duration time passed.
                meetings[person].append(now)
                # Get the next time for each persons time.

    return now, meetings

now, meetings = scheduling(times=[9, 11, 13, 15], duration=[30], persons=[1, 2, 3])
print(now)
print(meetings)

instruction:
Give a brief explanation of the requested part of the paper.

Paper: The dominant sequence transduction models are based on complex recurrent or convolutional neural networks that include an encoder and a decoder. The best performing models also connect the encoder and decoder through an attention mechanism. We propose a new simple network architecture, the Transformer, based solely on attention mechanisms, dispensing with recurrence and convolutions entirely. Experiments on two machine translation tasks show these models to be superior in quality while being more parallelizable and requiring significantly less time to train. Our model achieves 28.4 BLEU on the WMT 2014 English-to-German translation task, improving over the existing best results, including ensembles, by over 2 BLEU. On the WMT 2014 English-to-French translation task, our model establishes a new single-model state-of-the-art BLEU score of 41.8 after training for 3.5 days on eight GPUs, a small fraction of the training costs of the best models from the literature. We show that the Transformer generalizes well to other tasks by applying it successfully to English constituency parsing both with large and limited training data.
Explain: The dominant sequence transduction models
output:
Give a brief explanation of the requested part of the paper.

Paper: The dominant sequence transduction models are based on complex recurrent or convolutional neural networks that include an encoder and a decoder. The best performing models also connect the encoder and decoder through an attention mechanism. We propose a new simple network architecture, the Transformer, based solely on attention mechanisms, dispensing with recurrence and convolutions entirely. Experiments on two machine translation tasks show these models to be superior in quality while being more parallelizable and requiring significantly less time to train. Our model achieves 28.4 BLEU on the WMT 2014 English-to-German translation task, improving over the existing best results, including ensembles, by over 2 BLEU. On the WMT 2014 English-to-French translation task, our model establishes a new single-model state-of-the-art BLEU score of 41.8 after training for 3.5 days on eight GPUs, a small fraction of the training costs of the best models from the literature. We show that the Transformer generalizes well to other tasks by applying it successfully to English constituency parsing both with large and limited training data.
Explain: The dominant sequence transduction models for machine translation are based on complex recurrent networks or convolutional layers that involve an encoder and decoder. Attention is used by the majority of RNN-based machine translation systems to control the flow of information between the encoder and decoder. This paper proposes a new network architecture built on attention mechanisms, instead of convolutions and recurrent layers, which is simpler and more efficient during train time. We find that our network architecture, the Transformer, performs very well in terms of translation quality and training speed in the machine translation domain. We also apply the Transformer architecture to constitute a new state-of-the-art in English constituency parsing on both Penn Tree Bank and Brown 1996 and 2002 datasets with limited training data.

\section*{Acknowledgments}

We would like to thank the anonymous reviewers, the organizers of the 2016 HLT workshop,
the WMT 2014, 2015 and 2016 challenges, and Google Research for making the WMT 2014, 2015 and 2016 corpus available.
This research did not require any experimental subjects.

instruction:
Extract the method that has been used in the research from the abstract of the paper. Give the exact sentences from the abstract that discuss the method.

We present a state-of-the-art speech recognition system developed using end-to-end deep learning. Our architecture is significantly simpler than traditional speech systems, which rely on laboriously engineered processing pipelines; these traditional systems also tend to perform poorly when used in noisy environments. In contrast, our system does not need hand-designed components to model background noise, reverberation, or speaker variation, but instead directly learns a function that is robust to such effects. We do not need a phoneme dictionary, nor even the concept of a "phoneme." Key to our approach is a well-optimized RNN training system that uses multiple GPUs, as well as a set of novel data synthesis techniques that allow us to efficiently obtain a large amount of varied data for training. Our system, called Deep Speech, outperforms previously published results on the widely studied Switchboard Hub5'00, achieving 16.0% error on the full test set. Deep Speech also handles challenging noisy environments better than widely used, state-of-the-art commercial speech systems.Collapse

instruction:
Create a short, concise summary of the paper based on its abstract.

Few-shot learning (FSL) is one of the key future steps in machine learning and raises a lot of attention. In this paper, we focus on the FSL problem of dialogue understanding, which contains two closely related tasks: intent detection and slot filling. Dialogue understanding has been proven to benefit a lot from jointly learning the two sub-tasks. However, such joint learning becomes challenging in the few-shot scenarios: on the one hand, the sparsity of samples greatly magnifies the difficulty of modeling the connection between the two tasks; on the other hand, how to jointly learn multiple tasks in the few-shot setting is still less investigated. In response to this, we introduce FewJoint, the first FSL benchmark for joint dialogue understanding. FewJoint provides a new corpus with 59 different dialogue domains from real industrial API and a code platform to ease FSL experiment set-up, which are expected to advance the research of this field. Further, we find that insufficient performance of the few-shot setting often leads to noisy sharing between two sub-task and disturbs joint learning. To tackle this, we guide slot with explicit intent information and propose a novel trust gating mechanism that blocks low-confidence intent information to ensure high quality sharing. Besides, we introduce a Reptile-based meta-learning strategy to achieve better generalization in unseen few-shot domains. In the experiments, the proposed method brings significant improvements on two datasets and achieve new state-of-the-art performance.

Answer: This program is ugly, but might do what you ask:

\begin{code}
#!/usr/bin/env python

import sys
import re
import string

cut_table_str = (
    r"[0-9]+"         # Col number, no leading $ or @
    +r"\s*|\s+$"     # optional whitespace characters
    +r"""[0-9]*{}"   # optional column prefixes $ or @
    +r"""[0-9]*"""   # optional column suffixes $ or @
    +r""").format(sys.version_info)

def get_column_width(line):
     col_width = cut_table_str.search(line)
     if not col_width:
         raise ValueError("Error: line [%s] cannot be cut into column" % (line))
     return col_width.group(1).count()

def parse_line(line):
    if not line: return
    return map(int, re.split(cut_table_str, line))

def split_line(line):
    """split_line(line)

    Split the string on [space] characters, which
    is the default delimiter. Ignore leading or trailing
    [spaces].
    """

    n = get_column_width(line) if isinstance(line,unicode) else len(line)
    for ch in string.split(" ", line, n):
        if ch in string.whitespace: continue
        return ch

def main():
    in_fd = sys.stdin
    in_iter = iter(in_fd)
    out_fd = sys.stdout

    if not isinstance(in_iter, file):
        in_iter = iter(in_iter)
        out_fd = StringIO(sys.stdout)
        print >> out_fd
    lines = out_fd.write(next(in_iter))
    while True:
        line = next(in_iter)
        lines += [map(parse_line, str.split(" ", string.strip(line)))]
        lines += [str.join(map(parse_line, str.split(" ", string.strip(line))))]
        lines = str.strip("\n") + "\n" + "".join(lines)
        out_fd.write(lines)
        out_fd.write("\n")
        out_fd.flush()
        if not isinstance(in_iter, string):
            in_iter = iter(in_iter)
            out_fd = StringIO(sys.stdout)
            print >> out_fd
        in_fd = StringIO(next(in_iter))
    out_fd.flush()

main()
\end{code}

Assess the sentiment of the given tweet and categorize it as Positive, Negative, or Neutral.

"This is the best cheat-sheet paper that I've found in a LONG time."
output:
Assess the sentiment of the given tweet and categorize it as Positive, Negative, or Neutral.

"This is the best cheat-sheet paper that I've found in a LONG time." - @thomas_dewet

- This class implements SentiWordNet 2.0 as its default sentiment classifier.
- The sentiments can be categorized as Positive, Negative, and Neutral.
"""

import os
import string

from collections import defaultdict
from pprint import pprint
from string import maketrans
from sklearn.feature_extraction.text import TfIDFvectorizer

from scipy.stats import norm

from dkrest.classes import DKRSTweet, DKRSTweetList
from dkrest.exceptions import OSError


###############################################################################
# Functions
###############################################################################

def sentiment(val):
    """Determine if val contains a positive, negative, or neutral sentiment.
    :param val: The text representation of the value that will be sent to the sentiment
                 analyzer.
    :type val: string
    :return: The value that is determined to be positive, negatively, or neutral based on the
             analysis of the sentiment classifier function.
    """
    sentiments = ['n', 'p', 'n']
    if sentiments.count(val.lower()) > 0:
        return sentiments.index(val.lower())
    else:
        raise ValueError('Sentiment not determined from "%s"' % val)

def wordnetizer(tweet, sentiment=False):
    """WordNetizer function.

    :param tweet: The instance of DKRSTweet
    :type tweet: DKRSTweet
    :param sentiment: If True, the value will be sent to the Sentiment analyzer function.
    :type sentiment: bool
    :return: An instance of DKRSTweetList with the new sentiment values added
    :type: DKRSTweetList
    """
    if sentiment:
        val = sentiment(tweet.text)
        if val > 0:
            for tweet in tweet.list_tweets:
                wordnetizer(tweet, val)

    # Get TF-IDF vectorizer for all words in the tweet
    vectorizer = TfIDFvectorizer(ngram_range=(1,3))
    vectorizer.fit(dok.escape(tweet.text))

    text_vect = vectorizer.transform(dok.escape(tweet.text))
    for i, entry in enumerate(text_vect):
        for e in entry:
            if e > 0:
                e = (e - math.log(vectorizer.vocabulary_); e) * \
                    dokexpr(vectorizer.norm_transform([e])))
            else:
                e = 0

            for k, v in e.items():
                temp_v = (v / (vectorizer.vocabulary_ - 1))

                temp_word = maketrans(string.ascii_lowercase)

                temp_list = [dok.escape(word) for word in temp_v]
                temp_sent = maketrans(temp_list)

                temp_v1 = [dok.escape(word) for word in val]
                temp_sent1 = maketrans(temp_v1)

                temp_list = ([word for word, _ in val.items()]
                             + [word for word, _ in temp_v1.items()]
                             + maketrans(temp_list))

                val[i] = temp_v = maketrans(temp_list)
            # Sentiments are always at index 0 in SentiWordNet 2.0
            # This method allows you to use the rest of the
            # vectorization features with the sentiment analysis
            # without the vectorizer trying to analyze the sentiment
            # itself
            temp_v.update(temp_sent1)

            val[i] = temp_v

    # Sentiment is an index in SentiWordNet 2.0 and is mapped to a key/value pair
    # so that the rest of the vectorization features can be used with the sentiment
    # analyzer

print "Hello World!\n"

Using \em{print} is like print and end, in this case, there is \em{end} after \em{print}. I don't know if you're aware of it, but is also a good practice to use the \em{.gsub} method. This way you can make your code more readable.

\begin{code}
from nltk.corpus import brown
from nltk.tokenize import sent_tokenize
from nltk.sentiment import SentimentAnalyser

brown=brown.raw()

#checking words
words = brown.words()

#analysing sentences using nltk SentimentAnalyser
sentence_text = 'I do not like apple. Apple is poison.'
sentence_words = sent_tokenize(sentence_text)
sentence_sent_text = SentimentAnalyser()
sentence_sent_text['sentences'] = sentence_words
pos_words = sentence_sent_text['pos']
neg_words = sentence_sent_text['neg']
sentence_sent_text['pos'] = sentiment.sentiment_score(pos_words, neg=True)
sentence_sent_text['type'] = sentence_sent_text['type'].split(',')

print(sentence_text)
print(sentence_words)
print(sentence_sent_text)
print(sentence_sent_text['pos'])
\end{code}

Provide a name for the dish given the ingredients and instructions.

INGREDIENTS:
2 (5 oz) cans Bumble Bee¬Æ Solid White Albacore Tuna, drained
1 avocado
2 Tbsp Sriracha
1 Tbsp Dijon mustard
2 to 3 Tbsp celery, chopped
2 Tbsp red onion, chopped
2 green onions, chopped
1 Tbsp fresh cilantro, chopped
Salt and pepper, to taste
2 heaping cups leafy green lettuce
1 cup matchstick carrots
4 (10 inch) whole wheat tortillas
INSTRUCTIONS:
In a medium bowl, mash together tuna and avocado until combined. Add in the rest of the ingredients through the salt and pepper, mixing well.
To assemble, top each tortilla with a 1/2 cup leafy greens, 1/4 cup matchstick carrots and divide the tuna mixture evenly among the wraps. Tightly roll up the tortilla, slice and enjoy!

INGREDIENTS:
2 (5 oz) cans Bumble Bee¬Æ Solid White Albacore Tuna, drained
1 avocado
2 Tbsp Sriracha
1 Tbsp Dijon mustard
2 to 3 Tbsp celery, chopped
2 Tbsp red onion, chopped
2 green onions, chopped

Salt and pepper, to taste

Comment: It‚Äôs hard to get much mileage out of ‚Äúdish‚Äù meaning ‚Äúrecipe‚Äù, but still, it would be more precise to call those ‚Äúguidelines‚Äù (or recommendations, or instructions‚Ä¶) or ‚Äúingredient list‚Äù (or ‚Äúsuggested ingredients list‚Äù) or ‚Äúmenu‚Äù or ‚Äúlist of menu items‚Äù or ‚Äúpantry list‚Äù.

Comment: I think this makes the most sense. Is it common to leave off the "ingredients" part of the puzzle but have it in the text, at the end of the paragraph, maybe, to show the reader it's part of the problem? (Think the old riddles where the answer showed up after a few words/phrases were taken away.) Or, when you don't want the title to show up, are there other common ways to word it?

Answer: How about \strong{guidelines}?

According to [Cambridge Dictionaries Online](http://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/guidelines?q=guidelines), it can also mean \strong{list of instructions, especially for a team or an organisation}. So, it suits well with the part of the instructions you've added.

From \strong{Oxford Dictionaries} [dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/guidelines](http://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/guidelines)
:

\begin{blockquote}

something (such as a list of instructions) that shows how to do, or how to be, something
\end{blockquote}

The usage of \strong{guidelines} in this case is very common. You don't often describe the recipe as instructions. It's always a list of ingredients and maybe a few instructions. Like I've said before, it can be anything that shows how to do something. So, I'd recommend using the term.

instruction:
Given a programming language and the name of a function, write a command to show how to use the function.

Language: Python
Function: input

Provide a pleasant compliment based on the quality you have been given.

Truthfulness
output:
Provide a pleasant compliment based on the quality you have been given.

Truthfulness and uprightness do not depend on whether our words are being received well by the one at whom they are aimed. We can use an honest truth in a cruel or untruthful manner -- that is a different matter. But for the sake of the truth we may be criticized harshly, and yet, it must be said, with a good purpose.

No, that can never make you a liar. And so with a pleasant compliment. The quality which it seeks to emphasize really shows that you are honest, truthworthy, upright. And so the quality of sweetness, of tact, of kindness, must accompany all genuine compliment-giving.

The Complimenter

The one who is given the good words is, of course, the recipient. He is the one to whom the compliment is directed, upon whom it is bestowed.

But just as the word, the phrase, and the thought is one with the man giving it, so the word, the phrase, and the thought is one with the man receiving it.

So I know my attitude about the word to be what my attitude about the man is, and so in the mind of the receiver of a sweet compliment the sweetness of the words will be lost. To a man of kindness the receiver of unkind words will be hurt. And to a man of kindness the words of unkindness will be unkind.

The real receiver of the sweetness is the personality. The one who sees it is the man. With him goes the thought of the sweetness. As it is in the mind, so he is. The man knows his own sweetness, knows the goodness of the good words which have been given him.

This is not the compliment -- for in receiving the gift the receiver knows the giving. This is not the sweetness -- for in receiving the gift the receiver knows the sweetness of the words. The real gift is in the man, and it is this that the one giving the word has been directed to see.

A Sweet Complaint

In any matter that may come to an argument, a complaint, a discussion, a contest -- make it as sweet as you know how to do, a sweet compliment. It will save you from bitterness, from unkind words, from hardness, from untruth. Let it be a plea for the other man, a plea for the relationship, and not a plea for your own right.

When all is said and done, when you have lost your point, when you have been given good words which you had not expected -- let them be true in your heart. And so be a witness to the loveliness of the world, as you see it.

Let it be a sweet word. In the midst of strife, in the midst of turmoil, in the midst of greatness, let it be a sweet word with which you leave your neighbor.

The real sweetness will come because you are, have been, and will be in your heart a great one. But in the presence of that great one, you may have been unkind. But a word of kindness may have saved you from bitterness, and that word of kindness will go into the world, and will come back to you a thousand-fold.

Let us seek to be kind in all things, and let us remember that any sweetness we bring into the world must be sweetness from our hearts. We must be ourselves the living, speaking proof of the greatness of the world when we speak.

We Must Be Comfortable

There is a wonderful comfort in making this effort to bring sweetness, to receive sweetness. There is a wonderful beauty in the way the thing comes forth.

The world around us is sweet. There is nothing sweet about the things which are harsh, which are unkind, which are evil. The sweetness is in you. It is you who have it in your heart. It was not there until you added yourself to the world.

The world has a sweetness, but it is not your world except as you have added yourself to the world of the man, the woman, the child. But when you see the sweetness, when you feel its sweetness, and when you hear its sweetness, and when you know its sweetness of the living things which are moving or which are still, why can you not believe in the sweetness of the world in which you live? Why can you not then know for yourself the sweetness of the world in which you live?

There is something beautiful about the way it comes. There is something wonderful about

Someone gives you some information about where they want to go and what they enjoy seeing and doing. Describe a proper road trip for them and find the best stops and sctivities in the way.

I'm looking for a west coast road trip. My goal is to start near San Diego and travel to Los Angeles.
output: Someone gives you some information about where they want to go and what they enjoy seeing and doing. Describe a proper road trip for them and find the best stops and sctivities in the way. I'm looking for a west coast road trip. My goal is to start near San Diego and travel to Los Angeles. My budget is up to $100/night and I don't really care if we have to camp some nights or where we eat. My boyfriend and I have very different interests and preferences. For example, he prefers to visit small towns and I like urban areas. \strong{Sample question:} \begin{blockquote} Hi, I'm planning a trip around the West Coast and am wondering if anyone here had the best route and a place to stay that they enjoyed. \em{[Sample answer]} We went from San Diego to Los Angeles and stopped at this [place in Santa Barbara][1]. We stayed in a small hotel in downtown LA in Hollywood. \end{blockquote} I tried to come up with something and I was thinking about [this travel stack exchange post][2] but I'm looking more for a simple list in the question: \begin{itemize} \item A proper route to take \item Stops, must see points \item Somewhere (camping, hotel, hostel) to stay the night \end{itemize} [1]: http://www.staylo.com/hotel-san-fernando Some related questions: \begin{itemize} \item [Where to drive for 3 days from San Fransisco Bay area to Los Angeles by March 1](https://travel.stackexchange.com/questions/25780/where-to-drive-for-3-days-from-san-fransisco-bay-area-to-los-angeles-by-march) \item [Driving from LA to SF, what must I see in between?](https://travel.stackexchange.com/questions/20483/driving-from-la-to-sf-what-must-i-see-in-between) \end{itemize} Answer: This looks like an online planning application, and seems to get the job done in a more efficient manner than posting it here on a website. It's free to use. It's based on Google Maps. https://www.mapswithme.com/ Once you've got a more precise plan and route, and a destination or area with a lot to see, the next step is figuring out places to stay, and therein lays another question entirely. Comment: I think Mapswithme is the right tool to use when planning. It even says "It also has options to search for places to stay with no need for internet" Answer: The quick answer: Going from San Diego to Los Angeles will take you about 3 hours in normal traffic (45 mph speed limit, so ~60 mph if you're speeding). So you should allow 2 and a half days to get from San Diego to Hollywood if you plan to move around a bit. Of course, this isn't the whole answer. On your list: \begin{itemize} \item Don't assume that people with different interests will be \em{happy} with different interests. It's a great way for people to have really good arguments. Your boyfriend, I'm guessing, is going to be far more pleased with an entirely different set of stops and activities. You will probably have a better time if you compromise. \item Stop by the desert outside of Palm Springs or the Salton Sea in the middle of no where if you want to avoid the crowds and see some awesome weirdness \item I would make every possible effort to book the cheapest, crappiest, and most anonymous motel available in any given spot to avoid "having to eat" and "having to camp" \item You should look at a map and try to make sense of it. For example, it's pretty easy to see that the desert of southern California is a good place to go, because it's full of nothing but nothing, and you won't encounter the massive, sprawling, massive, and even more sprawling cities of the east coast until much later in the trip. (Don't drive past Phoenix!) \end

output:
Regex is a set of characters that define a search pattern. This kind of pattern is usually used by string-searching algorithms to find or replace strings or to validate inputs. Convert the natural english text to regex.

Match a valid ip address. Check out this [page](http://regexpal.com/compare).

\begin{code}
^(?:\d{1,3}(\.\d{1,3}){3}\.?)|(\2{3}){1}(?:\2\.?){2}$
\end{code}

Above is valid IP v4 and v6, in this case if the string is ip address in v4 format it match the first group `{1}` and so on.

Now how to convert ip address to regex, for this in the web we can use http://www.regular-expressions.info/ip.html and regex101.com.

This [page](http://www.regular-expressions.info/ip.html) explains every format and gives sample regex too. This [page](http://regex101.com/r/UhXD0) also explains how to convert.

Above is regex in java regex and you can use it with the string `ip_addr` that is IPv4 format.

Hope helps.

The function for getting the property address is defined below.

\begin{code}
import requests
def get_address():

    query = "https://api.zillow.com/research/get_address_details/id/1/query_type/sale_page/location/"
    response = requests.get(query)
    property_address = response.json()["results"][0]["address"]

    return property_address

print get_address()
\end{code}

For a few reasons explained below, I want to have one function that returns the property address as well as the description and pictures. The description and pictures are given in the same json format as the address. The description and pictures are fetched from the same location as the address.

Comment: You say that you want the pictures from the same URL. But that URL doesn't seem to support that request. I'm guessing that you want to pass this URL somehow to `requests.get`?

Answer: I am not sure exactly what you are trying to accomplish but I will work with both API responses returned from `requests` and the data you have provided. Here is my attempt below:

\begin{code}
import requests, json

# Get the property address
def get_address():
    response = json.loads(requests.get('https://api.zillow.com/research/get_address_details/id/1/query_type/sale_page/location').text)
    address_json = response[0]

    # Get the pictures
    url = "https://api.zillow.com/v2/"
    url += "pictures?address=" + address_json['address']
    picture_id_list = []
    response = json.loads(requests.get(url).text)
    for element in response[response]:
      picture_url = element[0]['photo_url'] + '?zestimate_id=' + element[1]
      picture_id_list.append(picture_url)

    # Make an array to store the addresses
    all_list = []
    # add pictures to all_list
    for picture_url in picture_id_list:
      all_list.append([picture_url, '', '']
      url = 'https://api.zillow.com/v2/'
      url += 'pictures?zestimate_id=' + address_json['id'] + '&pic_link=' + picture_url
      data = json.loads(requests.get(url).text)
      # get the description
      descrip += data[0]['description']
      # get thumbnail for description
      thumbnail_url = data[0]['thumbnail_url']
      img_src = thumbnail_url if 'thumbnail_url' in data[0].keys() else data[0]['picture_url']
      # save data
      all_list.append([img_src, descrip, ''])
    return all_list
\end{code}

The result should be a data object (or a list in this example). However, a single property with its entire description is not enough! We must retrieve the entire description and all the details of the property.

This example illustrates how to achieve this goal using the `lxml` module. The key parts of code are indicated here:

\begin{code}
from __future__ import print_function

import lxml.html as html

def html_parser(url):
    """Retrieve HTML data from a URL.

    :param url: URL to HTML data.
    :type url: str
    """
    r = requests.get(url)

    r.content = html.fromstring(r.content)

    return r
\end{code}

Once we have the HTML data, we will use `lxml.html.etree.fromstring` to create an `lxml` object from the data and extract the desired metadata from the property list.

\begin{code}
from __future__ import print_function

import lxml

def html_parser(url):
    """Retrieve HTML data from a URL.

    :param url: URL to HTML data.
    :type url: str
    """
    r = requests.get(url)

    r.content = lxml.html.fromstring(r.content)

    return r

for r in html_parser(url):
    metadata = {}
    meta = lxml.html.etree.fromstring(r.content)
    for meta_elem in metadata:
        metadata[meta_elem] = ' '.join(
            str(e) for e in lxml.html.etree.XPathSelector(meta, './/'))
        break
\end{code}

instruction:
Suggest some product bundles that are often purchased with a given product.

MacBook Air
output:
Suggest some product bundles that are often purchased with a given product.

MacBook Air bundle with Airport Express
Windows Laptop + Bluetooth
Linux Laptop + VPN

Comment: There's no bundle that comes with it? You are using this laptop to buy onlin and you'd rather have some extra thing. It would seem to me that the bundle should only take effect if you buy your laptop onlin and not offlin and then take the shipping time and extra cost out of the equation.

Answer: You should keep this information somewhere else, if it's going to be reused frequently.  Having the ability to quickly lookup this information as needed will help keep you from having to pull it off this document each time.

I would definitely keep this in the documentation.  You may use a database to keep track of, and query, the data.  If the data is not going to change much, using a spreadsheet is a great option.  That way you can copy it quickly to a document you're trying to write-up.

Answer: I agree with the previous posters; you have to maintain this list somewhere, because you're going to have to reference it every time.  In addition, I would add that you should also keep the ordering system up-to-date.  There's no point in having a list that has information that's no longer valid, and the only way to keep it current is to update it.

I would suggest that you have multiple "lists" for different products: a "computer" list for computers, a "printer" list for printers, and an "accessories" list for accessories.  You may not need to refer to the accessories list as often as to the computer list, but if there's a good deal on a new iPod, or some kind of accessory, that needs to show up on the list at the top too.

You could also have a "list of lists"; one list of computer lists and another list of printer lists - and then just refer to that master list when you need any of the lists.

The only caveat that I would add: if you have separate lists for the "same" product, you may have a conflict if someone who's selling one of the "sibling" products (e.g. Macs and iPods, both made by Apple) decides to make an offer on the other product, especially when this offer only lasts for a limited amount of time.  If the product has identical descriptions and names, you're probably OK; if not, make sure that any changes you make are obvious.

Comment: The "same product" scenario is handled very easily with SKU's and/or PN's. If both products share a common SKU/PN, then their description and names can overlap. If a computer has an iPod accessory bundle, we would just change the SKU/PNs on both products to indicate their inclusion in the bundle.

Comment: @Jason - What happens if a customer makes an error with the PNs/SKUs, and orders the wrong product?  Or what if the customer has multiple products, each of which is listed multiple times in the catalog, but for different products?  What good is a PN if two products have the same PN, but different descriptions and names; it might make sense for customer support, but if it goes out to the general public, how is it going to make any sense?  In many cases, names and descriptions are not arbitrary; Apple had a "Flower Power" Powerbook that sold a lot of iPods...

Comment: @Chris - Yes, this is an issue. I have no solid answer. I suppose that the product listing could be duplicated, and the customer support person can make the call to determine whether their query is valid (easily by comparing an SKU) and to tell them which product page to navigate to in order to order the desired item?

Answer: I would only add an SKU to the product page if it is going to be used on a shipping manifest to generate a shipping label. I would have a separate SKU for any bundles so they don't change on the merchant site.

If a product is not shippable, I would not add it to the merchant store but I'd include them in the product list.

Answer: I'd only add an SKU to a product in my inventory if:
\begin{itemize}
\item the product is shippable and/or resalable
\item it's going to change with the time, be it a limited-time bundle, a limited-supply bundle, a bundled sh

instruction:
As part of software engineering, user stories describe what the user wants the system to do, while acceptance criteria describe the conditions a specific user story must meet. Create basic acceptance criteria based on the given user story.

User story: As a user, I want to use a search field to type a city, name, or street, so that I could find matching hotel options.
output:
As part of software engineering, user stories describe what the user wants the system to do, while acceptance criteria describe the conditions a specific user story must meet. Create basic acceptance criteria based on the given user story.

User story: As a user, I want to use a search field to type a city, name, or street, so that I could find matching hotel options.
Acceptance criteria: The search field accepts valid city names, names, and street names, if the user types them in English and Arabic, and if the user types exactly 11 characters in the search field.
Question: When a user types English characters in the search field, it must not accept Arabic characters? or the opposite?

Thanks.

Answer: I believe you're looking for "acceptance criteria based on the language of text".

Acceptance criteria based on language of text are "acceptance criteria intended to prevent automated software from misrepresenting itself to the user."

The example (courtesy of [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_testing#Acceptance_criteria)) is "If the acceptance tests cannot pass the system can be used only by humans and not by automated systems".

Answer: The given story is for searching a hotel which will be on a website and the hotel owner want to search with different languages as per the requirements. if a user wants to add an hotel he wants to search for hotel with different languages i.e.: English, Arabic, French, Hindi, etc.

Now the question is when user types different languages in the search field then it should take one of the languages and not accept the different languages because the user want to search with different languages and not to type all the languages in the search field.

Now, based on this story you can create your acceptance criteria that what type of languages should accept in the search field and what type of languages should not accept in the search field and how many characters should accept etc.

So here I found that acceptance criterion which the user wants is based on languages and not accept the different languages.

Hope, it will help to understand.

instruction:
Paraphrase the given text in an academic style.

Lots of papers have been published on this topic.
output:
Paraphrase the given text in an academic style.

Lots of papers have been published on this topic. What I have found, however, is that even the most rigorous papers do not address my question and that is not surprising because there is no direct way to answer it.

My question is:

Can one say something about the probability to correctly rephrase a sentence of the source?

Answer: There is a simple solution that seems obvious at first sight: get the \em{[latent] topic model} representation of the source document, and then get the \em{topic-matched} topic model representation of the target document. Use these representations to calculate the [mutual information](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutual_information) (with an [emission matrix](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emission_matrix))  of the two representations.

The problem I would anticipate is that you will not be able to use the \em{topic vectors} to get the probability of the words to appear in a sentence, as the word probability is determined by other context. One option would be to build a separate model that predicts the probabiliy of different positions (e.g. the [Hadamard product](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hadamard_product)) for the words of the source document, using the same parameters as the topic model.

Answer: There could be two answers:

\section{Potential approach}

You can use a very common technique in text mining of comparing the [term-frequency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tf%E2%80%93idf#Term_frequency) (TF) values of source document and its rephrasing document and the document that is the closest in term-frequency to the target document.

I think this approach only works if you have the original sentence in English. Otherwise, we are comparing the rephrasing document to a sentence that might have been translated. I don't know if the term-frequency value of a translated sentence and the source sentence are comparisons that the computer can make with any real accuracy. They could be meaningfully similar, maybe, if the sentences are quite similar in the first place? Probably even less so, if the sentences in the rephrasing documents are in different language.

Even with the original source document, I think that this approach is extremely low in probability if the target sentence is long. The term-frequency values just aren't that comparable for sentences that are 100 to 500 words long.

But still, from a programming perspective, this is the only potential approach I can think of.

Even though I said it is a low probability approach, it is probably slightly better than a random shot at guessing. The computer might actually do a passable job of comparing the terms in the source sentence to the term-frequencies in the target sentence. The computer can make comparisons of terms, rather than rewording the source sentence.

So, you might be able to use a sentence from the rephrased document and a sentence from the source document that is similar to the source sentence in order to find the probability that the target sentence would have also been rephrased in a similar manner. It is a low probability technique, but it could be the only way of approaching the target sentence that the computer has.

\section{Other potential approaches}

The rephrased document also contains the original source sentence, in context. If its a website, it will have the page that it is on, usually. If your goal is to simply compare word frequencies from a source sentence to the rephrased sentence, then you can do that and use those statistics to predict how closely the rephrasing sentence matches the source sentence, with probability.

You can also compare the entire rephrased sentences (or the entire source sentence - it doesn't really matter, as long as the source sentences are the same length) to the source sentence and use that data to predict which terms within the source sentence can be compared to the same term in the rephrasing sentence, and the relative distances that these terms are from each other (like how many words are between them), in which case we use statistical probability methods to predict which terms are likely to be rephrased (or not, as the case may be), with the same degree of confidence as the rephrasing sentence is determined.

\section{Possible pitfall}

This is a possible pitfall of this method of determining similarity between two sentences: if you rephrase a source sentence and the document text is a small number of words (e.g

instruction:
Make a list of the pros and cons of the given decision.

Implementing a Remote Working Policy

Include important study notes and key points that someone should know about the given subject.

history of the USA
output:
Include important study notes and key points that someone should know about the given subject.

history of the USA, World War II, etc.

Historical essays can make heavy demands on a reader's patience and tolerance in the early going.

When studying a subject such as history or economics, students are told to read extensively to gain a strong intellectual grasp of the subject. For these subjects, extensive reading (of many different books) is often required. A lot of information will be thrown at you and you will probably have to read it all to pass.

In some instances, history or economics can be "taught" through an essay. In other instances, a lot of reading is required to pass a history or economics course.

It is often said that reading a book is the best way to read. But for "extensive reading", the above types of texts might be studied. If so, reading one of the above types of texts will take a lot of patience. And it will take time, because a lot of reading will be required.

## Other examples of extended reading

Extended reading is often associated with the subject of history. For example, "extensive" reading of "World War Two" requires extensive reading of "World War Two", which would be rather a long text if well studied.

"Extensive reading" and "extended reading" are generally considered to be the same thing by most people, such as teachers, writers, and students.

Extensive reading and extended reading are commonly mentioned together in books and on the web.

Education specialists often mention extensive reading or extended reading or both of them in books or on the web.

Extensive reading often involves "reading several texts or books in a single subject (eg, World War Two, history, economics, etc.)".

Often, extensive reading is a method of study used to gain knowledge of a subject (eg, World War Two).

Extensive reading or extended reading is commonly associated with history and economics, among other subjects.

Many people are familiar with the concept of "extensive reading" or "extended reading" because it is commonly encountered in books and on the web. These people may, for example, encounter the term "extensive reading" while they are reading the web, or they may encounter the term "extensive reading" in a book that they have bought.

## Books

Books about extensive reading:

* The Lexical Approach
* Essential ELT Reading
* Reading for Understanding
* Receptive Skill Development

## See also

* Essential ELT Reading
* Language acquisition
* Reading (process)
* Reading (learning)
* Reading to learn
* Receptive skill development
* The Lexical Approach

instruction:
Provide an ESRB rating for the following game.

This is an action-adventure game in which players help Kratos and his son on a dangerous quest. Players explore various realms and engage in frenetic hand-to-hand combat against human-like raiders and fantastical creatures (e.g., centaurs, trolls, dragons). Players use axes and chained blades to battle enemies, often resulting in large blood-splatter effects and dismemberment. Players can perform finishing attacks that depict close-up impalement via bladed and hand-held weapons; repeated axe strikes to a creature's neck results in decapitation. The words ‚Äúf**k‚Äù and ‚Äúsh*t‚Äù are heard in the game.
output:
Provide an ESRB rating for the following game.

This is an action-adventure game in which players help Kratos and his son on a dangerous quest. Players explore various realms and engage in frenetic hand-to-hand combat against human-like raiders and fantastical creatures (e.g., centaurs, trolls, dragons). Players use axes and chained blades to battle enemies, often resulting in large blood-splatter effects and dismemberment. Players can perform finishing attacks that depict close-up impalement via bladed and hand-held weapons; repeated axe strikes to a creature's neck results in decapitation. The words ‚Äúf**k‚Äù and ‚Äúsh*t‚Äù are heard in the game.

### ESRB ratings controversy

The ESRB rating for God of War III drew some controversy. The content descriptors of "blood and gore" and "fantasy violence" drew some ire among media outlets. God of War III's cover features a decapitated head, and Kratos is decapitated at the end of the game. The game was rated "M for Mature" by the ESRB on March 11, 2010. "M" indicates that the game would be inappropriate for anyone under 17, and includes content descriptors for "Blood and Gore", "Licensed Music", and "Fantasy Violence".

## Development

Development began in August 2007 at Santa Monica Studio on God of War III, a continuation of the God of War and God of War II action-adventure games. God of War III introduces Kratos' son Atreus into the story and action, and offers players "a new adventure in their beloved God of War Universe".

After completing God of War II, Cory Barlog, creative director, had several ideas for a third game. It was Barlog who wanted to introduce Kratos' son, Atreus, and who pushed for the use of Blu-Ray technology. With the help of a team of about 150, he started to develop the story of the third game. Barlog said that they spent their time trying to "capture the soul of the first game, the magic of the second, and the excitement they'd be feeling for the third". When he was finished with the story, he gave the script to Sony, and asked them if they thought the story was believable. Their response was, "It wouldn't make any money." The script was then passed onto Sony Santa Monica Studio for the rest of production.

The next big challenge Barlog faced was to create the game world to match the expectations of the fans. Barlog said "I don't think we'd just go out and pump out something like we did with God of War II to get it out the door quick." God of War III features a brand new world to explore. They wanted to see many new ideas and wanted an innovative game world. The team knew they could no longer use Greek mythology and they needed to move on. "We looked at Norse mythology", said Barlog, "we looked at Eastern mythology, Samurai, Ninja. There are a ton of things like that that have magic elements; there are things like wizards and the undead, things like monsters. I felt like we needed something really new and fresh". It took the team about two years to develop the world of God of War III.

The design of God of War III would be very similar to that of God of War and God of War II. The design team spent the early years of design concentrating on the visual look of the game, and once this point was reached, it became very easy for the visuals to stay consistent throughout the game. Barlog said, "We have always wanted the ability to bring the visuals into a third-person game and make that experience as smooth as it possibly can be. But this time we wanted to push, we wanted to take that to an extreme and create a world that was beautiful and beautiful to play in at the same time." The world included a range of settings including forests, temples, tundra, villages, waterfalls, and wastes.

The team made sure that the characters remained true to who they really were. "I think that we have to maintain the personality traits and the visual designs of our characters and keep them consistent. We had this idea of doing this for Kratos and Atreus, and keeping them consistent, and keeping their movement on screen fluid."

Barlog

instruction:
A color description has been provided. Find the CSS code associated with that color.

A light red color with a medium light shade of pink
output:
A color description has been provided. Find the CSS code associated with that color.

A light red color with a medium light shade of pink. The color is lively and very springy. A fresh feeling from nature that gives you positive energy when you look at it!

This color, which is inspired by the tulips in 17th century Holland and the bright orangey-pink tulips with yellow edges sold now days. The color name is a mix of the two words and the pinky-orange-yellow. The color can be used for clothes, but also as a background color.

Hex: #EF8560

## History

Designed by Nimbus Design and first mentioned in Adobe Photoshop version 2.5 which was released in May 1998. According to Adobe, this color was the result of a "design team meeting that got a little rambunctious". Adobe's description reads:

Our design team was in the middle of a meeting when some of the members got a little hot and bothered. As you can imagine, things got a little lively. One of the designers took out some colored pens and pencils and started sketching a bright flower that just kept getting hotter ‚Äì so hot that it turned to fire!

The name of this color is not unique to Adobe, but can be found in other Adobe products, such as Illustrator, Adobe InDesign, Adobe Fireworks, Adobe GoLive, and Adobe Acrobat, as well as other products, such as Serif PagePlus. Microsoft Paint also has a Firecracker-esque color.

In 2016, Nimbus Design was acquired by Adobe and in May 2017 the color was retired by Adobe in favor of "Flamingo". Adobe also released the new color via press release. Nimbus Design founder Jared Tarbell said "the color‚Äôs name comes from a funny inside Adobe story, and we‚Äôll miss the color‚Äôs spirit being made available to everyone. But Adobe has done a great job in developing the color for use within their products, and we wanted to support their efforts."

## External links

* Nimbus Design Home Page.

Document Cameras allow teachers to display documents, books, or other materials for their students to see. These devices are a simple way to provide your entire class with an unimpeded view of your lessons while retaining an awareness of your students. By using the document camera with your laptop you can easily turn your classroom into a multimedia teaching space. The EON Document Camera brings you closer to your lesson by allowing you to have a greater ability to engage with your students. With its unique feature of the Equipped Light you can control the illumination on your documents from the ease of your laptop. By turning on the Equipped Light you can be assured that you are providing sufficient light for all of your students within your classroom. In addition the use of the Equipped Light also allows for the prevention of shadows from your classmates being cast on your documents. The EON Document Camera also allows for an easy access to the control buttons to use its powerful built-in zoom lens to gain closer focus on your documents.
Our Document Camera is compatible with all Windows-based computers, Macintosh and Linux systems. You can connect our product with a USB connector and get started immediately.

Answer: I think it is more a matter of a company looking at their product and saying "people have so far only used this to do blah, what if we put these extra features in and then we can get into bizarre markets".

It is true that some companies, due to the nature of their products, might never see a market that is bigger than itself.

E.g. You can buy, if you like, a digital camera for the purpose of putting your photos on a website. Or in a newspaper, etc.

But companies like Canon et al, sell lots of cameras to people who don't have websites or a newspaper. They buy their cameras as a family-album, to record family memories and to be proud to show to friends and relatives.

But let us return to the document camera. There is one company who seems to have found a bizarre market. [Google](http://books.google.ie/books/about/The_Google_Guide_for_Business.html?id=4x3pA3ZD8WQC).

Comment: But then again, I would say that document cameras have a broad enough market that it can serve a variety of purposes other than presenting information.

Answer: What has changed is how you can sell the product - most document cameras would have been sold as stand-alone devices, and then a very small number of people would also have bought software to enhance their use.

Microsoft made the decision to bundle this in with their operating system (which is used on 90% of desktop computers). They must have concluded that they would sell a \strong{lot} more software if they were able to bundle it in the Microsoft Office package that everyone is now using.

It is now Microsoft's job to sell this to people so \strong{they} make money - they bundle it with Office, they may bundle it with another package, or they may have a special deal with one vendor to offer one of these document cameras in a package with a bundle of Microsoft products.

There is, as I say, nothing special about this product - any company would sell it if they had one, and then they could have bundled it with a package of other software the customer would already be buying.

Hope that helps :-), John

You are given a tweet and you should decide whether it's offensive or not.

She has certainly taken some heat for being such an....well idiot.
output:
You are given a tweet and you should decide whether it's offensive or not.

She has certainly taken some heat for being such an....well idiot. I've heard from some who want her gone, but I'd rather have her just leave of her own accord (I understand if she's not). She has gotten really nasty this last week or so, and we all know it's got to have a lot to do with this last round of layoffs. I get that people are pissed off, but she's been pretty nasty to those of us who have tried for months to get answers from the company and still aren't getting them to this day.

I believe the post has been removed.. or I can get a copy of it.

Now, let's just put it all out there right now: What is your opinion? And please do not comment if you don't believe we should have this person as a moderator, simply because we don't agree with this issue at all!

What do you guys think? Have you noticed something different or similar about how you've been treated compared to others?

I'm just really confused by this whole thing... And I'm really really curious to know if anyone else is pissed off about all of this.

Comment: Why have this person moderate then?

Comment: We have to. She's been named the new moderator. We can try to "de-moderate" her of course..

Comment: And if there was any doubt about that.. she's deleted her Twitter account.

Comment: I'd say the question, rather than "is this person being unfair to users" to "why have they appointed this person to moderate when users might not be able to trust them".

Comment: @Andrew, that question is valid. I just felt it was important to get the user perspective of the question first.

Comment: "Should she be allowed to act as a moderator when people may or may not be able to trust her?" seems like a better title.

Comment: @Andrew, maybe it is. I'll let other people make that decision.. it's a valid point. :)

Answer: I actually work with the person in question and I've worked with her for years and while she does get on the soap box occasionally and uses foul language but she's never unfairly treated anyone. And she's not about to start now.

She can take flack, I give her plenty of it everyday - but when it actually gets to the point of being inauthentic and offensive, she will respond to that and take it up with people when it becomes appropriate. I'd hate to give someone the "silent treatment" because they stepped on my toes (for years!), but if for the wrong reasons, it will happen.

Bottom line - no one person is going to get a vote as to who gets a moderator role. They're the ones, collectively, that get to "vote" for a person to take a role within the community. My main person who I work with is in charge of community. He is the one that should get to tell you whether someone is actually a good person for that role or not. There have been so many times where he has said "I wouldn't touch that person with a 5 foot pole" and then the community comes to them with a big problem with that person. Then, again, they are in the same pickle. We're at a loss for what a person should and shouldn't do, and unfortunately, they do.

If the person who you would like to become a moderator is offending folks and is taking a bad position on this stuff, then it's time to make it known and I'll be right there by your side.

Answer: I'm going to jump from this question of yours to my experience with the recent changes regarding who gets to moderate and why. As you may already know, after a lengthy public debate we ended up with [Matt Mullenweg](http://www.matt.org/) as one of two mods. Matt is a fairly active member of [WordPress](http://wordpress.org) who has been working with the project since it's inception. I've had several conversations with Matt via e-mail. He's a straight-up kind of guy, and it's pretty obvious that he's all about improving this community. Matt also doesn't sugarcoat anything, and he's very direct with his feedback to the community.

instruction: For a quick and efficient office workout, suggest a short routine.
output:
For a quick and efficient office workout, suggest a short routine.
Use exercise bands to increase stability, strength, and agility for an office workout. Precision Nutrition Coaching Precision Nutrition Coaching Precision Nutrition Coaching has no official nutrition curriculum.
The goal is to get the heart rate up to a brisk walking pace. If a team member starts to lag behind, that person can be encouraged to pick up the pace again.
Lying down to work at your desk, not a great idea. A recent small Australian study indicated that workers with desks that allowed them to stand did not expend any more energy standing than sitting. The American Council on Exercise ACE recommends at least standing for every hour of work.
If standing is not possible, consider adjustable desks which allow you to easily shift between sitting and standing. These can be relatively expensive, so consider looking in thrift stores or on the Internet Craigslist ; some are even free. Some offices even have standing desks. The average person has more than 23 hours of leisure time each week, meaning if you manage it well, you can still maintain your fitness routine.
Workplace Fitness - Office Fitness
So instead of thinking about office fitness as a chore, think of office fitness as a way to take care of your health outside of work so you can reap the benefits at work, too. When you prioritize your fitness, exercise becomes a natural lifestyle part of you.
For example, you might schedule in 15 minutes of walking at lunchtime every day to get your heart rate up, or go early to your office so you can tackle the treadmill, bicycle or elliptical for a few minutes before the craziness of the work-day starts.
When you have to, exercise during your lunch break.
These days, employees are more and more conscious about leading healthier lives outside of work‚Äîand bringing that healthy state of mind into the office! Workplace wellness programs have become a common addition to corporate health plans. Fitness at Work One of the best ways to implement fitness into your work routine is to do so at work.
You might also consider working with a personal trainer, or joining a gym to get a workout you know you won't skip.
A personal trainer may create a workout plan specifically for you that can be done in the office. For example, you might only have time in the morning to hit the elliptical before work, and in the evenings to go for a brisk jog near your office.
An office gym is also a good option and will keep you working hard even when those cold or flu bugs start to circulate.
Office fitness tip: It's easy to forget to make time to exercise, so plan ahead and schedule in your fitness sessions. Also, keep a record of the exercises you do to remember which ones you enjoy and work best for you.
Better yet, plan a lunch-time exercise session with a co-worker. Your partner might want more support than you, which is why a personal trainer is a great choice and provides you with personalized workouts as well.
Many corporate gym memberships have some form of redemption policy, so exercise hard. The last thing you want is to lose the money you paid to join the gym.
A few hours of exercise won't be enough to meet your fitness goals, so a mix of a variety of exercise is best! For example, you might do an hour of cardio on a treadmill or exercise bike, a strength training workout during your lunch hour, and a 30-minute walk during your commute home or run up a few floors at the office.
Another good option is a personal trainer to help you develop an exercise program and get a great workout to reach your health and fitness goals!
The personal training team of Crescendo Fitness has extensive experience in fitness and personal training with a variety of programs to suit your needs.
In fact, working out at lunch or after work provides you with the perfect opportunity to get outside, enjoy the workday, and stay healthy.
The first step to getting more exercise in your day‚Äîand to making it a lifestyle part of you‚Äîis to break down exercise as part of your already busy day. The best way to do this is to find ways you can naturally be more physically active. This can mean standing more. Standing up for one minute is great. Sitting down for one minute is a great idea.
Being active throughout your workday is a lot easier

Predict how many stars the author will give to the restaurant from a Yelp review.

The reviews were great, but honestly i felt it was just ok. Seemed like a typical tourist spot were the food was mediocre. The service was ok, not great, but not the worst.
The bread was very good. I ordered the muscle fries. They had a sweet Vidalia onion flavor. No need for fries bc they were soggy wo much flavor. My boyfriend ordered a pesto chicken pasta and it was again mediocre.
output:
Predict how many stars the author will give to the restaurant from a Yelp review.

The reviews were great, but honestly i felt it was just ok. Seemed like a typical tourist spot were the food was mediocre. The service was ok, not great, but not the worst.
The bread was very good. I ordered the muscle fries. They had a sweet Vidalia onion flavor. No need for fries bc they were soggy wo much flavor. My boyfriend ordered a pesto chicken pasta and it was again mediocre. It was more dry than anything. The fry came with marinaded olives that were soggy as well. No other flavor and had no taste. I also ordered a lemonade and it was fine. I would order lemonade every once in a while but never a favorite. My boyfriend ordered a chocolate peanut butter milkshake. Again it was ok, more like a treat to go with the meal.

My boyfriend and I also ordered the crab cake fritters as a snack and again the bread was great. So was the crab cake. However, the fritter was too overdone and they tasted quite bland.

I like seafood, so i was happy about that.
The service was ok. We didn't want the food so we asked for a box and the server was able to retrieve one within seconds.

It was just me and my boyfriend. We just started dating at the time.

Sarah
\end{code}

Answer: You are initialising `predict`, which is presumably a 1 or 0, `True` or `False`, and then passing it into your `numpy.argmax` function. `numpy.argmax` takes a vector, not a scalar.

Instead, do this:

\begin{code}
predict = np.argmax(predictions, dim=1)
\end{code}

Answer: There are a few errors, namely
\begin{itemize}
\item you are initialising `predict`, which is presumably a 1 or 0, `True` or `False`, and then passing it into your `numpy.argmax` function.
\item I'm not sure what you gain by checking whether `predictions` is a list and not just assuming so, but that's another error. I'm not sure whether you were doing this in Python 3, or whether Python 2 would let you perform type analysis in a statement body, like the first error.
\end{itemize}

So, all you have to do to fix everything is `predict = np.argmax(predictions[dim])`. Note that you do not need `dim=1` -- it is just a special case of `argmax`, where `dim=1

\newpage
\section{A Word List}

Here you can write down as many words as you can think of the chosen word, the antonym and synonyms of the noun.

  *    \textbf{laureating}
  
  \textit{art} - antonym - \textbf{vandal} - artist - syn - mime - syn - mimic
  \textit{art} - antonym - \textbf{maestro} - svengali - artist - syn - mime - syn - mimic

The antonyms of "art" are listed first and then those of "svengali" (the choice of placement is your own). Note how antonyms are written, with the first letter capitalized and the second letter lower case.

Synonyms are words which have almost the same meaning as the noun and the verb.

The use of italics is for words, not for letters. Here, you should italicize "art," "maestro," and "svengali."

The spelled-out words at the end are for verbs. The second "m" is lower case because it is just a part of the verb; not the whole word, which you may wish to capitalize. You might wish to add "the artist" with or without "the" and "the" with or without "that."

If you wish, you may write more antonyms and more synonyms. The use of multiple antonyms and synonyms shows your understanding of words and of how they work.

\newpage
\section{A Word List}

Words for a noun can change their meaning depending on what other words are near them. For example, "dog" can be a verb (to dig) or also a noun (a hound), but never both. We know a lot about words because of prefixes, suffixes, roots, etc. For example, "nano" means "microscopic" and comes from the Greek "nanos" which means "little."

Here, you can write the antonym and synonyms of  \textbf{art},  \textbf{maestro}, and  \textbf{svengali}.

\newpage
\newpage
\subsection{An Antonym}

A word's antonym is another word which means exactly the opposite. A word's antonyms should always be written with the first word capitalized, like this:

\textbf{Antonyms} are words which mean exactly the opposite. You can write down any examples which you can think of the given word.

antonym   antonym   antonym   antonym   antonym

______________________________________

antonym   artist  

The word "artist" has two antonyms.

\subsection{Synonyms}

A word's synonyms are words which mean almost the same thing as the given word. Usually, it helps to define the word's meaning first. You can write down any examples which you can think of the given word together with other words.

We can help students understand new vocabulary when we:

* Define the word
* give it a context using the story
* give the word a visual
* practice spelling the word, using context and words in the book
* practice writing the word
* model the words with finger play/hand motions if appropriate

Read together, giving the student a chance to guess the meaning of words on their own or to clarify any misconceptions she may have.

I could read part of the story out loud and have the student follow along reading words independently. This allows the student to have a good visual of the story and the vocabulary words.

If the student does not understand a word and it seems like the teacher must keep going without checking for understanding, try having the student turn the page and read the word she was unsure of herself. If she didn't understand it or had misconceptions about the word, the teacher knows she needs to address it more when discussing it. (This would also be a good place to teach self monitor/self assess.)

If a student is reading the book independently, I would have him use the dictionary and read the glossary definition so he has a good enough idea of what the word means and can use it in conversations with others. If he didn't understand the actual concept of the word, I would make sure he understood the conceptual meaning of the context in the story.

I believe it's good to get started reading a book with students and have them stop where you know they really understand. This allows for the student to stay engaged in the story even when the teacher needs to check for understanding. Also if they don't understand a concept you can go back again or provide additional context as you move along.

Answer: There are many, many different ways to teach kids reading. So it's hard to provide specific advice for one person.

What I would suggest is to have a chat with your teacher about which are her preferred methods and then figure out which of these methods is best for you. If you have a chat, the teacher will understand what you are hoping to do and will be able to provide advice tailored specifically to you.

Answer: This depends on how your teacher defines an \em{academic vocabulary}, how you are comfortable learning and how quickly you need to become an independent reader.

I don't believe you need a full understanding of a word's meaning to start reading it. This could even be a challenge, considering you don't have prior knowledge on what is \em{academic vocabulary}.

On the other hand, I would argue against you being too relaxed and not taking your reading as seriously. The moment you do that, your teacher and your school system might get a little concerned. You might need to have a conversation with your teacher about the balance.

Answer: There are five types of words that are necessary when learning to read. These words are phonic (sounding) words, sight words, high frequency words, low frequency words, and "academic" or "complex" words. While some schools are quick to teach their students words in groups (i.e. phonic words, sight words, high frequency words), others go on to teach words by grouping them into types (sight words are taught and then later other types of words).

Knowing this will help a teacher decide the approach. For instance, if a teacher decides to teach all of the words by type, they would start at the beginning of the year with teaching all phonic words (sounding words). Next up would be all sight words. After all of the sounding words and all of the sight words, another approach would be to divide words into four groups, one group of phonic words, one group of sounding words, one group of high frequency words, and one group of low frequency words.

Then, the teacher would use a method of learning with his/her students. This method can be one of three methods, a phonic method (sounding words), a sight word method (any high frequency words), or a combination of the two. This would also take the word groups into account. The teaching method should take a teacher's background into account. The teaching method should take the student's background into account (i.e. what is known, prior knowledge, and skills). Lastly, the teaching method should take the goal for learning the words into account.
