Although this description has more than 1,000 words, including some unique information, it still only provides a brief description for a property, much less one that is nearly 3,000 square feet (279 m¬≤) in size. In particular, the owner of this particular property does not follow the standard conventions for providing Airbnb descriptions. Most properties do not offer the address or information about the location, and instead include the street address of the property in the description. The Airbnb owner also did not utilize the standard template for the "About this space" section, so instead of offering information about the space, property, and amenities specific to the unique offerings of the property such as outdoor activities, nearby attractions, amenities provided, etc., the owner just posted another lengthy description of the property such as the one that is posted above. The owner never refers to any of the particular aspects of the property that distinguish it from other properties on the market, so the description is more applicable to every other vacation rental than it is to The Chalet by the Ridge.

#### Airbnb-listed properties without a property page (2013)

On June 8, 2013, Airbnb announced 21 properties that they will list on the site and advertise on their social networks, without requiring the properties to create a listing page or even upload a picture of themselves. In the original announcement, it was explained that Airbnb will be showing advertisements to Facebook users for these Airbnb-listed properties, in addition to the Facebook users' existing lists of Facebook friends and their own Facebook pages. The properties were chosen by Airbnb as it believed that the properties will appeal to the Facebook users, and so will hopefully improve adoption rates of the social features of the site. 
Airbnb CEO Brian Chesky wrote in a blog post that the company is "thrilled to be featured in some of these [Facebook users'] top 10 feeds...This is exactly the type of impact we want to make. We are working hard to be the company people turn to when they are ready to travel by using and learning from our network. Now that we have built a robust platform, that gives a voice to both people who like to travel or share their own homes to travelers, it‚Äôs time to start building that community. We can‚Äôt do it without your help."

Although Airbnb has already launched multiple promotional plans, these latest developments were the company's first move to directly list properties in an official manner that does not require the homeowners to actually post their properties on the site. The Airbnb-listed properties will not take up a property slots on the home page, as they will be shown in the "Featured Homes" tab, which is separated from the "Featured Experiences" tab.

The 21 properties are also not yet required to pay listing fees to Airbnb, so the company will only be making a small amount of revenue from this advertising deal for a small portion of the properties on the site.

#### Listing page redesign

In a major design overhaul on July 30, 2014, Airbnb updated the appearance of listing page from its first page in 2009 by changing the background color, adding a sidebar to the right side of the listing page, and removing most of the content from the middle of the listing page that was previously there to accommodate an increasing number of listing, such as the date, price, and amenities sections, which had previously stretched across 3-4 lines.

Most notable changes are the appearance of the property background picture in the middle of the page, the "Contact Host" button, and the "Reviews" button that was redesigned to make all of the reviews that were previously scattered at the bottom of the listing page as a vertical list. instruction: What are the main differences between Python and JavaScript programming languages?
output: What are the main differences between Python and JavaScript programming languages? It all depends on the kind of application you want to create. For large-scale applications like games, web servers, and desktop apps, you should code in Java or Python; for smaller projects like blogs, web pages, or even simple web apps, you should code in JavaScript or Python. Both of them are object-oriented languages, and many JavaScript codes are converted to Python. It's worth mentioning that JavaScript is a better language for front-end developers, but Java and Python are better for back-end developers. What are the differences between JavaScript and Python? JavaScript and Python are two extremely popular programming languages. These languages are used for different purposes for two separate groups of developers; the front-end and the back- end developers. As most of the web applications are back-end, Java and Python are heavily used for developing back-end applications. However, most of the web applications are front-end so JavaScript is used much more extensively by front-end developers. However, JavaScript is a single-threaded language whereas Python is a multi-threaded language. Hence, Python has some edge over JavaScript in terms of performance. Python is an object-oriented language whereas JavaScript is an imperative language. However, JavaScript is more close to C language hence, it has most of the C syntax. There is a huge difference between Python and JavaScript in terms of readability. Readibility plays a significant role in any programming language. Python is relatively much more readable than JavaScript. Hence, developing a project in Python is much easy from programming view-point than developing in JavaScript. Also, Python is a more mature language than JavaScript, so there are various libraries provided for developing Python projects. JavaScript has only few built-in tools for developing projects. How do you compare Python vs JavaScript? Java can be used for developing desktop applications like Excel, word etc, as well as web applications and mobile applications. Java is an obect oriented language, like Python which is similar and can be used for back-end as well as front-end development. The syntax of Python and Java is also vry simillar. Both can be used for writing small applications as well as large application. Both are very powerful languages. I prefer to use Python, Java, C+ because I am more comfortable with them. But I am more familer with C#, because of the project that I am working in, I need to use it often. And with the same project I am also familiar with Java, because often we are required to create a mobile application, so both C# and Java are very important to me. Both languages are very good as far as the object oriented paradigm and powerful as well. Although its my opinion C has better syntax among all three of them, its not a very high-level language. I also prefer C++ in terms of speed, as it has better ability optimization for speed than C or Java. What if you're looking for the best data science certification? Try Simplilearn's Data Science Certification (44 Cours). What is the difference between Python and JavaScript? There are many programmers who know the Java and Python and are unable to distinguish which is better in which context. However, for developing applications, they choose Java and its library over Python or Python library. There are many programmers who are just interested in learning languages and don't have any specific applications to learn. There are many programmers who are interested in developing applications for mobiles than desktop systems, as well as interested in developing applications for internet browsers as well as games. Both languages, Python and Java, are popular languages used by programmers. Java is a popular choice for back- end developers who are developing large applications whereas Python is a popular choice for front-end for web pages and applications. These languages share a common code base and both are known for its simplicity and elegance. Also, it reduces the coding time which is important while developing a application in a limited time duration. Python is known as a very easy to learn and to understand language where a programmer can learn it in a short time duration. However, Java being much more complex than Python demands longer time to learn and understand the language. Java is known to have features which are not found in Python which are used less often. Hence, both Java and Python are used by programmers according to their applications. For developing desktop applications, games and mobile applications, it is preferable to use Java. For simpler web pages, web applications, or simpler applications which require only less coding, programmers in general prefer Python. However, some web application developers prefer to use Java as well in web projects. instruction: Can you explain the basics of quantum computing?
output:
Can you explain the basics of quantum computing? What makes a 200-qubit quantum computer special and how did you build yours? Can you explain how these special qubits are connected into the quantum computer? What does it mean when a Quantum Computer executes a Quantum Algorithm? How would it look in a practical scenario?

Answer: One of the main things you might be wondering is how these qubits fit into a computer; in other words, how a quantum computer program is loaded onto a classical computer. Generally, the simplest way to do this is to send an electronic mail from one classical computer to another, and hope that the message is correctly encoded to a stream of quantum qubits sent from the receiver to a quantum processor.

Most of the time, the sender actually writes a normal computer program; this has a normal computer algorithm, as though the computer was working exactly like a classical computer. In this program, the computer is directed to send the classical message to a second electronic mail account, which is really the address of the second classical computer. After a certain time, a process on the receiving computer detects that the message has arrived, and sends it down to a hardware box which actually runs the quantum computer. There are two different ways to store this message; the first is to send it down to memory chips on the computer which, like the memory on a desktop computer, act as a storage facility. The second, and much more powerful and convenient way, is to run it through a hardware device called a Quantum Data Bus. I won't explain more about that than what I have; it's somewhat complicated, and it's not exactly easy (or even possible, really) to see how a quantum computer works while actually running on a classical computer.

Now there's a slight technical point here, but it's actually probably the most important point, so in hopes of this thread living forever, I'm writing about it. Classical computers have a fixed number of memory chips (for example, 8GB on my computer), and after 8GB it's impossible to store any more information (no matter how big that information is). Quantum Computers, however, have an extremely large number of storage chips to work with; most commonly, a 200-qubit machine will have over 1600 storage chips dedicated to the qubits, and some machines have even more. However, if you can't store the message, then it will not be processed by the quantum computer. Therefore, quantum computers need a way to "store" a given amount of information so that it can be retrieved once the machine is ready to run. The solution to this problem is to use a quantum data bus.

A quantum data bus provides a large network of superconducting lines (similar to a phone line) which can be used to send the message. However, most computers don't have this kind of line in them; after all, a phone line has a fixed amount of information it can send (and receiving) over the line, and you don't need one for each computer. So this bus is actually controlled remotely, from the second machine; it has software which sets up the lines, sends messages over them, and disconnects them. By using this method, the second classical machine can send the message, and only uses a small line between the first computer and the data bus - most importantly, however, all of this happens outside of the machine.

As a final note, the most commonly requested use of a quantum computer is actually to send an e-mail. I know this is a surprisingly common task, but a lot of people want to send an e-mail to Bill, who is actually a lot farther away than he looks, and would like to send him an e-mail on the quantum computer. Now, the sending of the e-mail is a relatively simple matter, and it's easy to encode the e-mail message as one stream of qubits which are sent down to the second machine; actually, since a quantum message is sent as one stream of qubits, sending Bill an e-mail is really sending two: the e-mail and the message, "Would you like a message?", both of which will be encoded on the qubits in a single stream. (And a warning is in order for the second classical machine; since you're going to be sending a ton of bits and qubits to a machine which only has 512 or so quantum bits, you might want to test out the message with the "would you like a message?" test to see how much error your machine will make in processing it!)

The key to learning how to manage is to understand which skill you are working on. A good place to start is by reviewing and updating your. We will look at some best practices in leading and managing a high-performance team. Managers and supervisors need to know how to manage their time if they‚Äôre to stay on top of all that needs to get done, manage their people, handle all the paperwork, and still take care of their personal life ‚Äì all efficiently and productively.
If you‚Äôve got tasks to complete you, either as a standalone manager or as part of a team, you‚Äôve got to learn how to prioritise your work. The ability to prioritise your time and work is essential to being able to get everything done and do it well.
Sure, some things have to happen to ensure the business‚Äôs continued existence and profitability. But, some tasks are less pressing than others ‚Äì often, you can push them down your ‚Äòto do‚Äô list while working on those tasks that are more important. Managing a project is about managing resources ‚Äì specifically, the people who will be dedicated to making the project a success.
A good project manager knows how to get the best out of the people they lead. Effective project management calls for good people skills and time management skills. As a manager, you need to understand how to motivate your team, delegate tasks efficiently, and monitor their progress towards meeting project deadlines. And, of course, you‚Äôll need to be able to negotiate with other project managers, your customers, and even, your subordinates.
You may lead people who report to you, or you may not manage people at all. But, you will still need to manage tasks and projects, keep abreast of what‚Äôs going on throughout the organisation, and deal with the paperwork.
A good manager can manage effectively in the face of a tight deadline, unexpected problems, and sudden new demands ‚Äì and they can make good decisions about how to prioritise the work and tasks that need to be done.

instruction: What are the major challenges faced by the education sector today?
output: What are the major challenges faced by the education sector today? In 2012, UNESCO launched a new Education Strategy (2012-2021), with its slogan of ‚ÄúEquitable quality education and lifelong learning to empower all‚Äù. Its overarching goal is to support its Member States in meeting the education MDGs, with the ambition of creating learning communities across generations. It aims to: strengthen educational policies and systems; improve learning outcomes; promote equity and gender equality; and foster knowledge sharing and intercultural understanding. The Education Sector Strategic Plan 2013-2020 aims to achieve this by: increasing and improving opportunities to learn; addressing equity and access to education; improving the quality of learning; developing the capacity of the education sector for results; supporting and enhancing education management at all levels; and strengthening the education, scientific and cultural interchange. It is the fifth education Strategy adopted by UNESCO since 1948, and is designed to help the Organization to improve the achievements of the Education For All (EFA) movement since 2000. Over the last decade, UNESCO has worked with Member States to ensure that the EFA movement translates into concrete impact on basic education, in particular, in terms of access and increasing levels of learning. Education policies and systems have been strengthened nationally and internationally in a broad range of topics: from early childhood education to teacher education and special needs education; from school infrastructure to the design and implementation of educational monitoring systems; and from the professional development of teachers and managers to the integration of ICT. Recognising the need to promote equitable quality education and empower all to make informed decisions throughout their lives, UNESCO launched in 2012 the Global Action Programme on Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) to support its Member States and partners to reach UNESCO‚Äôs Education for All-related Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and Global Goals on Sustainable Development, including SDG 4, ‚ÄúEnsuring inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all‚Äù. It aims to: raise global awareness about the need for education to play a central role in sustainable development; promote national policies and global partnerships to mobilise resources towards education for sustainable development; support teachers, parents, students, educators, and local communities to promote education for sustainable development; and provide evidence and facilitate knowledge sharing on innovative and effective ways to promote education for sustainable development. It is the first action programme on education for sustainable development at global level involving all UNESCO Member States (about 192) and all international partners. The Global Action Programme (GAP) will be implemented over a period of four years (2013-2017). It will be based on three pillars and four strategic actions. UNESCO GAP will be implemented in four steps: ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ Initiative phase: Preparatory phase; GAP launching and first four years. Implementation phase: (2017-2021) Monitoring and evaluation phase: (2018-2022) Conclusion phase: (2020-2022). Source: UNESCO Global Action Programme on Education for Sustainable Development. UNESCO GAP will focus on achieving the following four strategic priorities: Developing knowledge, evidence and tools on education for sustainable development (ESD) and sharing best practices, innovations and challenges; Promoting integrated approaches and transformative education in order to mainstream education for sustainable development; Promoting global governance on education for sustainable development; and Reinforcing and strengthening capacity development at all levels to implement education for sustainable development. UNESCO GAP will focus in four specific strategies: Educator development; Education for sustainable development in formal education; Education for sustainable development in non-formal education; and Education for sustainable development as an issue of policy. UNESCO GAP will focus on the following global challenges: Increasing access to quality education and reducing the number of outof-school children, particularly those in vulnerable situations, including children; Gender equity in education, particularly in non-formal and technical education; Empowering education communities, in particular teachers, parents and students, to become active agents of changes; Ensuring the relevance of education for sustainable development; and Taking action to protect the environment and use natural resources sustainably. instruction: What are some potential implications of using a single-use plastic bottle versus a reusable bottle on both the environment and human health?
output:
What are some potential implications of using a single-use plastic bottle versus a reusable bottle on both the environment and human health? (3 pts) Potential Implications of Single-Use Plastics on the Environment It is extremely expensive to use a plastic bottle rather than a reusable one. The single-use plastic bottle is one of the most expensive of all single-use plastic items that we purchase. Because the plastic bottle is so expensive, many people do their part in helping to keep the environment clean by saving up their single-use plastic water bottles, refilling them when they need, and taking them back to the store. When you recycle a plastic water bottle and reuse that same water bottle to avoid the plastic, you are keeping that one piece of plastic from being thrown away. Plastic recycling is a bit easier than glass or metal recycling (which can be used in different ways) because plastic only needs to be melted down and processed before it becomes part of a new piece of plastic. The environmental impacts of using single-use plastic bottles could be significantly reduced if people used the appropriate type of bottle/containers and then properly disposed of or recycled these bottles when they weren t in use. In addition, if people were more conscientious in not dropping plastic items into the ocean and in not walking out of stores with bottles in hand, then this would have an even greater benefit in helping the 21
22 environment. This would be a good way for people to be more environmentally conscientious with a simple change in their habits by disposing of their plastic items properly. The environmental impacts of using single-use plastic bottles could be reduced significantly if people used the proper type of bottle/container and then properly disposed of or recycled these bottles once they weren t in use. In addition, if people were more conscientious in not dropping plastic items into the ocean and in not walking out of stores with bottles in hand, then this would have an even greater benefit in helping the environment. This would be a good way for people to be more environmentally conscientious with a simple change in their habits by disposing of their plastic items properly. Potential Implications of Single-Use Plastics on Human Health To begin with, plastic (and other environmental) sources have been associated with increased incidence of cancer, a variety of endocrine disruptors present in plastic leach into food, and hormone-disrupting chemicals in plastic toxics can cause problems with neurological development, including behavioral disorders (which can last through adulthood), reproductive health, and cardiovascular disease. In addition, plastics and other environmental sources have been associated with increased incidents of cancer, a variety of endocrine disruptors present in plastic (leach through the plastic) into food, and hormone-disrupting chemicals in plastic toxics can cause problems with neurological development, including behavioral disorders (which can last through adulthood), reproductive health and cardiovascular disease. It is also important to note that plastic itself is not the harmful chemical, but the plastic leached from food containers or plastic toxins that enter the food supply through meat and fish will make people sick. The health effects include changes in reproduction and development, immune function, endocrine or hormone function, and changes in the DNA, which can be passed on to future generations. The health effects that people have experienced who work in these factories also include problems with their skin, lungs, and nose, and in general this is a pretty dirty industry to be involved in (Finkel, 2007). The plastics industry spans a global range which includes North America, South America, Europe, and Asia/Pacific. The plastic and resin (which is made up of a portion of plastic) industry in North America has a total value of $43.9 billion in 2010 which accounted for more than 18% of the total plastic and resin product value. (Finkel, 2007) In 2008, Americans purchased more than 33.6 billion pounds of plastic of which more than 80% was recycled or reused. 185

How can a government utilize fiscal policy to combat the effects of inflation?
Fiscal policy is that which is used in an attempt to combat the effects of inflation while also balancing the budget. Inflation can be directly dealt with by cutting spending, increasing the money supply or a combination of both.
Cutting spending is typically recommended by economists, since increasing revenues can also be done, and there are no tax increases with spending cuts. If spending cuts are not done or if they do not prove sufficient, increased revenues can be introduced. Increased revenues could be achieved by raising taxes, so this is typically not recommended either. These types of policies are rarely used to counteract the effects of inflation since they are not beneficial for the majority of the population. A nation can implement a combination of spending cuts and tax increases in attempt to reduce the budget deficit.
These policies may not prove successful all of the time, and therefore, many economists now consider a nation in debt unfit‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ [Read More]

output:

16:58 Sharon Camp: These are just two of the important questions our workforce must be well versed in answering. The healthcare system and many of those who are involved with it are dependent on a workforce that understands what drives these patterns of infectious disease and how to better prepare in advance. This really is the frontier of modern infectious disease practice and research.
17:55 Sharon Camp: The frontier of infectious disease, and particularly infection control research, practice, and policy, is really the exploration and use of data. Data, big data, are changing everything. In fact, at least according to what researchers are saying, you may not be able to understand anything about infectious disease without understanding big data.
18:29 Sharon Camp: The challenges created by big data also force the public health to develop the skills necessary to explore and understand it. This requires public health not only to understand the nuances of the available data sources, but also to learn and create additional novel data sources. We need to understand how the data are produced-- and what those data may reveal-- and then we need the skills and the confidence to make use of that information and apply it in ways that benefit the public.
19:34 Sharon Camp: Understanding the challenges, and also the opportunities, inherent in the use of big data and in the integration of data and data-generating processes within the public health is a crucial skill, one that must be part of any workforce development efforts in the public health.
20:59 Sharon Camp: One of the reasons I believe so strongly in the concept of data-driven decision making in infectious disease, particularly now with the rapid and transformative changes on the horizon, is that it is the critical component that will allow public health to rise to an increasing degree of complexity and sophistication.
21:50 Sharon Camp: Infectious disease is already a highly complex area of expertise, and it's growing much more complex-- it's becoming bigger and more complex almost every day. As it does, we're going to need to make better and more informed decisions, and we're going to need to rely on data to do that. Data is what is going to provide us with the evidence and the information that are invaluable resources in order to navigate the complex challenges of the 21st-century environment.
22:40 Sharon Camp: I know public health is used to making choices. No public health is perfect, and no choice is always best. As we make choices and as we're confronted with difficult trade-offs, we're going to rely more and more on data. We need to be better equipped, individually and collectively, to use big data and to have the tools needed to understand its implications and to apply it appropriately to move us toward a better infectious environment.
Sharon Camp: Big Data and Infectious Diseases: A Public Health Opportunity
This talk will give an overview of the current and emerging uses of big data in order to better understand and address infectious diseases, and will discuss the public health policy implication.

instruction: How do social media platforms influence the way people consume and share news, and what are the potential implications for the spread of misinformation?
output: How do social media platforms influence the way people consume and share news, and what are the potential implications for the spread of misinformation? Is there any way to filter misinformation on social media platforms, and if so, how? How can social media platforms be most effectively used as a tool for journalism and news distribution? Is online news and journalism changing the way people consume and share news, and what are the implications for the spread of misinformation? These questions are being asked as media platforms adapt to change and attempt to create a more responsive model for news and journalism, in an effort to increase consumer engagement and to remain viable in a disrupted media landscape. The disruption began with the introduction and adoption of digital, mobile and social media platforms. Journalism and news were redefined and the internet became the new home for content. Journalism is experiencing a period of transformation, as it has been forced to adapt to a rapidly changing consumer and news media landscape. What was once defined by established standards has now become a much less structured landscape, redefined not by who owns the news media brand but by who controls audience engagement. Traditional media brands and platforms are in danger of becoming irrelevant to the next generation of consumers if they cannot meet the audience where they exist online. At the same time, it has become critically important for brands to understand what matters to consumers, as they are bombarded by information on a variety of platforms. Media and technology companies are exploring what it takes for brands to meet consumer expectations. According to Pew Research, more than 90% of all Americans ages 18-29 expect to receive content on their phones, tablets or computers. Nearly 60% of that same segment of consumers believe receiving content from brands that they follow on social media is very important , including Facebook. To that end, Pew Research has found that 65% of smartphone and tablet users say they look at news content several times per day, while another 20% report they look at such content several times per week. And they prefer to get their information delivered to them on their preferred devices. It is no longer enough to have a website, deliver content through apps , and reach social media followers with short posts that are designed to catch their attention and drive them to your site. Content and delivery must become more integrated and cohesive. Consumers want to be spoken to and they will be in new ways, and brands must develop their ability to deliver tailored experiences to their customers, as they go after markets and audiences across all platforms, with the ultimate goal being to influence a consumer s decisions about where to invest their free time, and what to purchase with that time. In short, media and technology brands are being forced to understand what matters to their audience, so that they can deliver highly engaging content that drives business and brand growth. This requires an understanding of what is being delivered on brand platforms across a variety of media and the platforms, as well as the ability to understand what is being said about those platforms and brands. AI and Machine Learning will play a critical role in helping brands meet consumer expectations and to more effectively deliver the data needed to make the most of their content and engagement efforts. These technologies, combined with data analytics, will help companies and brands gain actionable insight into their audience, helping them understand what matters to consumers and the best ways to deliver content, while helping them more effectively influence customer decisions. 3. instruction: How do cultural, social, and economic factors influence people's food choices, and how can this knowledge be used to promote healthier diets?
output:
How do cultural, social, and economic factors influence people's food choices, and how can this knowledge be used to promote healthier diets? The field of public health promotes healthier eating patterns and greater food security in various population groups. Food policies that influence affordability, access, consumer protection, and healthy food promotion are needed. How do cultural, social, and economic factors influence people's food choices, and how can public health use this knowledge to promote healthier diets? Public health practitioners working on food policy must take into account social and economic factors that can influence a population's food choices. Cultural factors - including foodways, ethnicity, religion, and gender - must also be examined. Food security, access to healthy foods, and economic factors may influence how food products are priced and how well they are promoted in supermarkets, convenience stores, and restaurants. Innovative food policy strategies have successfully promoted local food economies and improved healthy food access and pricing in inner city, rural, and farm communities across the country. This article discusses this work, as well as promising policy strategies to encourage healthier foods and increased food access. Public health practitioners can use the following principles and strategies to improve dietary intake and reduce health disparities: Promote and incentivize local food economies to increase the supply and lower the price of healthy food products. Incorporate health and nutrition standards and guidelines in all food policies and regulations. Promote food security for all through subsidized healthy food products and food insecurity intervention. Require food retailers and restaurants to sell healthy products on par with unhealthy products. Use food pricing programs, special buying opportunities, and nutrition promotion to increase consumption of healthier foods. Provide educational, economic, and food access opportunities for food retail workers and health professionals. Use local and traditional food systems strategies to promote food security and local food economies.
Learning Objectives: 1 Discuss the food environment of inner cities. 2 Discuss policy strategies to encourage healthier food access in urban communities. 3 Summarize approaches to improve the food environment in rural communities. 4 Describe local food economies and their health benefits, along with strategies to build these economies. 5 Discuss the use of innovative strategies to promote local food systems and improve food access.
Citation: Cohen DJ; Stedman R. 2015 Jan;34(1):19-24. doi: 10.1080/14703287.2015.999248.

instruction: How would you introduce yourself as a medieval knight at a royal banquet?
output:
How would you introduce yourself as a medieval knight at a royal banquet? As a member of the upper class, you would have been well educated and, therefore, able to speak at length, but you would have addressed your future bride as "Madam" even if you were related to her. Perhaps your lady friends would tease you about your choice of clothing: "Do you think that your shining coats of mail will impress your new bride?" Maybe you would joke "Madam, my coat of mail is made of pure gold!"
Your bride, of course, would introduce herself with something along the lines of "Madam, I come from a long line of warriors" or "I am a woman, unencumbered by weapons and armor." Then the conversation would begin in earnest. Perhaps you would discuss the recent wars that had taken place throughout Europe, or the political situation in your homeland. If there was a war brewing between two countries, this would be a subject you both would be deeply concerned about. Perhaps you would talk about what you have seen in the cities and countryside of your own lands, how different your people might be from one another in outward appearances, but sharing much in common in the basic desires of their hearts. Perhaps you would talk about your beliefs and your faith. When talking about faith, what did you believe in? What were the most common beliefs that you, of the upper class, shared that would have been common to almost everyone in Europe?

output:
Pretend to be a world-famous chef. How would you describe your signature dish to a panel of judges? I would tell them I would make my signature dish if it was something special for a celebrity and that I would make it in a big fancy kitchen, I would take the dish out on my big fancy coper pots and then I would throw wine at the judge if they didn't like it.
What do you think is the most over-rated food? I think the most over-rated food is sushi. All you think about is how much it costs. Is it really worth it?
What's your secret ingredient? My secret ingredient is candy. Everybody who eats my food would be like "I love this" and they would ask me what's in it and I would say "It's a secret".
Which celebrity's wedding should we be invited to? The wedding of Tom Cruise and Katie Holmes, so you can stare at Katie Holmes eating cake.
Your message to all those watching you on Saturday night would be... It's gonna be great. I'll give ya something that'll make ya lol.
Which celebrity's wedding should we be invited to? Sienna Miller because I think the dress and the hair is gonna be amazing.
What do you think is the most over-rated food? Cheese. It's everywhere.
What's your secret ingredient? A pinch of salt and a bit of seasoning.
Rod, 44
What food is your guilty pleasure: I feel quite guilty about this but I really like McDonalds.
Which of the other celebrities are most under-rated? I think Jodie Kidd is an under-rated celebrity because she is a really good rider and the same with Darren McMann.
What do you think is the most over-rated food? Marmite. I cannot eat that stuff.
What's your secret ingredient? Cutting the cake with a knife rather than a fork.
Davina, 34
Which of the other celebrities are most under-rated? Darren McMann. He's an under-rated chef.
What food is your guilty pleasure? There's one I can't stand but you know what it is, I actually like it but I hate it? Pork pie. I hate pies generally but I love pork pie.
What do you think is the most over-rated food? A mango. You know when you buy them, you have 15 minutes to eat it. You sit down the next day, open it and its a mushy mess.
Which celebrity's wedding would be the most fun? I'm very tempted to say Tom Cruise and Katie Holmes because I reckon it'll all be over before it even begins.
Your message to all those watching you on Saturday night would be... have a great time, have a laugh and have a good time and if you don't watch the food programme you'll be a very sad person indeed.
What is your guilty pleasure? Chewing gum- I think the last time I chewed gum was in 1991 but that is my guilty pleasure.
Which of the other celebrities are most under-rated? Jodie Kidd. She doesn't get the recognition she deserves for her horsemanship... if I tell you any more, I wouldn't give you an edge.

5 4 The International Letter The International Letter is a letter meant to be shared with people in other countries, especially people with whom you have no personal contact. In this letter, you will address someone in another country who is speaking in the same language you are. The International Letter is meant to be personal and friendly, so address your reader as a personal friend. Open your letter by writing Greetings, Friend. A sentence or two could easily fill the left side of the page. You should mention the country you are living in, perhaps include some information about the culture, geography, history and economy of the country, and mention some of the most important industries and cities, as well as the national language. Then you should write about your favorite sports, your recreation and hobbies, and even about some problems you have faced or a situation that you worry about, to help your friend feel that you are a real person. It is important that your letter be written as a true friend would write to another true friend. So, write a letter to a good friend across the world, imagining that you two have some of the same values, likes, dislikes, worries, etc. Include as many details as possible. Try not to get bogged down in formal language or long paragraphs. Write in your own words. A letter is meant to be friendly and conversational. Your letter should be polite, businesslike, and formal. Be sure to include your full name and complete address. Your letter should be neat or even handwritten, but not excessively so. The only real difference is that in The International Letter you are writing a letter to someone in another country and sharing your thoughts about yourself, your interests, etc. In the Personal Letter, you are actually writing letters back and forth to a personal friend who either currently lives in or is moving to, the same country where you are living. The first sentence or two on each page of the personal letter should include the name and address of the person you are writing to. The second sentence should include something personal about the person receiving the letter. The third sentence should repeat what is in the previous sentence, usually just adding another fact about the person (aside from their name and address), like, I am glad we will have time to be together when you are in your new home. S/he knows the correct words and terms because s/he has read those words in books/articles or heard the terms used at some social function but can't explain what those words really mean. This person is very likely the one who will ask the questions because s/he is not confident enough when speaking and so this "snooping" is a way to "feel" less insecure/embarrassed when speaking. 4. To understand this behavior it may be useful to see a psychologist. 5. There are some people who cannot admit that they may be lacking in knowledge. They will ask you to explain a situation, saying "You already know what I am talking about." So, if you agree they may think that they have an expert on the subject. 6. Also, some people ask you questions to get opinions from you. They want you to give them advice. It is important to not just say "YES" to all their questions, because in the future, they may ask you to help them on a project, and will be less likely to help you if they feel you did shoddy work. 7. instruction: Why might someone prefer to shop at a small, locally-owned business instead of a large chain store, even if the prices are higher?
output:
Why might someone prefer to shop at a small, locally-owned business instead of a large chain store, even if the prices are higher?
There's a psychological phenomenon called the "Halo Effect," in which we judge a person by how they look: physically attractive or well-dressed/groomed. You'll often find these folks get more and better jobs, receive more respect from other people, and get better service from vendors. So it goes with businesses, and in particular, restaurants.
When I first moved to New Orleans, I had to make a living in Houston. I hated Houston, and I really hated spending all that time at work (and all the money I had to spend there.) Since there were three other restaurants in Houston at the time, I started asking around to find out which restaurants the "Bigs" liked to eat at the most. It wasn't difficult for me to find out (since those people are so well known,) and I did manage to eat at some of the most difficult to get into spots around town.
I guess it's a "good problem" to have when you're trying to stay afloat in the crowded Houston restaurant scene, and if my business partner and I hadn't recognized this, we would have continued to struggle (although eventually, we did manage to make it work.) That's how we got our foot in the door at the "best of" Houston eateries, and we used that to build our business.
I'm a big believer in the power of the Halo Effect. I'm also a big believer in using it to your advantage in your business. It doesn't have to be "the best Halo Effect recipe in the world." Sometimes it can be "the best that you can do."
And in these times...that might just be the best you can do.
Labels: New Orleans Restaurant, New Orleans Restaurant Reviews, New Orleans Restaurants, NOLA Restaurants, Nola Restaurants

Never let anyone know that you are a true connoisseur of beignets.
No one ever wants a friend who has "been there, done that."
When you go to a New Orleans restaurant, always eat in the bar. There you won't get recognized, and you can enjoy the atmosphere. Even if you have to watch the World Cup.
Know the difference between a "bar" and a "restaurant" because there is a big difference in service style and product quality.
When you're working in a front-of-the-house restaurant job in New Orleans, it's all about the people. Even when you don't have to deal with any customers at all, you're still working with other staff members, and if they are unhappy, they may take it out on the guests. So be polite, be helpful, encourage people at every point in the employment cycle.
If you're not nice, people will find out, and you will probably be on your way out the door. And you know what? Your attitude will affect every member of the staff. So it's one of those "pay it forward" kinds of things. Smile, give people the benefit of your professional expertise, offer to help, listen, don't let them see that you're totally over this line of work they're hanging out over, be humble enough to tell people that you don't know something, and if you do know it, let them know that too.
If you'd rather not be a waiter, consider being a bar back. It can be even more challenging!
Never give away your opinions on how you think the restaurant business should run.
No matter what you think the restaurant business should run like, someone else has an opposite opinion.
And no matter what you think, someone will be doing the job in front of you

instruction: Why do some people enjoy the sensation of being scared, such as by watching horror movies or going on roller coasters, while others avoid these experiences?
output:
Why do some people enjoy the sensation of being scared, such as by watching horror movies or going on roller coasters, while others avoid these experiences? The latest study suggests a key difference in the physiology of brain regions which are involved in risk assessment, such as in the hypothalamus, as well as in the motivation centre and in the sensory systems. In the human brain, there appear to be two distinct pathways, one which is responsible for the enjoyment of fear, such as in roller coaster rides, and one which is associated with a fear response and which, in individuals who are most sensitive to adrenaline for example, reacts most strongly.
Ten people who responded strongly to adrenaline had their brain activity monitored in an fMRI brain scanner whilst watching several scary clips from The Exorcist and Alien vs Predator. The researchers then compared their physiological responses to the scary clips, by analysing the amount of adrenaline and heart rate in the participants. Individuals with a strong response to adrenaline showed a larger response in the right insular cortex in the brain, while those with a low adrenaline response showed more activity in an area in the back of the brain called the dorsal striatum.
The results show that the insular cortex and the dorsal striatum seem to play an important part in the enjoyment and response to scary stimuli in the brain, as well as in the risk assessment of the situation ‚Äì a risk response could activate the insular cortex and then be assessed further in the dorsal striatum. In conclusion, the brain seems to react differently to the enjoyment of fear than the physiological fear response.
Dr David Merrill, the author of the study, comments: "This is the first time we have been able to show using fMRI that there is a difference in brain activity when looking at an extremely scary film, such as The Exorcist. In fact, the differences show that it's not always the same areas of the brain that are involved in processing fear. In the case of people who are more sensitive - for example, to the smell of coffee - we see a different network of brain areas being involved in processing scary material‚Äù. Dr Merrill adds: ‚ÄúIt's also interesting to note that the parts of the brain that were more active, particularly the insular cortex, play an important role in making us aware of others and their activities. So, we may not even be aware that such a response is happening in our brains‚Äù.
The researchers now plan to find out whether adrenaline release is increased in participants who enjoy scary stimuli more.
Dr Merrill has further published a follow-up paper, "Identification of the neurobiological correlates of a sensitized neuroendocrine response to fearful stimuli in The Journal of Neuroscience: http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/abstract/28/2/352?maxts=28&sortspec=recent 1&view=long&V=S&maxts=28&sortspec=recent 1&view=long&V=S&sa=U&ved=0ahUKEwil8_KH6HTAhUPk4MKHQ-bC3EQkgUUgEwIY‚Äù.
The full study, entitled "The neural correlates of sensitization to fear films‚Äù from the Journal of Neuroscience, has recently been published online at: http://www.jneurosci.org/cgi/content/abstract/28/2/352?maxts=28&sortspec=recent1&view=long&V=S&sa=U&ved=0ahUKEwil8_KH6HTAhUPk4MKHQ-bC3EQkgUUgEwIY&enc=DE1aWFpbXQhcnRsO3ZhOGFpbnKaXhIUm1tZ2FvcmVwc2U9HUFW1eT3HJyXzE3M2VXaC1Tc0ZmRiT08uZHBoOGUwZjlSd2pXNUJhYXQrSUxUOUVKRjxBNElpTXRxMlJUeUhvWXRJek1QaG1OQTlOZ2JvcmJt

Bryant goes for a walk at Disney World. He wonders if a "The Good Life" will help him reach his goal of traveling to 9 new countries/year. Is this realistic? Also are there any limits to what you'll do to make life pleasurable? Join us!
#15 - What is F.U.M.L.U.S 0
What is F.U.M.L.U.S. That‚Äôs right, just this once we are not talking about Bryant‚Äôs favorite topic‚Äîf*#k you money. No, it‚Äôs F.U.M.L.U.S, which stands for Freedom of Ultimate Misery, and it is a question that the brilliant economist Hernando de Soto has been asking. Does the majority of the ‚Äúunbanked‚Äù population really want financial services? On today‚Äôs episode, we explore what F.U.M.L.U.S. It might mean for everyone. Join us!

Bryant asks how he should invest money if he is trying to save up for travel and have a happy life without worrying about money? Is it best to invest in a business that has potential to make money on its own? Or should I invest in something that is already making money? Bryant doesn't have a lot of money, but he wants it to work for him so he can keep traveling and live a great life without worrying about whether or not he has enough money. Join us!

We have all heard the saying that "Good Money" can buy you anything. Does that mean that "Good Money" can buy happiness? On this episode, we have an in-depth discussion on what "Good Money" is and what it isn't. We also get into how "Good Money" is different from "More Money", how to make "Good Money", and what to do when "Good Money" is the hardest money to make. Join us!

What role does work play in life overall? We want to work because we need to do work in order to live. We work for money to buy food, clothing, shelter, and transportation to and from work, as well as any other luxury we want. But should we be doing a job we hate, in order to do work we don't want to do? The reason we work at all is to help ourselves and help other people, but do we always have to put our family's and our own needs first, or are there situations where it would be better to sacrifice yourself for the greater good? We tackle this very important, life altering question in this episode. Join us!

instruction: In a world where automation is becoming increasingly prevalent, is it more important to prioritize job creation or technological progress?
output:
In a world where automation is becoming increasingly prevalent, is it more important to prioritize job creation or technological progress? It all depends on the circumstances. If you can‚Äôt create enough jobs, but you can improve living standards and create a skilled workforce by reducing unemployment, then you‚Äôd be better off focusing on technological progress. In the UK, the answer is clear. We can‚Äôt create enough new jobs, but we do have unemployment and an education system that needs to be improved. We need to create as many jobs as we can, in skilled sectors. How can we achieve this? The government has already made a good start by keeping corporation tax low, and by creating a business environment where entrepreneurship thrives. They should now look at what we can do to attract businesses to the UK‚Äînot to create new jobs, but to take over existing jobs, either in service industry or by offering manufacturing jobs at a cost advantage. By offering an attractive manufacturing cost environment, we should be able to attract more foreign direct investment. Foreign direct investment will then create more jobs in the UK, and indirectly help create more jobs by paying UK taxes and spending money here. We also need to improve productivity and skills in order to be able to attract new businesses. Both require a good education system. The focus of education must move away from a traditional three Rs, and towards developing work skills and employability, as well as teaching children to think. An example is the apprentice scheme, where people get vocational training. This has helped create and develop UK manufacturing, including many cuttingedge technologies. The challenge now is to do more and to develop more of this. The government should therefore have a strong focus on developing a worldclass apprenticeship scheme, and provide grants to industries to develop their skills. The government also needs to give employers greater flexibility over the apprenticeship scheme, so that it is flexible enough to serve the needs of individual companies. Over and above this, we need to improve the UK‚Äôs education system so that it is more focused on training children to think. This makes far more sense than doing more traditional teaching, especially if we are to focus on developing high‚Äìskill manufacturing jobs.
A.M. Gadgil

instruction: How many lightning strikes occur on Earth each day? Try to explain your answer. Your explanation should take the reader through your reasoning step-by-step.
output:
How many lightning strikes occur on Earth each day? Try to explain your answer. Your explanation should take the reader through your reasoning step-by-step. Lightning is an electrically charged discharge of atmospheric nitrogen occurring within 30 miles (50 kilometers) above ground, says the author of "Weather." That is the distance, as measured in a straight line, from the ground up to where lightning occurs. From this information, lightning strikes per day can be determined. Lightning strikes the ground about once per second, meaning there are about 60 lightning strikes per minute on Earth. Lightning strikes Earth approximately 10 times, each second on every minute, on every day throughout the year. Therefore there are about 60 x 10 = 600 lightning strikes every hour on Earth and about 24 x 600 = 14,400 lightning strikes on Earth every day. Since there is 24 x 14,400 seconds per day and lightning strikes occurring per second, there are about 24 x 14,400/60 lightning strikes on Earth per day. That equals to roughly 360,000 lightning strikes per day on Earth. An average lightning strike hits a land mass or an object on Earth. Lightning strikes that do not hit the ground, such as strikes in outer space, happen less than 1/3 of 1/1000 of the time. Therefore one lightning bolt occurring each second equals less than 5 lightning strikes per minute and less than 30 lightning strikes per day. Lightning does not happen every second on Earth. Therefore there are approximately 360,000 lightning strikes per day divided by 5 = 72,000 lightning strikes per minute and divided again equals to about 72 x 6 = 432 lightning strikes occurring each minute on Earth. One lightning bolt occurring approximately every second occurs 9,720 times per day, about 24 hours per day. Lightning happens once per second x 24 hours per day. A lightning strike occurs about every five seconds throughout the day. In other words, lightning strikes occur in five seconds x 24 hours x 30 minutes, approximately 1,920 times in 30 minutes. It occurs 9,720 x 30 minutes per day or about 1,204 lightning strikes per day. Lightning strikes occur 54,760 times per day which approximates to about 72,000 x 3.5 lightning strikes per day. The number of lightning strikes per hour occurring on Earth equals to 432 lightning strikes per minute and 72,000 lightning strikes per day. The number of lightning strikes per day divided by the number of lightning strikes per minute equals to about 72,000 divided 432 or about 166. The average number of lightning strikes, 166 per day. This equals to about 3725 lightning strikes per hour that occur on Earth.
The answer is 166 lightning strikes per hour.

instruction: How many snowflakes fall during a typical winter? Try to explain your answer. Your explanation should take the reader through your reasoning step-by-step.
output:
How many snowflakes fall during a typical winter? Try to explain your answer. Your explanation should take the reader through your reasoning step-by-step.
How many snowflakes will fall on earth during a typical winter? Try to explain your answer. Your explanation should take the reader a step-by-step.
This question is related to the previous one. However, it focuses on the distribution of snowflakes as a function of size. In particular, it asks whether the average diameter of snowflakes is about 0.008 inches.
The average ice crystal diameter in the atmosphere, including precipitation, is about 0.002 inches (Miyamoto et al., 1978). This number is based on the measurements of ice crystals in the Northern Hemisphere. The numbers from the Southern Hemisphere are lower, by about 40% (Miyamoto et al., 1984). However, the mean crystal size is less certain due to differences in the measurement method.
There is still some uncertainty regarding the actual measurement method. Most of the research focused on the observation of precipitation. However, they observed different sizes and numbers of crystals in one individual precipitation droplet which suggests that the measurements may be biased against large crystals (Miyamoto et al., 1984).
To estimate the average crystal size, scientists have to use some averaging technique. Different averaging techniques will result in different average sizes.
The first method that scientists have used is a counting method that was based on the number of counts of flakes on a sheet of paper. However, such a method would include the measurement of the flakes that are too small for human eyes to see. Thus, it is unlikely to be accurate due to the possible bias on the large crystals (Miyamoto et al., 1978). However, a counting method has its own advantages as it is unbiased against large crystals.
The second method is to count the frequency of different sizes of crystals in one individual precipitation droplet (Miyamoto et al, 1978). The average diameter of individual crystals was found to be about 0.002 inches (Miyamoto et al., 1978).
The third method is to find the most common size of the snowflake that is visible. In other words, if 70% of the snowflakes visible and 2% of the snowflakes are 0.008 inches, then the average snowflake size is found to be 0.008 inches. A research showed that the most common visible snowflakes are about 0.008 inches (Thober et al., 1978).
The fourth method and another method used to estimate the average size of snowflakes in a typical winter is to use the modeling data in relation to the airborne dust particles. In addition, the model has also indicated an expected size of an individual snowflake based on the visibility of snowflakes by humans (Thober et al., 1978). The number of snowflakes that can be seen and a typical human eye view of snowflakes.
After considering all of these studies, the scientists have concluded that all of the models have been able to explain the distribution of snowflakes as a function of size (Thober et al., 1978). In addition, it appears that the average size of a snowflake in the atmosphere is roughly 0.002 inches.
How much melting would take place during a typical winter if all of the 0.002-inch snowflakes melted instantly? The answer seems easy because you can calculate the area of one layer of snowflakes by multiplying the area by the average diameter of the snowflakes. You can estimate that all of the layers in a typical snowfall would form a layered slab of snow on the top of the atmosphere.
How many layers are there in one typical snowfall? Assume that the layer of snow gets thicker as the snowflakes melt. You can easily calculate the average thickness of the slab by multiplying 0.002 inches and the number of individual snowflakes (0.002 inches * 2000 snowflakes * Layer thickness).

instruction: What if the Aztecs had successfully repelled the Spanish conquistadors?
output:
What if the Aztecs had successfully repelled the Spanish conquistadors? What would Central America look like today? Could an alternate colonial Central America have evolved into a major player in the modern world? This is the question that this thoughtful, well-researched novel tries to answer. The result reads somewhat like a detective story, as the adventurer/researcher is chased from one exotic land to another in search of his lost love. The setting is richly described, and the backdrop of colonial Central America is colorfully detailed. In spite of this, the story falls a bit short of the mark set by the premise. Unfortunately, what's left is a bit on the dull side. This may be the novel's intent: to present a grim picture of what is inevitable, and inevitably boring, in the wake of a complete revolutionary upheaval of a country's society. It is well done, and interesting to read, but not something I'd be desperate to read again.
This is very interesting history, and how Central America could be.
I bought this book because I wanted to read more about Central American History. I don't have a strong interest in politics, but I love reading and learning about other cultures. This book is about what could have happened if the Inca's in the Andes region were not crushed and Spain were defeated in the Caribbean. What makes it interesting is what happened in Central America after these events, and the characters that get involved. I won't give away too many details, but I really enjoy this novel. It gives you the sense of being a part of it, and not a casual observer. I would recommend this book to anyone who enjoys history!

instruction: What if Alan Turing had not cracked the Enigma code during World War II?
output:
What if Alan Turing had not cracked the Enigma code during World War II? If Turing had been caught or failed at cracking the code, or even had a different view of the importance of cryptology, then the outcome for the Allied war effort could have had dramatic consequences.
One possible outcome could have seen an Allied victory which took far longer to achieve. It's possible World War II may have continued for several years or longer, and ultimately result in a world devastated not just by the effects of World War II, but also the nuclear bomb, which may have been unleashed at an earlier date when it could have had the greatest immediate impact.
The world today is a very different place than what it would have been had Turing not contributed to breaking the Enigma Code. For one thing, the cold war probably wouldn't have happened. Possibly Britain would have been the Soviet Union instead of the United States. Possibly the United States wouldn't exist. Possibly all of our technology wouldn't exist. Possibly humans wouldn't have even come into existence. Possibly everything would be just like it is in the TV show Battlestar Gallactica. Imagine that! If Alan Turing hadn't solved the Enigma code, and if the Soviets had taken complete control of Europe, then you would never be reading this right now, and neither would I, and neither would anyone else. If you had never been born, this website would not exist, and Alan Turing would definitely never have won a Nobel Peace Prize and be famous as one of the greatest thinkers in all of human history.
If Alan Turing had not succeeded, then the technology we know today would be impossible. Our world would be run by governments (if we had them at all), and we would have much lower levels of technology than we have now. In fact, we don't know how much better our technologies are in our world than the other world, because in one world, nothing is technological. And in the other world, everything is technological.
I'm sure you now realize how important Alan Turing's work was with cryptography. His methods and ideas inspired other mathematicians and people like Leonardo da Vinci, Sir Francis Bacon, John Napier, Charles Babbage, Thomas Alva Edison, and the ancient Greeks and Romans. If one person had not contributed to this field of work, then it wouldn't be where it is today.
What if there weren't any mathematicians in Turing's time?
First, we wouldn't have computers built based on the design of computers invented in Alan Turing's time. Also, there would be no Turing machines and no Turing tests, so there wouldn't be artificial intelligence. This would mean we wouldn't have chess playing computers, robots, artificial limbs, or probably any other new technologies. So many of today's great, life-changing inventions such as the Apple iPhone, the touch screen technologies which allow it to be so easy to operate, the Internet in general, and most of the computer science fields such as web design, computer graphics, and a whole bunch of others are invented by people who are inspired by the work of Alan Turing.
What if there hadn't been any mathematicians in Turing's time? Then there wouldn't be anything else which inspired a whole bunch of other things which we take for granted and can't imagine ever living without.
Alan Turing's life was so unfortunate and tragic, and it's impossible to imagine how life would be different today without him.
One thing for sure is that the work of Alan Turing wouldn't have been possible without the work of other mathematicians in his time.
Born: June 23, 1912 | Died: June 7, 1954
Leading Ideas:
1. Turing defined an algorithm as "A sequence of precise instructions which is intended to bring about a predestined goal state."
2. Turing developed the concept of the "Computer" which is one of the most important ideas anyone has ever thought of. It's also pretty cool that Turing is responsible for defining the concept of a "machine" as something that can perform tasks and have a program run on it, as opposed to something with no program, like a robot.
3. Turing invented the Turing Test. (A Turing machine is a programmable machine which has functions (instructions it can do) which can be coded in a list of instructions. A Turing Test is an artificial intelligence test where it's trying to determine if a machine has an intelligence equivalent to that of a human being or

Suez Canal Essay
...12/13/13 Canals The Suez Canal was built in 1869, and was a major shipping lane in the eastern Mediterranean. The only possible way to get across from east to west and vice versa, without having to go all the way south. This lane provided an incredibly efficient transport between Europe and Southeast Asia, saving about three thousand nautical miles of travel time. A canal allows water transportation which would not otherwise be possible, and thus allows the movement of large quantities of cargo using a smaller amount of transportation infrastructure. In the case of the Suez Canal, it allowed the connection of the Red Sea to the Mediterranean for shipping. The canal was originally constructed by the French in 1869 to link their military base in Egypt's Canal Zone with ports on the Red Sea and in the Indian Ocean. It was later rebuilt and operated by the British. The canal was closed and operated by the Egyptian government from 1956 to 1975; it was open for 9 1/2 years of that period. The Suez Canal was reopened in 1976. The canal was closed again by Egypt in the aftermath of the Six-Day War, reopening in 1975.
