instruction: What if the Maya civilization had never mysteriously collapsed?
output: What if the Maya civilization had never mysteriously collapsed? Would we now know more about the secret of their success? And what difference would it make to us, even if we did? These were the conundrums that faced Paul Thompson and Christopher Rempfer, both anthropologists and maya experts at the University of California at Riverside, when in the early 1990s they began to develop a project that evolved into the National Geographic Bee. The purpose of the Bee was to give students the opportunity to explore one of the worlds greatest civilizations in the context of one of earths greatest science and geography competitions. In the Bee, the student population of one of the worlds great civilizations is presented with a series of questions based upon Mayan history, language, location, and culture. These questions provide the students with an opportunity to not only learn, but also experience some of the ways in which the Maya accomplished one of the greatest intellectual and technological achievements in world history more than thirteen hundred years ago. Mayan civilization originated in the southern Yucatan Peninsula in about 800 B.C.E. and reached its greatest development between 800 C.E. and C.E. 900 the Classic Period. During this time, Mayan civilization flourished in hundreds of cities throughout the Yucatan, Guatemala, and eastern Mexico. The Maya built monumental structures including a wide variety of temples, many of which were devoted specifically to the worship of the gods. Their most famous monuments, however, were their stunningly detailed and elaborate stone monuments or carvings of Mayan gods. The Maya also built monumental structures, many dedicated to the worship of gods. (1) In addition to their famous stone carvings of gods or deities, they built magnificent temples, both monumental and small. These temples were decorated with exquisite sculptures, paintings, and detailed hieroglyphic inscriptions. Although many of these were later destroyed by Spanish explorers, archaeologists have been able to identify examples of each of these Mayan art forms and to decipher at least a part of the languages in which many of their hieroglyphic inscriptions are written. Although their monumental works were primarily created for religious purposes, they also served the secular function of creating and maintaining political order and stability in Mayan society. A third major feature of the culture was the Mayans sophisticated calendar system. While it still remains the subject of great academic curiosity, the calendar system that Mayan society employed was far more accurate than that employed by many of the civilizations that followed it the Egyptians and Romans. The most important function of this calendar system, however, was that Maya society employed a system of dating by which it could both record and predict important events and occasions in its social and religious life. (2) According to Paul Thompson, one of the co-founders of the National Geographic Bee, Mayan civilization represents one of the greatest intellectual and technological achievements of any society in world history: (3) The greatest achievement of any people who have ever lived from one point of view is Mayan civilization with its extraordinary astronomical calendars and its extraordinary building technology. And to this day with every new discovery more is learned about how their buildings were constructed. The Maya had very advanced techniques of building and extremely sophisticated calendars, and so perhaps, all by themselves, without any outside influence, they developed a very sophisticated culture. A second significant contribution made by the Bee is in providing a means of promoting awareness of the achievements of the greatest intellects, including Mayan, throughout the history and development of humankind. The first of the National Geographic Bees, which took place in 1991 with students from thirteen states and the District of Columbia were held, the finalists were asked to identify famous leaders of different civilizations throughout world history the Egyptians, the Romans, the Chinese, and the Maya. For the thirteen students who advanced, answering these questions proved to be a challenge. Even after the event was over, student winner Cynthia Guenther of Washington stated the importance of the experience she had just had: I m glad I was able to have the experience of competing because I think it s really important to know history and the role that different civilizations have played. I know that the people who came before me have played a part in who I am today. And if I m able to play a part in who some-one else is down the road, then I will feel gratified. In explaining the significance of the history of which the students were being taught, John Fle

instruction: What if Christopher Columbus had not discovered the Americas?
output:
What if Christopher Columbus had not discovered the Americas? There is no way of knowing where worldwide economic activities would be if it had not happened. Some experts believe that the world was already involved in a global economy. In the early 1900's, the Americas had the highest production of manufacturing goods of all nations. In 1901 they produced 8.5 billion dollars; the next highest nation was Germany producing 4.5 billion dollars. This was mainly because the U.S. had the best technology of the time, and was able to produce more items with an even lower price. There is no exact way of telling what the effects of worldwide trade was before the time of Columbus. However today, world trade is estimated at $ 17 trillion dollars in 2007 at it's lowest rate while the United States economy is around 15.7 trillion. Columbus made possible an economically free world. If the world was not involved at that time in an open global economy or the world was still a feudalistic society and was less tolerant of the individual it could have been a lot different. Even the most ardent critics would admit that the world would be a much greater place with global trade and exchange in which individuals are free to choose the pursuits of their lives. Another theory is that before Columbus discovered the Americas, he found the Aztec, Mayan, and Inca civilizations with their magnificent architecture, pyramids, and fine craftsmanship. Archaeologists have found that before the arrival of Columbus, these civilizations had a highly developed system of commerce, mathematics, and science. In 1492, Christopher Columbus found the New World (the Americas) while trying to find a shorter, more direct route to the East and India. When Columbus landed on what is now believed to be Haiti, he found the people living in peace, being ruled by a king named Anacaona. The first Native American to meet Christopher Columbus was a Taino, whom Columbus named "Guat" (today spelled Guata). He quickly befriended and traded with the Taino tribe. Another thing that Columbus did find in the New World was gold. He thought that he had found India, and was hoping to find great gold treasure. He found that gold wasn't a problem to find, which excited him even more. He had found the New World, not just the old world. He had found a rich society that would become the main source of wealth for many colonists afterwards. As history shows us, there were many repercussions on the discovery of the Americas. The main negative effect was on the lives of the Native Americans who had no idea what was about to happen to them. They were used and treated poorly as they were seen as less than people. With the coming of European colonists, there was a conflict with the natives which ended up leading to the extinction of many tribes, and the destruction of many civilizations such as the Aztec, Mayan, and Inca. Another large negative effect was the lack of attention to the environment. The population boom which followed the discovery of the New World, brought about deforestation, land use changes, and the resulting environmental damage which included massive species extinction. Also there were many large effects from the discovery of the new world. One being a new source of treasure; gold and jewels....
Discovery of the New World Essay
...The discovery of the New World. The discovery of the New World and the consequent voyages of discovering further, is one of the greatest moments in our world‚Äôs history, as it was of enormous importance to modern era, especially to the worldview and to the science of the 16th century. And even though Christopher Columbus is known by many to be the first person to discover the New World, but this is no real proof to be correct, as many other countries and sailors claimed to be first to find the New World, making their voyage in the 16th century or even later. One important aspect of discovering the New World is that even though many people may argue about the date, in which the New World was found, this fact still remained unchanged for all ages, that it was found. Before the discovery of the New World, many nations of Europe were in an expansion, and they were looking for new lands of wealth and of which would be an asset and a help in their future success. The main reason for this expansion is because of the Renaissance period of which gave birth to many new inventions and discoveries which improved our world‚Äôs knowledge and awareness, and the expansion of Europe into the new lands was mostly done thanks to those inventions which improved the transport

instruction: What if Vincent van Gogh had been a successful artist during his lifetime?
output:
What if Vincent van Gogh had been a successful artist during his lifetime? What if he hadn‚Äôt cut off the lower part of his ear? What if he hadn‚Äôt painted ‚ÄúCaf√© Terrace at Night‚Äù? He went into the caf√© to see what the painter was going to do with the colors, the shapes, the lines, the values. Everyone knew the place, and it was a common gathering spot for artists. He wanted to find out‚Ä¶ So what would his success have looked like? Would the gallery that sold his work have been filled with collectors? Or, would people only go because it was the new thing and try to understand what he was doing? Would art historians study it? Or would the curator of the museum just ask, ‚ÄúIs he good?‚Äù Would the art be praised or ridiculed? Maybe it would be popular. Maybe it would just be there, collecting dust‚Ä¶ We‚Äôll never know‚Ä¶ But, imagine if we had seen his first work, his last work. His early work, where it could have easily been rejected, would be something‚Ä¶ Or his later, where he only cared about doing what he wanted without a worry about the rest of the world‚Ä¶ Imagine how different things could be. ‚ÄúWhat if, is a book, written by the Dutch author, Gerard van de Esch. Its aim is to imagine, what if events happened, in other moments of time. This, is the first in the series for Vincent van Gogh. It is a short read, and a brilliant one at that! Gerard van de Esch, does a brilliant job of portraying, what it could have been, if a different event took place‚Ä¶ What if, Vincent van Gogh had been a successful artist during his lifetime? What if he hadn‚Äôt cut off the lower part of his ear? What if he hadn‚Äôt painted ‚ÄúCaf√© Terrace at Night‚Äù? What if, he had painted ‚ÄúStarry Nights, 2‚Äù? There are a good number of questions, the reader asks. It is not a book that will necessarily be remembered for a long amount of time, but for the short time that one is reading it! A brilliant book, for a brilliant author! Enjoy it! üôÇ

The reason why the saline-saturated groundwater is coming up is actually the "wetness" of the ground. The ground is essentially the water table, so as you remove more water from underground, the place is left more dried up. The water from the water table is not just pure water and has natural chemicals like salts and other minerals in it. This groundwater is already there in the form of liquid water, so its only evaporation that causes a higher concentration of dissolved solids. You won't get something like that from the fresh water you get by tapping a natural spring, where the water coming out is almost pure, or at least has no salts. So this is probably the result of over extraction. The chemical concentration of the stuff that's going up, might simply be the result that these natural chemicals are dissolved in most of the water, and the water coming to the surface now can no longer hold these chemicals in solution. The concentration of dissolved solids comes from this, and a lower water saturation. But I really can't tell more, since its not so much my field of expertise.

In this time, I have developed close ties with ______________. He is one of the top students in my class. He has always done exceptionally well on all computer science exams and in all of his programming assignments. His academic record from 19__ _ to 20__ _ was exemplary. His research efforts have been outstanding. He even organized, developed, and supervised a special project this Fall to automate the accounting systems for the university computer center. ______________ has excellent communication skills; he is a charismatic leader. His ability to motivate others is exceptional. His problem-solving skills are superb. His project management skills have been refined this semester as he planned and directed a computer science project. His ability to work as a team player and as a member of a community (of computer science students) is a strength. I would like to bring the following to ______________‚Äôs attention: o o o He is a team member who works hard, has good ideas, and can be counted on to lead a team by present leadership and example. 27 Case Study: Delivering Customer Satisfaction Delivering Customer Satisfaction is a 1-hour training module and was developed to assist employees involved in customer service to gain an understanding of customer expectations and the importance of managing customer relationships to gain customer satisfaction. It also provides practical advice on how to deliver outstanding customer service. A 30- minute training module which will provide employees who deal with customers with an understanding of the customer journey and how customers experience and measure service. The customer journey is made up of 5 stages: Recognition: at this stage customers recognise the company or organisation. The company or organisation has therefore already started to work on their customer image. Interest: At this stage customers consider the company or organisation on both professional and social terms. At Interest customers are also looking at whether they can do business with the company. Service: At this stage customers interact with the company or organisation to either find out what they have to offer or to buy a product or service. At Service, customers are looking for a quick response or resolution which helps them to make their decision to deal with the company. Sustaining: At this stage customers keep dealing with the company because the company is fulfilling their needs in a consistent way. This is where the relationship between the customer and the company or organisation starts to become developed. Loyalty: At this stage customers are committed to dealing with the company in preference to the competition. The module includes a quiz (or a questionnaire) at the end of each module. This should be completed by any employee dealing with customers whether at face-face, or over the phone. Once completed by all employees, the module manager can produce a summary report showing the percentages of correct responses given by each level of employees (e.g. Managers, Supervisors, Team Leaders). The module manager can then use this as a training plan. Incorporating the training modules is easy as they do not require specific planning. They can be delivered as and when needed. The customer service assessment (or questionnaire) can incorporate information from the customer-service plan. This is an effective way of measuring the performance on the customer journey, or any customer specific objectives. Page 26

instruction: Write a symphony concert review, discussing the orchestra's performance and overall audience experience.
output:
Write a symphony concert review, discussing the orchestra's performance and overall audience experience. You are not writing this as a critique, but as a concert fan. As such, you might want to focus on what was engaging, fun, and funny rather than dwelling on what didn't work. However you structure the review, know that the review is one more way to make the review accessible, and to help others see that the concert, no matter what it was, was worth your time and money.
It's not enough to just write down an outline for everything you'd like to do one day. Take a look at that list. Do any of those things have a deadline? Be honest with yourself: If you don't achieve a particular goal within a certain time, would you take that goal off your list?
If you answered yes, then you have to say, honestly, that you have to get these things done and that you will be accountable for doing them by a given deadline. If there is no way you know now that you'll be able to finish your book within a five-year period, then you need to be writing down the short-term goals that will help you write that book. It's OK to be impatient: You are a human being, and you're entitled to want to see your goals happen within the time you thought they would. But take a step back. You have to take care of your most urgent and long-term things, and not try to do it all at once. It's just not feasible. So look at your list. If a goal doesn't have a deadline, get a deadline. If it has a deadline, then mark your calendar with dates for reaching those goals.
When do you create deadlines? It's a great idea to create "mini‚Äìdeadlines" as you go along. These mini‚Äìdeadlines force you to consider your goals every day. And if you don't "succeed" at the goal that day, maybe in the long run that's a good thing. Sometimes success requires you to acknowledge that you failed that day and to try to find a way to succeed the next day, and then the next day. That's how you'll get closer to achieving your goals.
It's also a good idea to take a step back every few months to take stock of where you are and where you could be. Take five minutes every two weeks to write down your goals and where you are with them. If you've accomplished one thing, congratulate yourself. If you haven't, come up with creative solutions to keep moving forward.
Once you have a few mini‚Äìdeadlines that might help you accomplish an overarching goal on your long-term list, start working from the top down. Start with those three- to six-month deadlines. You can probably knock that part of your long-term list out in a month or two or within a few months of the deadline if you're really motivated and work from eight to eight and don't waste any time.
By this time, it's probably pretty clear to you which of your goals are the most important to you. You'll probably even start to see trends coming into play. Maybe you want to get a book published. But what kinds of books do you want to write? Do you want to publish e-books and reach a huge global audience? If so, you need to start thinking about the digital publishing world. How are you going to create content, where is that content going to live, how will you keep track of it all, and what social media tools do you need to reach readers?
Are you actually going to publish a physical book, and the success of which has a lot to do with where you're going to publish it, who's going to distribute it, how you're going to promote it, what will you charge for it, and how will you sell it?
Maybe you want to write a magazine article. It's a good idea to start considering journalism school as a possible next step because it teaches you how to get your work into print, how to write well in general, and how to understand the mechanics of being a writer. But maybe you decided in the next year that you want to start a magazine for people in an industry that you have expertise in.
Maybe what you want to do is start a blog with other people. What kind of blog? What will you contribute in the way of content? Will you share and repost others' blog content, or will you write your own stuff?
Maybe what you want to do is start a book club. How will you find other people who want to start a book club, and how will you reach them?
